Subject: [sfraves]nrr:More police on the street -- more kids in jail 

http://www.gettingit.com/article/594

When Cops Attack!
More police on the street -- more kids in jail

It's a morning like any other. The family is sitting round the breakfast 
table watching Good Morning America. Then the front door gets kicked in. 
Screaming at the tops of their lungs, a heavily armored SWAT team bursts in 
waving automatic weapons. Before you lift a finger, you're hog-tied on the 
kitchen floor at gunpoint. A nervous cop threatens to shoot your dog to stop 
it from barking. Someone waves a piece of paper in front of your face saying 
something about a search warrant, while the police spread out across the 
house, pulling open drawers, throwing the contents into Hefty bags. Welcome 
to your first starring role in America's Most Wanted.

But this isn't just another Fox special; it's a growing political reality. 
SWAT raids and confiscations are becoming an everyday tactic against even 
the smallest crime; and, as many activists have recently discovered, that 
includes the offense of mouthing off once too often against the powers that 
be. Fifteen-year-old Brenton Gicker and his family found out this unpleasant 
fact the hard way, and their story is a chilling tale of the extremes to 
which one police department will go to prove their point.

On October 17, 1998, Gicker, along with a ragtag collection of 50 adolescent 
punk rockers and other anarchists, staged a demonstration at the Eugene, 
Oregon Nike Factory Store, protesting working conditions at the company's 
overseas facilities. During the rally, about 10 individuals entered the 
store and trashed the place, smashing Halloween pumpkins, knocking over 
displays, and even breaking a window. The police were on hand, but no 
arrests were made at the time.

Two weeks later, on the morning of November 2, Brenton's parents Janet and 
Randall Gicker were preparing to leave the house to run errands, when 
Randall spotted several darkly-clad figures scurrying outside the window. As 
he went to investigate, a battering ram smashed in the door and 
approximately 13 police officers in paramilitary uniforms stormed into the 
house, guns drawn, and ordered the Gicker family to the floor.

The two-page search warrant listed Brenton Gicker as the prime target in 
connection with the October 17 Nike "riot." The evidence sheets list over 
360 separate items taken from the Gicker house. Brenton's room was cleared 
out as the cops took posters from his walls, his computer, assorted books, 
pamphlets, and a Ronald Reagan hockey mask. Janet, who runs an online 
business selling collectibles on eBay, lost her computer and her personal 
files, as well as the family's videotape of the Bruce Willis film Die Hard, 
into the police evidence bag.

Gicker was formally arrested at school on February 8 and charged with 
burglary, disorderly conduct, riot, and criminal mischief. After several 
months confined under house arrest, he faced a bench trial (meaning his fate 
was decided by a judge rather than a jury) in juvenile court on May 28. His 
lawyer, Don Diment, filed a discovery motion and found that the case against 
Gicker was pretty thin at best -- amounting to a smudged set of fingerprints 
found on a placard at the demonstration and a coerced "confession" from one 
Sean Downing. Downing, 22, was picked up in mid-January and charged with 
second-degree burglary in connection with the October 17 event. Under 
intense interrogation, Downing fingered Gicker as one of the culprits, even 
though the two had never met before.

The story doesn't end there. At the annual "Reclaim the Streets" 
demonstration on June 18, police spotted someone wearing a straw hat and a 
pair of overalls behaving badly. Naturally, they assumed it was Gicker. He 
was re-arrested by Eugene Police Officer Greg Kalef on July 5, charged with 
violating the terms of his release, and held in juvenile hall for four days. 
The charges were only dropped after documentary footage, aired on a local 
cable community service channel, showed Gicker at the demonstration in a 
completely different set of clothing and behaving in an orderly manner.

Unable to admit they made a mistake, the police pushed for a harsher 
probation for Gicker. "I just can't believe it," his mother complained, 
"they were proposing community service as punishment. Now it's this big 
probation thing where he is not allowed anywhere in town. The probation 
officer says he's not even allowed to go to the library and read about 
anarchy. He's 15 years old and he is being persecuted for his beliefs."

The trial lasted all of three hours. Downing recanted his testimony, yet 
Gicker was still found guilty of burglary and disorderly conduct. On July 
14, Gicker was sentenced to a year in a youth correctional facility. The 
court then suspended the correctional facility sentence, and placed him on 
an extremely restrictive year-long probation. He is not allowed to be 
anywhere near the downtown Eugene area without the company of his parents, 
and must adhere to a daily 10 p.m. curfew. Despite being found not guilty on 
the rioting charge, he was ordered to pay a $400 restitution fine and to 
perform an additional 40 hours of community service.

"The cops were just making me an example, which is funny," Gicker says 
philosophically. "There was a whole lot of people at the Nike protest, and 
who knows how many actually trashed the store. I'm guessing quite a few. 
Only one person gets screwed over, you know? So it's well worth it."

Despite motions filed on their behalf, the Gickers have yet to receive their 
confiscated property. In order to continue her online business, Janet had to 
shell out over $1,300 for additional computer equipment.

Not Enough Donuts to Go 'Round

While the Gicker case can be viewed as an extreme example of cop behavior, 
Christian Parenti, author of Lockdown America: Police and Prisons in the Age 
of Crisis, sees this as a disturbing trend. "Crime is down," Parenti says, 
"The police are not [dealing] with a lot of murders and revenge killings 
they have to solve. They are looking for action. There is no end in sight. 
Clinton's crime bills of '92 and '96 have put 100,000 new cops on the 
street. Some police forces have doubled in the last eight years."

The Gickers are not alone. Several incidents have occurred that bear 
striking similarity. In Tampa, Florida, a group known as the "Tampa Three" 
was subjected to FCC-sanctioned SWAT raids in an effort to shut down three 
pirate radio stations broadcasting in the area. Doug Brewer, operator of The 
Party Pirate, had $100,000 worth of electrical equipment seized on the 
morning of November 19, 1997. Kelly Benjamin of 87x was charged with 
possession when the cops found marijuana at his house, and Arthur Kobres was 
prosecuted for operating his Patriot-affiliated unlicensed station. All 
three have yet to have any of their equipment returned.

A more recent case is that of Kevin Keating. Keating was stopped by the San 
Francisco Police Department and arrested for carrying a backpack full of 
posters and pasting materials. The police were looking for "Nestor Mahkno," 
the sinister man behind a terrorist group calling itself "the Mission Yuppie 
Eradication Project." The MYEP's posters targeted new upscale bars and 
restaurants that have sprouted up like weeds in the working class 
neighborhood, vowing to reduce them to "picturesque ruins" during the "major 
urban riots" against "cigar bar clowns." In other words, the kind of 
telegraph-pole hyperbole you expect from art school refugees -- not from the 
Symbionese Liberation Army.

After being held incommunicado for over 15 hours, Keating was formally 
charged with a felony count of making terrorist threats and one misdemeanor 
count of malicious mischief. During those 15 hours, the SFPD executed a raid 
on his home and carted off boxes of his possessions. According to the 
35-page evidence sheet, this included over 70 books, his computer, 
diskettes, and correspondence; all the materials of a nearly complete 16 mm 
film project; and a picture of Malcolm X. Charges against Keating were 
dropped pending further investigation, though he can be re-indicted up to a 
year from now. In the meantime, his possessions will remain with the SFPD 
indefinitely.

The stories of Gicker, Keating, Brewer, Benjamin, and Kobres represent the 
unfortunate state of policing in America. Apparently, repeated viewing of 
those reality cop shows has had its desired effect, making SWAT raids and 
confiscations accepted, commonplace events of everyday policing. Parenti 
concludes that this is an example of the supposedly non-political police 
force acting out their true political purpose. "The function of the police 
is to suppress dissidents and manage surplus populations. They do that if 
these populations are white or black; if they are well behaved or ill 
behaved. In a class society, the police always have this social control."

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: SCARY ! improved trust or Big Brother ?

http://www.againsttcpa.com

how long till this happens? Soon I bet.

-------------------------

What are TCPA and Palladium?

TCPA stands for the Trusted Computing Platform Alliance, an initiative led
by Intel. Their stated goal is 'a new computing platform for the next
century that will provide for improved trust in the PC platform.' Palladium
is software that Microsoft says it plans to incorporate in future versions
of Windows; it will build on the TCPA hardware, and will add some extra
features.

What does TCPA / Palladium do, in ordinary English?

It provides a computing platform on which you can't tamper with the
applications, and where these applications can communicate securely with the
vendor. The obvious application is digital rights management (DRM): Disney
will be able to sell you DVDs that will decrypt and run on a Palladium
platform, but which you won't be able to copy. The music industry will be
able to sell you music downloads that you won't be able to swap. They will
be able to sell you CDs that you'll only be able to play three times, or
only on your birthday. All sorts of new marketing possibilities will open
up.

TCPA / Palladium will also make it much harder for you to run unlicensed
software. Pirate software can be detected and deleted remotely. It will also
make it easier for people to rent software rather than buying it; and if you
stop paying the rent, then not only does the software stop working but so
may the files it created. For years, Bill Gates has dreamed of finding a way
to make the Chinese pay for software: Palladium could be the answer to his
prayer.



from : http://www.againsttcpa.com/tcpa-faq-en.html

-------------------------

AUDiOTACTiX "control, i'm here"

From sfraves-return-101735-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu May 01 19:58:30 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-101735-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 9531 invoked from network); 1 May 2003 19:58:30 -0000
Message-ID: <20030501195827.29030.qmail@web41807.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 1 May 2003 12:58:27 -0700 (PDT)
From: Psychedelic Armadillo <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
To: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>, Sean Griffith <srg@pdx.edu>
Cc: JBlaze112@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0304301210420.2695-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] A naive attempt at comparing the rave scene to a revolutionary movement

--- AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
> 
> On Wed, 30 Apr 2003, Sean Griffith wrote:
> -&e->I had a vegetation-induced conversation with
> Dr. Graham over this one,
> -&e->actually. Someone (who's name I can't remember!
> :/) pointed out something
> -&e->pretty apt.
> -&e->
> -&e->Assuming raves as a movement and rave
> collectives as groups become unified
> -&e->and organized: I.e., groups like Cloud Factory
> become Non Profit
> -&e->Organizations and bill themselves out as art
> groups, these groups then
> -&e->ascend as minor corporate/NPO entities, and
> raves (like the acid tests)
> -&e->become largely commercial affairs
> (...become?...), this will just be a
> -&e->repeat of what happened in the 60s. Realize
> that those kids who were 18-25
> -&e->in the sixties are now in their 40s and 50s,
> and are controlling the
> -&e->united states as people in their 40s and 50s
> always have.
>
> Wait... why in hell would you imply that CF became a
> non-profit in order to cash in on anything?  For
> one, CF, the collective is not a NPO...
> (CFCA, an arts wing started by people within
> cloudfactory is).  And second, given just about
> every other promoter in the area, how fucking
> dare you even imply that CF would have anything to
> do with the scene going commercial?

don't get yer knickers in a twist laddie...he said
that the npo-status thing is part and parcel with the
overall trend towards forming organizations. party
crews form production companies, collectives form
NPOs. it expresses itself differently in different
contexts but it's the same dynamic at work.

> Why not point the finger at the decline
> that's already
> happening, looked at the price of a Skills ticket
> lately?  Checked your
> email and seen nasty list scraped spam lately?  How
> about clubs that claim
> to have the attendee in mind, but will treat you
> like shit in order to
> stay open because of draconian police guidelines?
>
> A lot of people in CF are already well into their
> 30s, and we happen to
> see what we do as a sustainable and wonderful thing,
> still going strong.

but that's his point, man. it's grown up. it's
organized. it happened before, it'll happen again.
instead of an anarchic force with the power to change
things, it's a sustainable, wonderful thing, still
going strong. sounds like the lyrics to some Japanese
company's corporate song.

(hey, that rhymed! note to self: if ever do rap album,
remember above lyrics.)

> -&e->This is just another generation going through
> it's growing spurts,
> -&e->organizing, flourishing, only to become the
> next generation of industry
> -&e->leaders. Unless, of course, it's different this
> time.
> -&e->
> -&e->Unless, of course, those of you who actually
> respect rave culture as a
> -&e->movement, rather than a business, remain true
> to yourselves.
> 
> Maybe I'm going off here, but why in hell would you
> choose one of the few
> flat budget party throwing collectives (it costs to
> attend what it costs
> to throw it for most of their parties, when they
> aren't free as many of
> them have been) as your example of what's going
> wrong?  There are far
> better examples of promoters and collectives that
> have lost their way in
> our scene.

I totally disagree. first, the guy didn't actually
single out CF at all. he mentioned them in passing.
second, CF lost its way hardcore.

the Cloud Factory is basically a communist
organization. nothing wrong with that in and of itself
-- communism is incredibly useful for developing
countries. it prevents stronger countries from taking
stuff away by force, because it pools resources along
traditional tribal lines.

however -- when you've got a group of middle-class
white people pooling their resources along traditional
tribal lines, how the fuck is that supposed to be
cool?

don't get me wrong, I've been to Cloud Factory events
which were absolutely wonderful. but the philosophy is
completely ass-backwards. that's why you have kickass
musicians and DJs at every Cloud Factory event -- yet
you can't guarantee you'll actually get to hear them,
because it all depends on whether or not their name
gets pulled out of the hat. CF makes it possible to go
on drug-infused picnics with the best DJs around and
not hear a single one of them spin. CF is completely
fucking insane.

sometimes CF events are wonderful and I take back
every bad thing I've said about them. words are
meaningless and forgettable. but the thing is --
actually, this is a total tangent, but blame mercury
retrograde, because here I go:

I'm getting a Transmat tattoo soon. Growing up in
Chicago, I heard "Strings of Life" on the radio when I
was a teenager. And the thing is, that wasn't the
result of a collective enterprise. Transmat Records is
and was a business.

> -&e->If the trend goes towards money-making, just
> like in the 60s, when
> -&e->psychadelia became big business, those of you
> who don't sell your souls
> -&e->will just be the next generation of burnt-out
> hippies. You know, the ones
> -&e->your parents told you did all that acid in the
> 60s (like they didn't. ha
> -&e->ha) and smoked all that dope and turned out as
> useless people that didn't
> -&e->'contribute' to the corporate-industrial model
> by becoming good little
> -&e->proles and etc.
> 
> Well, for one, they didn't all burn out and give up.
>  For two, the ones we
> remember (i.e. - Bill Graham, Grateful Dead) were
> sellouts to a degree
> back then even.

the Grateful Dead created something which was
surprisingly cool and powerful. the vibe at Dead shows
was a textbook example of how musicians and fans can
create entire alternate worlds together simply thru
their love of the same sounds. selling out arenas is
not necessarily the same thing as simply selling out.
I've gone to Dead shows just to smoke pot in the
parking lot. (in fact I was doing just that at the
last show Jerry Garcia ever played before he died.)

and how many thousands of lives did Jerry Garcia
change? credit where credit is due. I think what the
Grateful Dead did was amazingly cool, even though I
don't even slightly understand the appeal of their
music. (I'll admit I've got a few Dead CDs, but then
again I have hundreds of CDs.)

> CF was born out of the ethic of "if you want to know
> what's going on, do
> it yourself", and along with a couple other groups
> like Pacific, FnF and
> others with a similar ethic, they stand for the
> preservation of the scene
> past when it's profitable... hell they have for
> years.  These groups have
> kept doing what they do while watching countless
> promoters make their
> money and run.

Yeah -- but what about the people who make their money
and stay in the game? CF preserves the underground,
but the underground is a birthing point. Preserving
the underground sometimes seems to me like the
equivalent of prolonging your childhood. When Derrick
May was underground, he was the coolest thing in the
universe. Now that he makes a living off his music, he
stills seems pretty cool. In fact these days he
reminds me of a 21st-century Miles Davis.

Once upon a time Paul Oakenfold was underground too.
He made one of my favorite records of 1992 --
"Loaded," which was a Primal Scream remix. Oakenfold
is not that cool, he's more cheesey, but again --
credit where credit is due. These guys from London and
Detroit, and their fans, they created an entire
alternate world based on their love of the same
sounds. What they've done is incredible -- but if
they've moved on from the underground, what is it in
the underground that deserves preservation? What is CF
doing that is so worthwhile?

These aren't just rhetorical questions. I'm genuinely
curious. I mean it is possible that I'm missing
something.

But, I skipped the DEMF for a CF event once. I
remember scratching my head and wondering what the
fuck I was thinking. And now? Now I don't have the
money to go, and now this year's DEMF is gonna be
amazing. Derrick May won control back from the
corporate assholes who were running the show. He's
gonna do something absolutely incredible, and I want
to be there.

(wah wah wah. poor me...)

> I for one would love to see Skills, F8, FGE,
> Brainchild/Orgy or hell, even
> Burning Man seek out NPO status.

Burning Man could do it easily. In fact it's a really
good idea. A Burning Man arts-promotion NPO affiliate,
analogous to the CF organization, would have the
funding to make a difference, and would have access to
a vastly larger number of artists.

Someone in CFCA should talk about that to Sameer. (He
has the same lawyer as Burning Man.)


Giles


ps -- two more things.

1. things are going to change soon. it's inevitable,
because things are getting stagnant, and after things
getting stagnant, things change. so, if CF gets
dissed, don't be taking it personally.

2. the Grateful Dead are actually a really interesting
example because it may be that they form the model or
precursor for what eventually happens with the rave
scene. it's getting bigger and bigger, and in Europe
it's been huge for a decade. something's going to
happen. the only question is what.

I basically think there are two alternate futures for
the rave scene: the Moby future, and the DEMF future.

pray for the DEMF future.

Moby is sending a Terminator back in time to kill me.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Santorum's No-Sex Platform

--=====================_13499343==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Santorum's No-Sex Platform

By Dan Reines, Nerve.com
April 30, 2003

At some low level, your heart's gotta go out to Rick Santorum.

Not because the left hates him; that's to be expected, really. The=20
third-ranking Republican in the United States Senate, Santorum earned an=20
avalanche of criticism after the Associated Press published a profile of=20
him in which he weighed in on Lawrence v. Texas. That's the case =96 pending=
=20
before the Supreme Court =96 in which two men were arrested on sodomy=
 charges=20
after Houston police responded to a false complaint and found them having=20
sex in a private home. "If the Supreme Court says that you have the right=20
to consensual sex within your home," the Pennsylvania Senator reportedly=20
fumed, "then you have the right to bigamy, you have the right to polygamy,=
=20
you have the right to incest, you have the right to adultery. You have the=
=20
right to anything." Santorum went on to group gay marriage with bestiality=
=20
and pedophilia.

Well, bad news and bad politics travel fast, particularly in Washington,=20
and as soon as the story hit the wire, gay-rights advocates were calling=20
for Santorum's head, or at least his party leadership post, as were=20
Democrats and many in the press. But hey, what the hell, it's just the=20
commies, the queers and the damned liberal media, right? Well, yeah. Except=
=20
that it's not. 'Cause now Owen Allred is pissed at Santorum too.

Who's Owen Allred? Why he's the eighty-nine-year-old patriarch of Utah's=20
pro-polygamy sect United Apostolic Brethen, that's who, and he told the=20
Philadelphia Daily News last week that Santorum's comments =96 that is, his=
=20
brazen lumping of buggery with multiwifing =96 made him "so mad I want to=20
swear" (which is to say, pretty goddamned mad). Not that Allred necessarily=
=20
disagrees with Santorum; not in principle, anyway. As he'd explained the=20
day before to his hometown Salt Lake Tribune, "The people of the United=20
States are doing whatever they can to do away with the sacred rights of=20
marriage." (And marriage. And marriage. And marriage.) Nonetheless, Allred=
=20
said (in the Daily News) that the Catholic conservative "is an insult to=20
Christianity." Yikes. This from a man with eight wives.

Of course, the pile-on doesn't end there. Even Santorum's GOP colleagues=20
have gotten into the act. "Senator Santorum's views are not held by this=20
Republican and many others in our party," said Rhode Island Sen. Lincoln=20
Chafee, and Maine's Olympia Snowe added, "I believe Senator Santorum's=20
remarks undermine Republican principles of inclusion and opportunity." (As=
=20
damning as they were, neither statement held the entertainment value of=20
Nebraska Democrat Bob Kerrey's reported onetime crack: "Santorum? Is that=20
Latin for 'asshole'?")

Ah, but back to the matter at hand, the plight of poor, misunderstood Rick=
=20
Santorum. As David Smith, a senior strategist with the Human Rights=20
Campaign, put it, "He seemed to put gay people on the same moral and legal=
=20
plane as someone who would commit incest."

Santorum, of course, says he meant no such thing. "I have no problem with=20
homosexuality," he said in the same interview. "I have a problem with=20
homosexual acts" =96 all but begging for an update to the old drug joke:=20
Problem with gay sex? Move to the Castro, Rick. No more fucking problem.

The great irony here is that Santorum's right =96 examined more closely, his=
=20
comments on Lawrence v. Texas aren't actually homophobic after all. No, as=
=20
it turns out, Rick Santorum isn't anti-gay, he's just anti-sex.

Think that's silly? After all, Santorum has six kids. It's safe to assume=20
he's been engaging in something resembling sex with Mrs. Santorum. But read=
=20
the quote again. "If the Supreme Court says that you have the right to=20
consensual sex within your home, then you have the right to bigamy, you=20
have the right to . . . "

Catch that? Not consensual gay sex, but consensual sex. Period. It seems=20
Rick Santorum is making a pretty classic slippery slope argument, the twist=
=20
here being that the slope begins sloping not in the bedrooms of West=20
Hollywood and the West Village, but in your bedroom and mine as well. In=20
the Senator's eyes, the right to sexual privacy among consenting adults is=
=20
not a given: "It all comes from, I would argue, this right to privacy that=
=20
doesn't exist in my opinion in the United States Constitution, this right=20
that was created, it was created in Griswold [v. Connecticut]," Santorum=20
said, referring to the 1965 case that established the Constitutional right=
=20
of heterosexual couples to use contraception within the context of a=20
marriage. Yeah. So if Santorum can't get behind that, he's not going to get=
=20
behind any form sexual privacy, your own particular kinks =96 or lack=
 thereof=20
=96 notwithstanding.

All of which brings us to the heart of the matter. Santorum has been=20
vilified by the left and abandoned by some on the right for turning a legal=
=20
case into a platform for his bigoted views, and rightly so. But in reality,=
=20
Lawrence v. Texas isn't about gay sex at all. Well, okay, it is =96 the=20
sodomy practiced by the couple in question would have been legal if one of=
=20
them had been a woman (or a horse =96 gay sex may be illegal in Texas, but=
=20
bestiality isn't). But what Lawrence v. Texas is really about is privacy.=20
In Texas =96 and in more than a quarter of all states, it's worth noting =96=
 it=20
remains illegal for consenting adults to express their sexuality, even in=20
private, unless their sexuality meets standards laid out by the state=20
legislature.

If you're straight, do you perhaps think this doesn't concern you? Think=20
again. Because Santorum's right =96 it is a slippery slope. Seen as a=
 privacy=20
issue rather than a sex issue, the high court's decision in Texas impacts=20
your right to oral sex, it impacts your right to masturbation, it impacts=20
your right to contraception =96 hell, it impacts your right to everything=
 but=20
the missionary position, man on top, and it may just impact that too. In=20
short, it impacts your right to any kind of sexual autonomy, particularly=20
if you happen to be part of a "second-class" relationship.

That's not my term, by the way. William Donohue, president of the=20
conservative Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights, classifies=20
heterosexual marriage as "special" and all other relationships as=20
second-class =96 in other words, not just the cousin-fuckers and the=20
wife-collectors, but committed homosexual relationships and, yes,=20
unmarried, sexually active straight couples (uncomfortable yet?). And, as=20
Donohue puts it in throwing his organization's considerable support behind=
=20
Santorum, if the law allows those kinds of relationships, well then we may=
=20
as well "just let everybody fornicate and let kids be born into a society=20
of bastards."

Uh-huh. The way I see it, as long as Texas law =96 and the U.S. Constitution=
=20
=96 fails to protect our most private rights, well, a society of bastards is=
=20
exactly what we've got.

Dan Reines is a writer living in Los Angeles. This article originally=20
appeared in a slightly different form in nerve.com.

http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=3D15779


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

=20
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of=20
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the=20
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sad Sad day for us all:  Anti-rave legislation

--=====================_18445584==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I think it's important to understand we in the EDM community are not going 
to surrender and accept this infringement of our rights.  Even now, efforts 
are underway to repeal those provisions of the Amber Alert Act that affect 
our communities nationwide.

I urge all of you concerned with the future of our dance floors to support 
those organizations who are organizing opposition to this legislation.  The 
Drug Policy Alliance is addressing the rave crackdown in a number of ways. 
It has established an organization call the Electronic Music Defense and 
Education Fund. In 2002 the Alliance, with the help of its supporters, led 
an aggressive campaign to stop the federal RAVE Act, which would have given 
federal prosecutors new powers to shut down raves or other musical events 
they didn't like and punish businessmen and women for hosting or promoting 
them. The Alliance also has assisted the ACLU in its successful challenge 
to federal government restrictions rave promoters and participants. In 
addition, the Alliance has sponsored a series of public forums on rave 
culture and is working with dancers, performers and youth advocates to 
draft model legislation regulating electronic music dance events in a 
manner that protects First Amendment freedoms and promotes the health and 
safety of all involved.

The Alliance is now working with the ACLU to repeal the RAVE act.  Though 
I'm as financially strapped as everyone these days, I've made a donation to 
the Alliance and the ACLU and I hope those of you who can afford it will do 
the same.  Info below.

Much love,

Apollo

___________________________________________________


Bush Signs RAVE Act, Drug Policy Alliance Seeks Repeal
Wed, April 30, 2003


Today President Bush signed the well-supported but highly controversial 
Amber Alert, a far-reaching child protection legislation carrying a number 
of contentious provisions.

"After months and months of trying, we've finally gotten a green light for 
a national AMBER Alert program," says Senator Patrick Leahy (D-VT). "The 
problem has never been winning enough support to pass it.  The problem has 
been that our bill has garnered such strong support that it has been abused 
as a sweetener for highly controversial add-ons."

One such abusive provision, the RAVE Act, was tacked on to the legislation 
at the final minute. Last year Drug Policy Alliance and its supporters 
managed to squash the bill that would make it easier to arrest event 
holders for the drug offenses of their patrons, however, the determined 
Senator Biden (D-DE) snuck the harmful legislation through Congress on the 
back of the otherwise unrelated Amber Alert.

The next year will be crucial for the fight against the RAVE Act. As the 
law comes into play, Drug Policy Alliance will continue to get the word out 
about the dangerous legislation, create guidelines for business owners to 
help them deal with the law's complications, and start the fight for 
repeal/reform.

Drug Policy Alliance is not alone in its misgivings. Some Democrats, who 
support a stand-alone version of the Amber Alert bill passed by the Senate, 
argued that provisions in the bill reducing federal judges' discretion in 
sentencing criminals should have been debated on the floor. The provisions 
limit judicial discretion in a broad range of federal cases and in protest, 
federal judges and legal scholars, including some Republicans, are calling 
it an assault on judicial independence. Some judges have even threatened to 
resign. They argue that the legislation further erodes the discretion and 
authority of trial judges and that such discretion is necessary in certain 
cases, such as those involving minor participants in the drug trade and 
girlfriends or spouses of drug sellers.

Parts of the loaded legislation also take the country in the opposite 
direction to recent reforms in some states where strict sentencing laws 
have been eased. Many states have eliminated harsh three-strikes laws and 
mandatory minimum sentences to reduce prison numbers as they struggle to 
balance their budgets.

Despite complaints about restrictions and supplementary provisions, House 
and Senate Democrats voted for the Amber Alert bill. The House passed the 
bill 400-25 and the Senate approved in on a 98-0 vote.

With your support, we will take on Attorney General John Ashcroft and the 
DEA every time they use the RAVE Act to try to shut down electronic dance 
events, raves, rock and hip hop concerts, hemp festivals, circuit parties, 
and other events.  We will organize thousands of people to oppose this new 
government intrusion. We will launch an aggressive and relentless lobbying 
campaign to repeal the RAVE Act.

To do it, we need your help.  This campaign costs real money. Contributions 
from people like you help us pay for lobbyists, grassroots organizing, and 
all the faxes we send to Congressional offices.   Please donate $10, $20, 
$50, $100, $500, $1,000 or whatever you can afford at:

https://secure.ga3.org/05/raveact



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A naive attempt at comparing the rave scene to a revolutionary
 movement

--------------020302000800040207080301
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

thought i'd chime in on this...


Psychedelic Armadillo wrote:

>second, CF lost its way hardcore.
>
>the Cloud Factory is basically a communist
>organization. nothing wrong with that in and of itself
>-- communism is incredibly useful for developing
>countries. it prevents stronger countries from taking
>stuff away by force, because it pools resources along
>traditional tribal lines.
>
>however -- when you've got a group of middle-class
>white people pooling their resources along traditional
>tribal lines, how the fuck is that supposed to be
>cool?
>  
>
so transmat is 'cool' because its a business (that associates itself 
and/or its members with events thrown by massive corporations), but cf 
is 'uncool' because its a group, in your words, of middle-class white 
people pooling their resources along traditional tribal lines. that's 
the message?


>don't get me wrong, I've been to Cloud Factory events
>which were absolutely wonderful. but the philosophy is
>completely ass-backwards. that's why you have kickass
>musicians and DJs at every Cloud Factory event -- yet
>you can't guarantee you'll actually get to hear them,
>because it all depends on whether or not their name
>gets pulled out of the hat. CF makes it possible to go
>on drug-infused picnics with the best DJs around and
>not hear a single one of them spin. CF is completely
>fucking insane.
>  
>

how does: "you have kickass musicians and DJs at every Cloud Factory event"
corellate with: "not hear a single one of them spin"

?


<snip>

>their love of the same sounds. selling out arenas is
>not necessarily the same thing as simply selling out.
>  
>

i'm curious, what is your definition of selling out? you could draw a 
distinction between burning man and a dead show - they are both massive 
in terms of the numbers of participants and take big dollars to pull off 
- but one occurs (occurred)  in a venue inherently fused with brand 
exposure and strategic partnerships of the biggest corporations in the 
world ...


>Yeah -- but what about the people who make their money
>and stay in the game? CF preserves the underground,
>but the underground is a birthing point. Preserving
>the underground sometimes seems to me like the
>equivalent of prolonging your childhood.
>
preserving the underground seems to me like the equivalent of creating a 
place for things more intimate and driven by the love of an art, as 
opposed to (on the extreme end) being a statistic in a demographic 
study, tagged as a viable consumer for target-marketed products. maybe 
its just me. i find it more desirable to participate in something where 
i have a sense of being relevant as a person and possibly an artist, 
with something to offer to the collective experience other than being an 
attendant with money in hand and a pair of eyeballs to soak up brand 
impressions.



<snip>

>sounds. What they've done is incredible -- but if
>they've moved on from the underground, what is it in
>the underground that deserves preservation? What is CF
>doing that is so worthwhile?
>  
>
they are having a many-to-many dialogue with people. they draw a 
distinction between attendants and participants. they promote and live a 
genuine sense of family and relationship. they are doing something out 
of love and passion. they are bringing together many different kinds of 
artists and exploring a broader creative territory. i personally find 
these traits worthy of my admiration.



>1. things are going to change soon. it's inevitable,
>because things are getting stagnant, and after things
>getting stagnant, things change. so, if CF gets
>dissed, don't be taking it personally.
>  
>
interesting. i find CF to be one of the agents of said change, a group 
actually doing something about said stagnance.


>it's getting bigger and bigger, and in Europe
>it's been huge for a decade. something's going to
>happen. the only question is what.
>  
>
the only question is what are you going to make happen.
if the scene has one core trait attached to its genesis, its "do it 
yourself".

-joshua

--------------020302000800040207080301--


From sfraves-return-101745-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri May 02 03:31:41 2003

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 29722 invoked from network); 2 May 2003 03:31:41 -0000
From: BodhiInSF@aol.com
Message-ID: <f6.2ba8199c.2be34093@aol.com>
Date: Thu, 1 May 2003 23:31:31 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
CC: raversforpeace@yahoogroups.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="part1_f6.2ba8199c.2be34093_boundary"
X-Mailer: 6.0 sub 10577
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] IT'S OFFICIAL: RAVING IS ILLEGIAL IN AMERICA!!!

--part1_f6.2ba8199c.2be34093_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

  As most of you know, the anti-rave legislation (S. 226, the Illicit Drug 
Proliferation Act) was signed into law, snuck in the Amber alert bill. And 
like the signing of over 200 death warrants while Governor of Texas, "pro 
life" Prez Bush signed our death warrant to fun in America, that country that 
wants to infect "freedom" to the rest of the world; freedom defined as the 
freedom of "free trade", meaning radical capitalism where 10 year olds to 
work in Disney & Walmart sweetshops for 10c an hour, and having governments 
that will  expose their ass holes (at the point of a cruse missile if 
necessary) to the plan of the "New American Century doctrine, the modern, 
international version of the Manifest Destiny doctrine.
  So, what does this all mean now? Technically, it is illegal, not only to 
rave, but any event, rock concerts, hiphop, punk shows, back yard BB-Q's, 
house parties, wedding functions, any place where people congregate and drugs 
can be found, the promoter of the event as well as the property owner can now 
be subject to the crack house laws, which means they can have their property 
and assets confiscated, be fined $500,000 and face a 20 year prison sentence. 
Everyone in the music/entertainment business is having a cold chill go down 
their spines with this, and not only will venue owners think twice about 
renting a space for a rave, but any event, especially associated with music 
and entertainment of any genre. Sure, raves and music concerts could 
theatrically go on, but in order to assure that all events will be 100% drug 
free, which is the only option promoters and venue owners have been cornered 
into now to CTA's, patrons would have to be subject to literal strip and 
cavity searches, dog sniffs and be 1984'd all through the event. And I don't 
think not that many people will find an event worth going to be put through 
all that crap, even by those who don't do drugs. 
  So, the side walk of night life and partying of any kind could very well 
roll up in America and helping, amongst other things going on, to fast track 
the US to become the (Fundamentalist) Christian version of Ayatollah 
Khomeini's Iran or the Tallaban's Afghanistan of the Western world! I don't 
think we have yet digested what has been done. 
  One fallout of this bill that can happen, and it's going to happen a lot, 
is landlords being snoopy with their renters, looking for bongs and drug 
paraphernalia and would (to CTA's too) evict anyone accused of drug use or 
not rent to anyone who may (profiling) look like a drug user. All landlords 
are now subject to this fucked up law too and can face the consequences if 
the police show up at a house or apartment they rent and find drugs. 
Defiantly another fallout, mentioning going to raves or wearing candy jewelry 
at work or school could force people to mandatory drug testing. You can say 
all this is unconstitutional, but say that to Japanese Americans hauled off 
to concentration camps in WW II and Muslims sitting in detention centers 
today with no right to legal representation. More fascism is to come. You 
cannot pass this off as some conspiracy theory or an over abundance of 
paranoia anymore. This is serious! Hey, what about having something called 
"Operation American Freedom" here at home?
  But then, we did ask for much this, karma redux, But despite these fast 
becoming dark days, there is a bright side. I will go into our karma redux 
and the bright side in another post.
  Pacifica's Democracy Now program did a good expose on the anti-rave bill 
and Free Speech Radio News mentioned it in some detail as well. You can 
listen to these programs at: democracynow.org and fsrn.org and click on live 
audio program for 5/1/03.
  Peace to all, Bodhi ^ _ ^

--part1_f6.2ba8199c.2be34093_boundary--

Message-ID: <Law15-F45f69aZbLAX3000122c2@hotmail.com>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] IT'S OFFICIAL: RAVING IS ILLEGIAL, a rebirth

Although the Anti-rave legislation sucks a fat nut, and I do not support it, 
I am kind of excited to see a rebirth of underground culture.  I think that 
the legislation will have the largest effect on mainstream parties and clubs 
(which sucks), but I don't see it eliminating undergrounds.  The detrimental 
effect it will have on undergrounds is that it will in essence push them 
further underground.  Making everything a little bit more shady and a little 
bit less safe (like no DanceSafe etc).  This may put a lot of sleazy (and 
not so sleazy) promoters out of a job and that sucks too.  I suppose this 
type of pressure has never been applied to such a wide array of party 
people.  Proactive voting, political pressure (applied when available), a 
motivated spirit, and some comfy dancing shoes are the weapons that we are 
still armed with.  I hope that we can all use these tools to reform this 
oppression.  It's gonna be a long march to victory, but I can assure you 
that I'll be dancing all the way.
God Speed Soldiers,
)))-Trendy-(((

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: our government is full of sissy squares... 

I suspect that the government's resentment for drugs is somewhat similar to 
the Amish people's resentment for technology... 

You know I think someone like John Ashcroft fears taking drugs like an Amish 
person would fear riding a roller coaster... Sure everyone who's been on one 
knows it's safe (with the proper safty straps and harnesses) but just by 
watching what a roller coaster does and how the people act when they are 
riding one... i think is enough to make any Amish person go running home to 
their farmland.  

And have you ever noticed how people always say "they don't like roller 
coasters..." instead of "they are scared to ride a roller coaster..." 

things that make you go hmm...

Now this is not to say that people who don't take drugs should be pressured 
into doing so by calling them "sissys" but i think we should just get it out 
in the open that when it comes down to it, the truth is, people actually FEAR 
drugs, mostly for either superstitious or religious reasons. Also the fear 
comes from exaggerated propaganda created by people who have never touched 
drugs. I think a lot of people who have never done drugs are afraid that they 
will "freak out" if they do them, or that some wierd aspect about their 
personality will come out in the open, and they don't want people to see them 
like that. This is especially true for members of our government....

Transmat is unequivocally cool, and it is a business.
CF I have profound ambivalence about, and it is not a
business.

the becauses came from you.

> >don't get me wrong, I've been to Cloud Factory

> >which were absolutely wonderful. but the philosophy
> is
> >completely ass-backwards. that's why you have
> kickass

> >fucking insane.

> every Cloud Factory event"
> corellate with: "not hear a single one of them spin"
> 
> ?

go to a CF event. you could hear kickass musicians and
DJs spin. you could equally well hear non-kickass
musicians and DJs, while the aforementioned kickass
musicians and DJs were standing next to you listening
to said non-kickass folks.

nothing against those who don't kick ass, but not
everybody who spins is a DJ. I've been spinning for
five years and I only just recently got to the point
where I feel comfortable calling myself a DJ.

(am I modest? or honest?)

> <snip>
> 
> >their love of the same sounds. selling out arenas
> is
> >not necessarily the same thing as simply selling
> out.
> >  
> >
> 
> i'm curious, what is your definition of selling out?

Puff Daddy. Fred Durst. etc.

> you could draw a 
> distinction between burning man and a dead show -
> they are both massive 
> in terms of the numbers of participants and take big
> dollars to pull off

> fused with brand 
> exposure and strategic partnerships of the biggest

???

I'm assuming you mean the Dead shows were a corporate
environment? I gotta wonder if you've been to any. I
mean it's true that you could buy Pepsi there but
other than that I'm not really sure where you're
coming from.

> >Yeah -- but what about the people who make their
> money
> >and stay in the game? CF preserves the underground,
> >but the underground is a birthing point. Preserving
> >the underground sometimes seems to me like the
> >equivalent of prolonging your childhood.
> >
> preserving the underground seems to me like the
> equivalent of creating a 
> place for things more intimate and driven by the
> love of an art, as 
> opposed to (on the extreme end) being a statistic in
> a demographic 
> study, tagged as a viable consumer for
> target-marketed products. maybe 
> its just me. i find it more desirable to participate
> in something where 
> i have a sense of being relevant as a person and
> possibly an artist, 
> with something to offer to the collective experience
> other than being an 
> attendant with money in hand and a pair of eyeballs
> to soak up brand 
> impressions.

OK well I don't know what to say to that. but keep in
mind, Transmat (the big bad business) wrestled control
of the DEMF from corporate forces pretty similar to
the ones you're describing here. and the Cloud Factory
did not. escaping corporate control is not the same
thing as standing up to it and kicking its ass. you
can run away from bullies if you want to, but I like
the folks who beat the bullies up and finally teach
them to stop taking other people's lunch money.

besides, what you're talking about sounds more like
some kind of art therapy support group. real artists
don't need supportive environments. Detroit and
Chicago, respective birthplaces of techno and house --
you think those are supportive environments? ever seen
"Kentucky Fried Movie"?

Tyrant: Take him to be tortured!
Spy: You can't scare me!
Tyrant: Take him to Detroit!
Spy: Nooooooooo!
(spy is dragged away screaming)

that's a great movie btw. go rent it, it's awesome.

also, here's some inexplicable randomness:
     "are you with the dj?"
     defiance is good for you.
     words are trivial.

> <snip>
> 
> >sounds. What they've done is incredible -- but if
> >they've moved on from the underground, what is it
> in
> >the underground that deserves preservation? What is
> CF
> >doing that is so worthwhile?
> >  
> >
> they are having a many-to-many dialogue with people.
> they draw a 
> distinction between attendants and participants.
> they promote and live a 
> genuine sense of family and relationship. they are
> doing something out 
> of love and passion. they are bringing together many
> different kinds of 
> artists and exploring a broader creative territory.
> i personally find 
> these traits worthy of my admiration.

I dunno, those are good things, but taken too far you
just end up with a community art fair.

I admire CF somewhat, but only somewhat. I can't deal
with this like life-or-death loyalty thing. sorry, but
I don't love CF **or** hate CF. I'm not for you or
against you. if anything, I think you need to calm
down.

personally I feel CF is this kinda cool thing which is
a little bit over-rated. I mean, cooler than Skills?
okay fine. but cooler than Transmat? cooler than the
people who invented techno?

okay, look, that's fine too. why not? CF can be cooler
than the guys who invented techno -- so long as we
agree that Moby is sending a Terminator backwards in
time to get me. I'll entertain your delusions of
grandeur if you'll entertain mine.

I'll be back.

> >1. things are going to change soon. it's
> inevitable,
> >because things are getting stagnant, and after
> things
> >getting stagnant, things change. so, if CF gets
> >dissed, don't be taking it personally.
> >  
> >
> interesting. i find CF to be one of the agents of
> said change, a group 
> actually doing something about said stagnance.

well, only time will tell.

> >it's getting bigger and bigger, and in Europe
> >it's been huge for a decade. something's going to
> >happen. the only question is what.
> >  
> >
> the only question is what are you going to make
> happen.
> if the scene has one core trait attached to its
> genesis, its "do it 
> yourself".

well, obviously if you've got two people saying
there's only one question, and they're both saying a
different question is the only question, then
obviously we're both wrong, because our failure to
even agree on what the question is obviously prompts
the question, what is the question?

but I see where you're coming from, and I think you
need to chill out and go watch cartoons. :-p


Giles


ps - this is my last post ever on this subject. I have
nothing more to say about this. and if you read all
this and head out the door to a cf event, cool. have
fun! they're often good. some of the best moments of
my life occurred at cf events. but some of the best
moments of my life happened at Medusa's in 1990
dancing to Mark Farina. cf is awesome, you just gotta
realize the world is full of awesome things.

pps - my current favorite cartoon is "the fairly
oddparents." go watch it!

IMPORTANT!!!  All Hight Octane Presale holders will get into our next event "Aquatech" for FREE!!!

>From the Creators of Power Puff Girls 1 and 2, Enter the Dragon 1-3 and countless other record breaking events.

 

Shaolin Presents.Our BIGGEST party ever!

June 13, 2003

HIGH OCTANE <~~mini-MASSIVE

============================

 

LOCK N LOAD

The Lock N' Load project consists of two Dutch producers / DJs: Frank van Rooijen and Niels Pijpers. One fine day the Club Caviar boys came to visit the Lock N' Load studio, heard the old version of a song and offered to do a remix of it. In collaboration with Lock N' Load they delivered this stunning result and Niels decided to release "Blow Ya Mind". After all on Blue White Records, within a period of three weeks, it became the No. 1 club record in the Netherlands, and Europe followed soon after that, the United Kingdom was ready to be conquered. Through no. 1 positions in both the UK Club and UK Dance chart it had an amazing entry at 6. Help us welcome Lock N' Load to Sacramento.

Chris C.

Now firmly established as one of the Biggest and most popular DJ / Producers on the UK Hard House/NRG scene, Chris has masterminded the emergence and rapid success of his 3 Labels, Mohawk, Aztec and Nile. Positioning the former today as one of the genres top 5 marques. With over 30 single releases and 2 Albums to his name on various labels including Tidy Trax, Tinrib, Eve, Honeypot, Phoenix Rising, GBT, Bulletproof, etc...Chris' reputation as one of Britain's finest exponent of Hard House, both behind the decks and in the studio, continues to grow.

Whistler

Victor Cape a.k.a. Whistler shines as a highly respected DJ on the Pacific Northwest dance scene. Known for his tight mixing skills and uplifting personality behind the decks, Whistler blends energy and emotion from Hard Melodic Trance, Epic Anthems and Hard House to take his listeners on a dance floor rollercoaster ride. If being a DJ wasn't enough, he also manages Lovetribe which has quickly become one of the most well respected event productions in Seattle. It's been over a year and a half since Whistler's last performance in Northern California. So we're excited to bring him out for his first Sacramento performance!

 

 

Dyloot

Arguably Nor-Cals BIGGEST Trance DJ/Producer watch him work his MAGIC over the crowd.

 

Tom Slik Vs. Tracer

Two of Nor-Cals Biggest Trance DJs wage war for the first time in Sacramento.

Denise Vs. Paul the Fanman

First ever Teacher vs. Student battle between the establish Denise and the BIG up n comer Paul. Lets see if he learned some tricks on his own.

Dragnfly Vs. Scepter

Shaolins two BIGGEST DJs go head to head to see who really is the SHAOLIN MASTER.

Bazooka Joe Vs. Reckless Ryan

Showmanship is the only way to describe the performance these two put on. Turntablist House at its best. Watch as these two leave you in a wicky-wick-AWWW!

Valerie Sparks vs. The Doctor

Nor Cals Best Hardcore Female DJ goes against this up n coming Junglist.

Sascha 23 Vs. Gauge

The founder of Xtort bumps heads with one of Shaolins Most talented Producer in a must see set with original Shaolin tracks.

 

 

IMPORTANT!!!

All High Octane Presale Holders will get into our next event (Aquatech) FREE!

Free: Glowsticks, Glow Bracelets, Glow mouth pieces, Stickers, Tasty Candy, CDs and Gift Bags.

ALL RESPONSIBLE AGES!!!

7pm - 5am

Tons of Lasers, Lighting and Visuals. Plus dancing AIR PEOPLE and vendor village.

www.shaolinproductions.net <http://www.shaolinproductions.net>

Info Line: 916 484-5610

$20 Presale, $25 @Door

Presale Locations:

In Tha Mix: 916 442-0499

Skillz: 510 704-9876

Retropolis: 775 786-8661

F8: 415 221-4142

Solid Grooves: 408 248-6399

 



Kris

Scepter

Subject: [sfraves] BSP::::::Good Morning

GOOD MORNING FROM PORTLAND, OR      

 

 

 

What a day for house music. What a day for deciding to book a deep house
dj who can and will work your crowd. Why you ask should I book this
person there is plenty of good talent around. This is why, because I am
a kind hearted soul who enjoys walks on the beach and throbbing sound
systems. I do not have a self inflating ego I prefer to just enjoy the
beats and dance my poor white man dance. Another good reason is this no
travel costs. I am going to be in your area in about 2 months and just
need bookings with a small fee to go get my fix of vinyl from your local
shops. If you need to hear the beats here they are please do take the
time to listen as I have taken the time wait patiently while the mix
uploaded. To listen click the following link or paste it into your
browser. Http://www..flavoredclubbing.com/strawberry/ohmix2.ram
<http://www.flavoredclubbing.com/strawberry/ohmix2.ram>  

 

 

If after all this you are reading and smiling but you are not a promoter
please take the time to pass on my mix or name to your favorite
promoter. 

 

Now for a little about me. I am originally from Tucson AZ where I was
initiated into the rave scene in 1992 and then continued to party and be
stupid until 1995 when I got my first turntables. Living in the middle
of nowhere forced me to teach myself all that I know. In 1997 I moved to
the Bay Area and from there continued to the great NW. I now call
Portland my home and will continue to do so until I am lured to another
city with a promise of a better life for me. So please take the time to
think would you like a dj from Portland on your flyer? Would you like a
dj who can work a crowd? Would you like this dj for only small fees and
no travel costs? Well would you? Now quick hit the reply button and let
me know your dates and I will send you a contract and then when I get
the notarized contract back I will mark my calendar and see you on that
date. Pretty simple so what's stopping you? Oh yeah it is me stopping
you because I am still typing.....

Goodbye and remember Peace, Love, and Roller Skates

 

Jason Philips

OH Records

Problematic Beats

style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;color:black;font-weight:bold'>OH =
Records</span></font></b></p>

<p class=3DMsoPlainText><b><font size=3D2 color=3Dblack face=3D"Courier =
New"><span
style=3D'font-size:10.0pt;color:black;font-weight:bold'>Problematic =
Beats</span></font></b></p>

<p class=3DMsoNormal><font size=3D3 face=3D"Times New Roman"><span =
style=3D'font-size:
12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></font></p>

</body>

</html>

Subject: [sfraves] THIS SUNDAY ... Expo for the Artist & Musician 2003

--============_-1160217685==_ma============
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"

... making the rounds here on this. Apologies if you get it more than once.

j-w


We had a bunch of last minute registrations, and are at capacity for 
the venue! Come make the scene at ...

THE FOURTH ANNUAL EXPO FOR THE ARTIST & MUSICIAN!
Sunday, May 4, 2003, 11:00 am-6:00 pm
@ Cellspace, 2050 Bryant St., San Francisco

Connections, community, art & opportunity ...

http://www.artsandmedia.net/expo/

**No one turned away -- $2 suggested donation **

** Spread the word ... please forward this invitation as appropriate **


WHAT?
The Expo is a very low-cost community connection fair bringing 
artists and musicians together with galleries, studios, arts-service 
groups and the general public. The Expo creates a temporary public 
space for education, networking, sharing resources and cultivating 
music and the arts from the grassroots up.

This year more than 80 arts and music organizations will attend, 
ready to meet and connect with the community. This means YOU.


Be an Expo Angel!
Support nonprofit arts organizations during a time of massive 
arts-funding cuts.
http://www.artsandmedia.net/expo/angels/


Partial list of Expo attendees this year:
21 Grand * ABADA Capoeira SF * ArtHouse * ArtNetwork * ArtSF * 
ArtSpan * ARTworkSF * AXIS Dance * Bay Area Buzz * Black Rock Arts 
Foundation * BorderZone Arts * Comedy on the Square * Dandelion 
Dancetheater * daniland productions * dreams by degrees * East Bay 
Youth Band * Event Magic * FiftyCrows * FilmArts Foundation * FILTH 
Newspaper * gigslist.org * Gilman Street Project * Grass Shack Events 
& Media * H.E.A.R * Hip Hop Slam * Independent Arts & Media * 
Institute for Unpopular Culture * Jazz In Flight * Kearny Street 
Workshop * KFJC 89.7 * Kitchen Sink Magazine * KZSU 90.1 * Little 
Kids Rock * ME\'D1.ATE Network * Mission Creek Festival * Motogirl 
Productions * New College of CA * New Langton Arts * Other Minds * 
Pacific Rim Sculpture Group * Patrick Simms Studios * Performing Arts 
Workshop * Planet Drum Foundation * Propellent / Gooferman * 
Renaissance Entrepreneurship Center * Renegade Productions * REsearch 
Publications * Rhythm & Motion Dance Center * Rocket Words * San 
Francisco Media Archive * Sanitary Fill AIR Program * SCRAP * SF Art 
Institute * SF Center for the Book * Songs Inspired by Literature * 
Som\'ma Music Ensemble * Soul Clap Records * SoundSafe * Southern 
Exposure * SPARK/ KQED TV * Taking the Leap * The Art Explosion * The 
Crucible * the DJ Project * The Field SF * The Foundation Center * 
The Nocturnes Night Photo Website * Visual Aid * Watchword Press * 
Women Environmental Artist Directory * YLEM: Artists Using Science & 
Technology ...


WORKSHOPS & PRESENTATIONS:

IN THE PARACHUTE LOFT (upstairs)
11:30-12:30: Turning Your Passion into Profit
Janet Lees, Renaissance Entrepreneurship Center
Learn the "Seven Success Factors of Business" and explore what it 
takes to make a business out of your art.

12:45-1:45: Grantwriting Crash Course
Frances Phillips, Haas Foundation
Join writer and grantmaker Frances Phillips for a brisk overview of 
writing a grant proposal and advice about where to begin looking for 
sources of support.

2:00-3:00: B.A.N.D. Workshop (Booking and Other Necessary Details)
Jocelyn Kane, Motogirl Productions; dani eurynome, daniland
This workshop is a primer for local bands/artists to work on 
promoting their work. Emphasis is on increasing your "draw," 
creativity and networking ideas.

3:15-4:15: Arts Real Estate 2003
Kathleen Diohep, ArtHouse
Go in-depth on the status of the artist studio real-estate market in 
the wake of the dot-com bust. Diohep will be joined by 
representatives from the new Workspaces Limited nonprofit studio 
project on Alabama Street.

4:30-5:30: How to Book a Tour
Moderator: Conan Neutron, bandmember, Replicator.
Panelists: Jocelyn Kane; booker, promoter; dani eurynome, booker, 
promoter; Jeff Ray, booker, Mission Creek Music Festival, bandmember, 
Zmrzlina; Marshall Lamm, Yoshi's Jazz House; Ms. E, DJ/promoter; 
Anthony Bedard, booker, Hemlock Tavern.

IN THE COMMUNITY ROOM (downstairs)

12:00-5:00: Portfolio "Make-Overs"
Throughout the day, artworld professionals will be on hand to provide 
brief portfolio reviews and critiques. Artists are invited to sign up 
for a 10-15 minute session.
Reviewers include: Patti Mangan, Imagine That Design Studio, 
principal/creative director; Anne Colvin, professional portfolio 
consultant; Jessica Hobbs, working artist/curator; Chris Benfield, 
working artist/curator, Crucible Steel Gallery; Les Young, San 
Francisco architect/artist.


** Expo 2003 is sponsored in part by the CRAIGSLIST FOUNDATION 
(http://craiglistfoundation.org/), UTRECHT ART SUPPLIES 
(http://www.utrecht.com/), REMIX magazine (http://remixmag.com/), the 
FOUNDATION CENTER  (http://www.fdncenter.org/), the SAN FRANCISCO BAY 
GUARDIAN (http://www.sfbg.com/) and SFGATE.com.

Subject: [sfraves] nrr/bsp - berkeley housing: large room & private bath/entrance in 2-br apt

hey, my roommate is graduating and moving out at the end of the month so his 
room will be available starting june 1st. rent is $750 each, it's a 2 bedroom 
apartment on the southside of campus (ellsworth/blake), a quick 5 min walk to 
the south gate. there's no living room or common area other than the kitchen 
(which is big btw), but the available room is pretty large (about 12 by 17 
feet), you can fit a queensize bed, desk, dresser, coffee table and a futon or 
couch. you get your own separate entrance, the room's got a private bathroom 
and a walk-in closet. an overall studio-like feel to the place. the people in 
the building are very cool too (mostly students) and the neighborhood has a 
nice atmosphere. utils are shared, there are coin washer/dryer in the 
basement, rent includes parking space in the garage, you can go on 
month-to-month or year lease, and we also get cable modem/tv.
so about me: i'm alex, male, 23, first-year grad student at cal, born and 
raised in nyc and just moved to berkeley last august. i love techno (hard 
trance, goa, nrg), i'm a bedroom/up and coming dj (about 3 yrs), go clubbing, 
out to raves and hit up the bars occasionally. ya, i like to party but i also 
keep my act together cause i gotta get through eng. grad school. otherwise i 
like modern art, traveling, meeting people and just hanging out. i'm pretty 
laidback, easygoing but also responsible and respectful of personal space. i 
smoke cigarettes but only in my room and vent so the smell doesn't get into 
the kicthen or the other room.
i'm looking for a chill roommate that's fun to hang out with but also has a 
rather independent lifestyle. i'd like somebody responsible and trustworthy 
who can pay the bills on time. it would be cool if he/she (no preference on 
gender) had similar interests (especially the music, lol, we could hit up 
parties), but i'm open to anybody that's fun, friendly and open-minded.
if you think we might have a good match, send me a reply telling me a bit 
about yourself. leave me a number or reply-to so we can arrange a time for you 
to check out the place. cheers.

Subject: [sfraves] art therapy

ok, i'll the cf stuff alone, since you demanded it.

>I'm assuming you mean the Dead shows were a corporate
>environment? I gotta wonder if you've been to any. I
>mean it's true that you could buy Pepsi there but
>other than that I'm not really sure where you're
>coming from.
>
not that they were a corporate environment - they were _in_ a corporate 
environment.
the point i was making was about intent and a creating space... that was 
the burning man contrast.
relating to underground or not...



>OK well I don't know what to say to that. but keep in
>mind, Transmat (the big bad business) wrestled control
>of the DEMF from corporate forces pretty similar to
>  
>
>the ones you're describing here. 
>

i never said there was anything wrong with transmat.
as you put forth derrick as a true underground soldier,
i was merely pointing out mr. may's involvement in, for example, events 
put on by cigarette companies.

the move events were good examples of a US event being centrally focused 
around a corporate brand.
when we're talking about what's on the other side of underground, that's 
something on the other side.

don't get me wrong either.
i missed hearing richie and derrick at the desert move,
and i certainly would have liked to have seen the majestic stacks of 
cabinets in the air...

but, as you describe things getting bigger and bigger - i bring that up 
as a contrast to why the underground might yet have merit.
where's the diy heart and soul in it, if all you have to go to, to hear 
the music that you love, is corporate sponsored parties?

yes that's hypothetical.

on the other side of underground, there are specialized rave/club 
marketing firms,
looking at us to see if we have the numbers they need to move more 
consumer products.
i'm not describing that as 'evil' - simply that is what i see on the 
other side of underground.
i'm not making judgements. i'm interested in contrast. these are just 
observations man.




>besides, what you're talking about sounds more like
>some kind of art therapy support group. real artists
>don't need supportive environments. 
>
c'mon. why did they form a label then? why did they team up with each other?
so they wouldn't be lone superheroes.
they created their own supportive environment.

it could be said that creating transmat or generator or <insert crew or 
label> _was_ an art therapy support group.
artists reaching out to each other to find other like minds.

"from our minds to yours"




>Detroit and
>Chicago, respective birthplaces of techno and house --
>you think those are supportive environments? 
>

i'm from chicago also. no, chicago in and of itself is not a supporting 
environment.
people invariably create supporting environments within their cities, 
however cold and hard those cities may be.



>that's a great movie btw. go rent it, it's awesome.
>  
>
yes, its a riot. =)




>I dunno, those are good things, but taken too far you
>just end up with a community art fair.
>  
>
see, to me an electronic-infused community art fair with awesome music 
sounds like fun.
after 12 years of going to events that have the same basic form and 
structure,
a little variation and mixing it up a bit is a good thing.



>I'm not for you or
>against you. if anything, I think you need to calm
>down.
>  
>

i'll certainly admit to being passionate.
i understand if you can't handle my 'guatemalan-ness... my natural heat...'

(that's birdcage)

and anyway, aren't you a superhero techno dj?
superhero techno dj's don't want everyone sedate and calm.
a little underground resistance perhaps?  =)



>but some of the best
>moments of my life happened at Medusa's in 1990
>dancing to Mark Farina.
>
the first place i ever saw a music video, on that big white wall in the 
upstairs room.

-joshua

Not only that, but then we also seem to have a large group of people 
who DO use drugs, even just recreationally and in moderation, that 
feel guilty or bad about it which only makes it worse. Drugs aren't 
bad, though they are illegal. "Illegal" does not automatically equal 
"bad". If you think it does then you probably should really enjoy 
living in the kind of theocracy that America lately seems to be 
slowly becoming.

BS


At 04:26 -0400 050203, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
>I suspect that the government's resentment for drugs is somewhat similar to
>the Amish people's resentment for technology...
>
>You know I think someone like John Ashcroft fears taking drugs like an Amish
>person would fear riding a roller coaster... Sure everyone who's been on one
>knows it's safe (with the proper safty straps and harnesses) but just by
>watching what a roller coaster does and how the people act when they are
>riding one... i think is enough to make any Amish person go running home to
>their farmland. 
>
>And have you ever noticed how people always say "they don't like roller
>coasters..." instead of "they are scared to ride a roller coaster..."
>
>things that make you go hmm...
>
>Now this is not to say that people who don't take drugs should be pressured
>into doing so by calling them "sissys" but i think we should just get it out
>in the open that when it comes down to it, the truth is, people actually FEAR
>drugs, mostly for either superstitious or religious reasons. Also the fear
>comes from exaggerated propaganda created by people who have never touched
>drugs. I think a lot of people who have never done drugs are afraid that they
>will "freak out" if they do them, or that some wierd aspect about their
>personality will come out in the open, and they don't want people to see them
>like that. This is especially true for members of our government....

From: Kevin James <djkevinjames@yahoo.com>
To: boomboom@boomerangfidget.com,
  The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20030502213448.1330.qmail@web80109.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] I need (1) CD player w/ pitch control  

 Check ebay. That's the best place to find them used.
You can get a Pioneer cdj 100s for about $150. The
pitch control on that model sucks though to be honest.
It moves in incriments of .5% as compared to the cdj
800 or 1000 that move in incriments of .05% . What
this means is basically you have to babysit them. 

  You can probably find a Cdj 800 for about $500.
Thats what I recomend (and what I have). They are
basically a very stripped down 1000. They are 
expensive , but you will be much better off in the
long run. They are a dream to mix on, I actually would
prefer to play on 2 of them than 1200's.......and I
know plenty of other people who feel the same way.

 Kevin James

sadnessthat followed it... it was weird!!  But yeah... I called my Homie in 
LA like later that night & he was like totally buggin' about something & 
well we talked it out.... But yeah... it was kinda trippy how that happened, 
but that goes w/ my thing I told y'all B4 about how things happen w/ me 
Psychicly & people I'm close w/...

But what's weird is that while this was happening... I tuned in2 CNN & they 
had this like story about monkey's & this total live feed thingie @ the 
location they were doing the story on!!  I dunno how many of U I told my 
dram I had about when I owned a pet monkey, but this was way 2 weird!  OK... 
so yeah... I was thinkiin' about the monkey on TV I was lookin @ & likehow 
it should jump jump jump & it then did...

"Odd," I thought!

Then the trainer picked up the monkey & thought about it playing w/ her hair 
& it did!!  More wierd, ya know!!  I woulda thought this all coincidental, 
but when I thought that the monkey should play w/ her boobs & it did... then 
I was like HEllo 2day...

I dunno.... wierd stuff!!  But does trhat mean my Psychic powers r growing?

OK... There's alota dancing goin' on this weekend & hopefully I'll C U out 
there & we can Groove 2gether =)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] IT'S OFFICIAL: RAVING IS ILLEGIAL, a rebirth

In my opinion..I think we all need to take a look at why we are involved in
the scene, and make sure we are doing this for the right reasons. I also
feel that us promoters have an obligation to keep this thing going and we
need to fight the powers at all levels. Part of fighting this will be living
with the law and making sure we don't get put in jail for it. I personally
feel that our crew should take a much larger stance against drug use at out
events. I know everyone wont be happy with that but my concern is keeping
the parties going so we can go out and hear good music every weekend.

Nick
