SATURDAY MAY 17, 2003 =80 150 Folsom, San Francisco, CA
2 Year Anniversary Celebration

http://www.electronica-optica.com/events/


o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o

/\ Intro

Electronica-Optica is celebrating their 2nd anniversary by presenting their
first annual VJ & Visual Artist Conference in San Francisco on May 17th,
2003 from 2pm - 4am. This conference will be one of the first in the US to
highlight and showcase this growing visual culture.

VJs are similar to modern DJs in that they play out at concerts, nightclubs=
,
and festival, except VJs play video content using traditional equipment suc=
h
as VCRs, DVD players, laptops, and video mixers. Some may even mix digital
video clips using VJ software such as Arkaos, MotionDive, and/or MaxMSP.
(Over 2 dozen VJ software packages exist for PC and Macintosh computers.)

Visual Artists are creative individuals and studios that produce stunning
imagery and visuals using a variety of media including shot video, film, CG
animation, motion graphics, pattern generators, or any combination thereof.
Content varies in length and may be non-linear, narrative, semi-narrative,
abstract, or simply the equivalent of a painting in motion.

Visuals are different than music video in the sense that they aren=B9t
commissioned works to promote a particular music artist. Visuals are create=
d
to stand for themselves, work with a variety of musical formats, and even b=
e
mixed by VJs with other visual content to create an entirely new impression
for the audience.



\/ Workshops

The daytime conference will begin with a discussion panel featuring Radley
Marx (Electronica-Optica), Jon Schwark (LightRhythm), and Grant Davis &
Michael O'Rourke (Dimension 7). Each will be addressing different areas of
this emerging culture and sharing experiences and expectations for the
coming year. Topics will range from aesthetic and cultural expression to
practical market projects and strategies.

The afternoon workshops will be filled with a fun assortment of software an=
d
hardware demonstrations for VJs, DJs, visual artists, and newcomers to this
growing culture.

For DJs and new music producers, there will be a essential workshop for
sequencing video clips along with your music, using Arkaos VJ together with
Reason (the easy-to-use music production software that is quickly becoming
more popular than DJs). Equipment demos include VJ turntable-tools for
mixing and scratching video just like records.

For veterans, the Cycling =8C74 workshop will demonstrate the extreme high-en=
d
of what can be created and manipulated by digital video artists. Dimension =
7
will also be showing showing a variety of highly-developed equipment by
Edirol and M-Audio used in professional-level production.

Anyone is free to attend and take part.  This will be an excellent
opportunity for hands-on exploration and discovery.


/\ Screenings

Running concurrent with the workshops will be a series of visual screenings=
.
Just like a film festival, the screenings offer exclusive presentations of
short works and full-length visual projects from the visuals community.

The day will kick off with episodes of Electronica-Optica=B9s public access
series: VJTV. The full-length features include Yeast Films=B9 cultural music
sequence =B3Prophesy=B2 and a sneak-peak at the locally produced CG project, =B3I
Am=B2 by Dimension 7. The high point of the afternoon will be Bitz & Bytz, an
amazing assortment of 5-10 minute submissions by visual artists from around
the world including Addictive TV, D-Fuse, eMovie Collective, SquareSquare
and many more.




\/ Audiovisual Performances

The night celebration will feature performances by several outstanding
artists from the Bay Area and the mid-west. Headlining the night will be
VisualAudio, VJ Oz, and ESP - audiovisual performing artists that base thei=
r
show on the video as much as the music (or more). Other performances will
feature VJs and DJs playing together for exciting in-the-moment mixes that
spawn a powerful experience for the eyes and ears.




/\ Admission & Location Information

This conference is hosted at the Dimension 7 Studio, located at 150 Folsom
Street, in downtown San Francisco.

The workshops and screenings are FREE and run from 2pm to 8pm.

The night celebration goes from 8pm to 4am in the same space.
A small donation is requested for attending the night performances.




\/ Detailed Information

http://www.electronica-optica.com/events/




o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o


/\ List of Activities and Events


* Workshops (2pm-8pm):

Andy W & Mike Migurski - Audio/video interaction and integration - using
high-end technical products by Cycling '74 (including Jitter & Max MSP)

Steve Taormina (Robotspeak) - AV production using Reason 2 and Arkaos VJ -
the next essential step for DJs and producers

Grant Davis (Dimension 7) - VJ equipment demos

Grant Davis and Andy W - EJ System & Ms Pinky - turntable tools for VJs



* Screenings (2pm-8pm):

Bitz & Bytz Screenings An assortment of 5-10 minutes work from visual
artists and producers from around the world. Featuring visuals by Addictive
TV, D-Fuse, Benton C, eMovie Collective, Mickey T, Epsilon Labs,
SquareSquare, Mindcandy, and more!

Dimension 7 - I Am A pre-screening of this locally produced epic release,
over 3 years in the making.

Yeast Films / Raya =AD Develop A visual commentary mixing shot footage and
dialog from India and other countries, examining the economic and social
impact of uni-culturalism. Music by Nitin Sawhney.

VJTV - Best of VJTV - Season One Featuring interviews and visuals by Arcane=
,
Addictive TV, VJ Culture, Robotkid, VJ Luna, Suryummy, Absurde Collective,
Jon DeKron, gMunk, Honeygun Labs, WDDG, and VJ Pixielight.

VJTV - Best of VJTV - Season Two Featuring Visualaudio, 47, Johnny Dekam,
Imaginary Forces, Madame Chao, Blasthaus, Amoeba, Yeast, Tina Z, Speed
Tribe, C-TRL, Just-D Phantasmagoria Video, Swipe, VJ V2, and Overlay06/Alph=
a
Channel.

>=20
>=20
* Performances (8pm-2am):

Audiovisual Artists

VisualAudio =AD Chicago

VJ Oz  (Electronica-Optica)

ESP (Extra-Sensory Projection) featuring VJ Culture, Alaric, & Suryummy
(Dimension 7, Insect Funeral, Electronica-Optica)

Mike Migurski & Andy W (Viberations)


VJ / DJ Mix Sessions

VideoJon & Ben Sheppee (Light Rhythms) w/ DJ Surge (Eyephunk)

Hardsync & Kai (Electroradio) w/ DJ Amy (Infinite Kaos)

and more to be announced...


o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o



/\ About

Dimension 7 (D7) was formed in 1993 as one of the original visual artist
collectives and grew to become a full service production company. D7's live
production team combines multiple video projections, special effects, live
camera feeds, and laser animation to create what D7 calls "Immersive
Environments."

Electronica-Optica was formed by Radley Marx and Emmett Feldman as a means
to be creative visual artists and to help build a strong market
infrastructure for the emerging VJ industry.

Electronica-Optica is partnered with Media Box to produce VJTV, a monthly
one-hour television series that plays across North America and features
guest artists and visual content.

Radley Marx has worked in the west coast rave scene as a DJ and designer
under the alias Elemental and currently heads Electronica-Optica,
co-produces VJTV, and is developing his own live show as VJ Oz.

Emmett Feldman is currently working on original audio and visual material a=
s
Suryummy, as well as working with a variety of audiovisual groups including
ESP and LightRhythms.

Subject: [sfraves] Karma Redux: We brought this on ourselves, but...

--part1_129.2919be4a.2be461d5_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

  There is a bright side to all of this. I know I will be misunderstood for 
this statement, and I will be hitting a wasp nest with my thoughts, but as I 
have learned, and still learning from my mistakes and misdeeds that to 
misplace the blame on others and to play the martyr or victim is easy and a 
natural response for most of us, but it only drags us down further in the 
black hole of energy draining energies of fear and reactionary living, and it 
only makes our situation or our karma worse. The hard part is to own up to 
our karma: "it's my karma, I own it" and to stop focusing on others and trust 
that the wisdom of the universe will honor our honesty and make us wise and 
more mature in the end, not to mention better karma situations.
  Here's what's up. The rave scene has become so corrupted and so way off 
base that because we as ravers were unwilling to take charge of our scene and 
clean it up, the government had to step in and do our job for us, like you 
drive DUI, you loose your license, not because the CHP hate drivers, but 
because of your actions you are a threat to the safety of other drivers. I 
don't think the intent of all responsible for this bill was entirely 
motivated on a hatred of raving per-se, but drugs were getting out of hand. 
Those exposes of us on TV news zines were somewhat exaggerated, but true 
enough to scare the hell out of moms and dads of America; we, too busy acting 
as victims and martyrs to see and listen to our karma warning us of the day 
of reckoning coming if we didn't change our ways.
  Raving is no longer an urban underground phenomenon made up of a few urban 
perverts, techno hippies and anti-pop culturists that most didn't find 
attractive and thus didn't give a fuck about us. But thanks to greed and our 
"enlightenment" to capitalism, too many kids, many of them hella young kids, 
kids from conservative homes, white suburban kids and the poster minority 
group, Asian kids, were now getting fucked up on drugs and laying on the 
floor and engaging in acts disturbing to Mid-America. Raving was getting too 
close to places like Iowa, Tennessee, Danville and Stanford, so something had 
to be done to stop it. 
  We all know what was going down with our scene. I remember back in the 
early 90's seeing newbies coming to raves and within a month throwing 
parties. Most of these people didn't have alturistic intentions, but were 
drug dealers and capital venturists finding a market to sell drugs and to 
make a profit. Even though the rave scene back in the day had a good share of 
open minded, adventurous, friendly, drug responsible people who cared about 
others and the old skool parties were rich with spiritual themes and the vibe 
was generally PLURy, I, and many others knew back then this wasn't going to 
bring a positive outcome for the scene. If we knew back then what the scene 
would be like today, we would have been so overwhelmed with discouragement.
  What we have today is a scene that has been advertised and flyred to 
virtually every mall and high/middle school in America and PLUR has been 
replaced with narcissism and nihilism. Here's hitting the wasp nest really 
hard, but we all know it's all true, sort of a public taboo subject, many 
promoters, DJ'ds and other "VIP"s in the scene are into drug dealing and many 
parties have acted as fronts for drug dealing. The DEA has known that for 
years, and now is on it because, like I said mid-America is getting sucked in 
the drama. Many others are into the scene for ego stoking, rock stardom and a 
nice, player life style. It seems those who are in it for the love of the 
scene and the music, altruistic intentions you might say, have become fewer 
and fewer. Corruption rots everything it touches, and eventually the rot 
turns on those who corrupt; aka. 
  So you wonder back a few years ago when the alarm bells were sounding and 
not many people seemed to care, why many promoters and DJ's didn't step up to 
the plate to come together as one force and organize protest parties and 
benefits to help fund some lobbying effort to our elected officials or to 
help pay for the legal defense of raving, you know why.
  But, like I said there is a bright side. Most of these people, including 
the people they attracted to raving, once raving no longer becomes profitable 
or too dangerous to be involved with will bail on us. Watch a lot of well 
known people bounce out of here. I say, let them go! What a wonderful time to 
take advantage of this cleansing to go back, not to the old skool, but to 
those things that made old skool raving so special. Old skool is dead, but 
those values that made raving a magical, life changing experience is 
timeless. It may be illegal to rave, but it's not illegal for those of us who 
really love techno to come together, learn form our mistakes, start over 
again from scratch and rediscover PLUR, spirituality, adventure and self 
creativity, all those things that were lost in mainstream/narissistic raves, 
and see what the energy from our unity will manifest. That is what I'm 
excited about!
  Peace to all, Bodhi ^ _ ^

--part1_129.2919be4a.2be461d5_boundary--

To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Fri, 2 May 2003 21:27:01 -0700

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook IMO, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2910.0)
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2615.200
Importance: Normal
In-Reply-To: <1ce.8a9b97f.2be24f87@aol.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Act consciously, do not be unconscious

In Regards to the Amber Deal....

With this all, I think the question is...what is the reason this is being
protested.

Is it for the right to have drugs in a public venue? Or, is the right to
gather and dance?

If it is the right to dance and gather well than that opportunity is still
there if the drugs are left behind. If that is the choice than this law will
not affect those organization publicly promoting drug awareness in their
venues and coordinating with the government to even help spread information
on missing people through our vast network of patrons across the country.

One can't really argue that it is bad to want to find missing children but
of course having missing children tied directly into the "rave" scene is
certainly not a proven fact but a generalization and a little shady for the
Govt just to throw it in.  I can personally say through my experience years
ago, back in the underground after hour's scene back in LA, I knew several
people who just never went home.  Or the kids that would just not go home or
to school for weeks at a time going to the thrift store in the day to get
some clothes for the next night out.  Some of the people did literally
disappear after a while ...

I am certainly not preaching anti- drugs to those who chose.  But I do think
one should protect the rights of everyone by not bringing a substance in
that due to the current laws would "spoil it for everyone".. One thing I can
say personally is that I would not mind being able to walk through the dance
floor without having to step over the E-puddles. Once again, not against the
E but support the practice of moderation.

Act consciously, do not be unconscious

TNG




---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org


From sfraves-return-101779-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat May 03 10:56:30 2003

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 97663 invoked from network); 3 May 2003 10:56:30 -0000
From: JBlaze112@aol.com
Message-ID: <ae.3f013e26.2be4fa50@aol.com>
Date: Sat, 3 May 2003 06:56:16 EDT
To: thegirl@thenetworkgirl.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: AOL 5.0 for Windows sub 103
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Act consciously, do not be unconscious

I think the big question here is how many people do we all know who will 
continue to support a drugless rave scene? how many people will stay all 
night sober? how many peopel will dance their ass off sober? will sentimental 
trance songs still make us shed a tear? is it still acceptable to talk and be 
friendly to strangers? can we still tolerate mars & mystre & skills style 
music, sober all night? how about happy hardcore, energy, gapper etc.
    I myself think positive and i believe i would still attend raves if every 
single person was sober all night long, and i'd still dance my ass off. but i 
know for a fact we'd lose a lot of less courageous souls in the process. it 
would be really strenuous if you think about it, to try and bring back that 
"vibe" without even the pressense of drugs at all. it's somewhere close to 
impossible, but if tht's what it's gonna take then i'd say i'll give it my 
best shot. i'll represent, i'm sure others will too. 
    but just the fact that we can possibly continue raving without drugs 
doesn't make it ok that they put two irrelevant bills together and voted on 
them like they were one bill. knowing that the other bill would not pass by 
itself. (fucking basdards!) to just "look at the brite side" and just have 
raves without drugs from now on is just going to encourage them to keep 
pushing us around and treating us unfairly. i don't think the rave scene is 
supposed to be so "co-operative" with oppresion, i don't think that's being 
true to our spirit. 

    In fact, i think the goddess... is getting royally pissed off.... (don't 
ask me what that means) 

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Message-ID: <20030503110315.45292.qmail@web10708.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Sat, 3 May 2003 04:03:15 -0700 (PDT)
From: knowmad AE <knowmadae@yahoo.com>
To: TheNetworkGirl <thegirl@thenetworkgirl.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <NFBBKBPLPJDLCNANMCFIOECDDGAA.thegirl@thenetworkgirl.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Act consciously, do not be unconscious

Sec. 608
`(2) manage or control any place, whether permanently
or temporarily, either as an owner, lessee, agent,
employee, occupant, or mortgagee, and knowingly and
intentionally rent, lease, profit from, or make
available for use, with or without compensation, the
place for the purpose of unlawfully manufacturing,
storing, distributing, or using a controlled
substance.'

it's not "the right to have drugs in a public venue"
but the fact that no matter how tight the security (i
was all but strip searched to get into an event in the
bay before leaving on principle alone) there is a .01%
(my own random figure) chance that someone will be
able to get drugs into an event and ANYONE can take
them before hand.  because of the .01% and the fact
that 100% of the people who take the drugs before hand
will get in, that event (not rave but event, concert,
play, prom, etc.) can be shut down and the promoters,
venue owners, sound crew, etc. can all be fined.

granted, they got rid of the "know's or reasonably
ought to know" bit, but still all that needs to be
proved under the current law is that someone was on
drugs because, after all, everyone "knows" (thanks to
20/20 and frontline) that raves (events, concerts,
proms, etc.) contain drug use...

i don't "support a drugless rave scene" just as i
don't support a "drug rave scene", to each there
own...

i've danced my ass of sober many, many, many times...

i don't listen to trance, ew (joke, well not really
but... i do shed a tear to certain tunes)

strangers daily, don't you?

"still tolerate mars & mystery & skills style music,
sober all night long" - hell, i can't tolerate them on
drugs!  (hehehe, joke... or maybe not)

the fact of the matter is, there doesn't need to
actually be drugs presant (they can find their way
around that technicality)... it's the mere fact that
raves cater to drugs (after all 20/20 and frontline
said so) that makes the events (along with proms,
concerts, etc. as far as i'm concerned) illegal

Subject: [sfraves] segregated prom etc

As a Southerner from Alabama (I am a real, live, honest-to-God/dess 
HILLBILLY), I have noticed that racism began to re-emerge more fully 
into the common social milieu post-Reagan's first election. Before 
that, tolerance for racist crap was seen as rude and impolite, 
something that cultured people just did not do. As really minor as that 
seems to me, that even teensy change in social behavior was a marked 
improvement over the legendary, blatant racism of my home culture.

It saddened me to hear of the resegregated proms in Georgia. What are 
these people thinking????


James Lovette-Black

"http://www.live365.com/cgi-bin/directory.cgi?autostart=jimlbnsf".

What difference does it make to the dead, the orphans and the homeless, 
whether the mad destruction is wrought under the name of 
totalitarianism or the holy name of liberty or democracy? - Mahatma 
Gandhi (1869 - 1948), "Non-Violence in Peace and War"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] help me please some tech smart

if what you have is a .rar and not a .raw file.

a .rar is an compressed file format like a .zip, but it has to be extracted
with the application WINRAR, just go to

 www.rarsoft.com/download.htm

and they have all the info you need. basically load winrar, go to the dir
where you have the .rar file, right-click the .rar and extract to, play with
it and you will find it easy to use.

AUDiOTACTiX

Subject: Re: [sfraves] turntables

--0-1974307212-1052009991=:71521
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

i didn't even consider mismatched beatmatching. the human ear is pretty good at compensating for equipment faults and difficiencies. working on scrap builds artistic confidence. another way to look at it is that it shows you actually have ability. i like two mismatched tables and a mismatched cd mixer....ornament the alter as you like. tra-la-la. i also like used cars...prefer them to what's being churned out lately.  :)ES <exitstrategy2@yahoo.com> wrote:that's pretty good advice. i first started off in a studio to make sure i actually liked djing because it's not as easy as it looks. as for tables, remember that they are an investment. if you get the right tables, ie technics, they'll last forever, and maintain resale value. if you get two mismatched tables, they may not be in sync in terms of starting and stopping power, which hurts beatmatching. geri dahl's suggestion of studio time is probably best for cash strapped friends.

Geri Dahl wrote:please don't kill me, however, there's nothing like using someone else's turntables while they are asleep....something you might consider is getting your friend some quiet studio time alone if you can't get the turntables you desire....nothing like a nice quiet studio full of techie toys and a comfie chair...of course, the kitties are not in there unless pre-approved. ::)...hey look, i gots FOUR eyes ::)

Charlie wrote:yo, advice...friend of mine wants turntables fer his
b-day...and like most of us i'm half poor...but i
could scrounge together enough if i put my mind to
it...anyway what are the good ones and um...what are
the good semi-affordable ones and um...stuff...

charlie

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 15815 invoked from network); 4 May 2003 11:56:44 -0000
From: JBlaze112@aol.com
Message-ID: <1dc.8f0bb75.2be659f6@aol.com>
Date: Sun, 4 May 2003 07:56:38 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: AOL 5.0 for Windows sub 103
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] The Amber Ages...

    in our current situation and drug/non-drug paradox in the rave scene, i 
think it might be appropriate to create a "darker" more "jaded" scene to 
mystify ourselves creatively and artistically. i think there is a distinction 
that can be made out of a "ideal" rave for a person on ecstacy or other drugs 
and a "ideal" rave for a person who is sober. me personally, if i'm gonna be 
sober, i like dark techno and deep tribal house. maybe throw in some jungle. 
I think the dark sound symbolizes some sort of cause in the world and reason 
to be pissed off.
     on the other hand i love happy and melodic techno as well, epic trance, 
bubble gum, caroony, happyhard core bring it on.... but i like to save that 
music for times that are worth celebrating, and when i celebrate, i'm more 
likely to use substances. and considering this new laws we have now jepordize 
the lifes of people who produce parties... far be it from me to bring drugs 
into someone's partly that clearly says "no drugs" on the flier and what not. 
    So i'm just asking any DJ's out there who read this... please spin us 
some dark tunes because i do love the rave scene, but i am in no mood to 
celebrate untill this amber bullshit gets set straight. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------

To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-id: <BADA9300.9C2E%sfraves@deepfog.com>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
User-Agent: Microsoft-Entourage/10.0.0.1309
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] The Amber Ages...

On 5/4/03 7:56 AM, "JBlaze112@aol.com" <JBlaze112@aol.com> wrote:
>   So i'm just asking any DJ's out there who read this... please spin us
> some dark tunes because i do love the rave scene, but i am in no mood to
> celebrate untill this amber bullshit gets set straight.
> 

now, i wouldn't be *that* depressed.  we haven't actually seen what the
real-life effects are of this law yet.  a few years ago they passed a
no-smoking law in all the bars in san francisco, yet when you walk into many
bars, not only can you smoke in them, but there are ashtrays.

also, remember that new orleans case.  they've already tried sending people
to jail for things like what this amber alert tackon supposedly allows them
to tack on.   just because something has become law doesn't mean it can't be
either modified or even struck down in court.  perhaps that case of the past
will end up helping in some way.

...also, just try to put yourselves in the opposition's shoes for a minute.
i just briefly glanced over the 2002 version of what passed, and while some
of it is obviously exaggerated, some of the things might be a little bit
true, both due to irresponsible promoters and irresponsible partiers.
perhaps there will be a way for the responsible ones to survive relatively
untouched through the amber ages.

...then again, maybe it will be like that movie "The Running Man" where
they've got Osby, AndyW, and Mike Migurski running for their lives on
national TV for crimes they didn't commit!  get the popcorn!  well,
hopefully it won't be that bad.

so, anyway, i think we've got to wait and see what happens next.

fog out


-- 
"Dancing is healing to the soul, and that's the best thing most of us can be
doing right now. Dance until it falls off. I can't guarantee it will prevent
war, but then again, I can't guarantee it won't, either. Can you?" - Deepfog

I'll have to take Nick's stance on this one.  Unfortunately I can't decide
yet whether it'll be a futile act..trying to make parties drugless and
enforcing it so.  I mean, all it takes is someone to have a pipe or someone
who wants to make money by selling a pill or two to just fudge it up.  How
do you fight the powers that also say "I can check out what books you
checked out at the library cause we think it might be essential to national
security"-- "The Patriot Act").  The law makes it self so it's pretty damn
impossible to coorperate with it unless you have drug sniffing dogs and cops
doing the searches.  Kind of pointless if you ask me.  The cup to the
underground has been given to be filled up with the juice of responsibility.
Who's the first to drink from the grail?

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] IT'S OFFICIAL: RAVING IS ILLEGIAL IN AMERICA!!!

This has little to do with drugs, and a lot to do with the elimination
of a way of feeling, a way of thinking, and a way of life that grows out
of it.

Last year, we flooded the Senate with phone calls, faxes, and petitions
opposing this bill.  The appearance of such a political force out of
nowhere alarmed the powers-that-be.  It seems that it also strengthened
their determination to crush us,  so much so though that they employed a
blatant end-run around what is left of the democratic process to do it. 
No debate.  No vote on the measure by itself in either chamber.  Just
hook it onto the popular Amber bill that nobody dares to oppose.  In the
conference committee.  Even by Washington standards this is over the
top, but it got nary a peep in the media.


This law will drive our scene underground.  WAY underground.  They hope
to drive us so far underground that we lose any ability to make a
difference in the world.

Then kids in Iowa, Tenessee and Danville will never see or hear of such
a thing as a rave.  They will never dance except as part of the
socially-approved courtship ritual.  Many will never engage in *any*
significant physical activity that is not competitive.  Most will never
hear about PLUR.  They will hear a lot of other things on TV and believe
them.

It has become fashionable to put down PLUR, because Peace, Love,
Understanding, Unity and Respect seems so hopelessly far from the actual
human condition.  But consider the alternative:

War, Hatred, Misunderstanding, Divisiveness and Disrespect have become
government policy and are well on their way to becoming the new American
way of life.   We may be the only ones who can stop it.


JBlase112@aol.com wrote:
> if the laws that are passed keep us safe, but ruin our lives 
> emotionally and spiritually, than they will very likely be passed 
> anyway, and no one will even notice or have the power 
> to fight it. 

The ruination of our spiritual lives is not a side-effect.  It is the
real motivation for passing such laws.  If they can destroy us
spiritually, then they can enslave us absolutely.



DON'T LET THEM STOP THE MUSIC
-- 
Andy Nourse <nourse@tiedye.tiedye.com>

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 37475 invoked from network); 5 May 2003 00:02:57 -0000
Message-Id: <5.1.0.14.2.20030504163954.032670f0@mail.speakeasy.net>
X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.net
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 5.1
Date: Sun, 04 May 2003 17:07:00 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
In-Reply-To: <1052088191.1882.163.camel@shpongle.tiedye.com>
References: <f6.2ba8199c.2be34093@aol.com>
 <f6.2ba8199c.2be34093@aol.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_16202741==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] IT'S OFFICIAL: RAVING IS ILLEGAL IN AMERICA!!!

--=====================_16202741==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 03:43 PM 5/4/2003 -0700, Andy Nourse wrote:
>This has little to do with drugs, and a lot to do with the elimination
>of a way of feeling, a way of thinking, and a way of life that grows out
>of it.
>

I have to agree with Andy here...this is not really about drugs.

Illicit drugs have and will continue to be used throughout American society 
whether clubs and raves are closed or not.

It is important to pound into legislators and the public's collective 
consciousness that EDM events are not the cause of the increasing use of 
MDMA, nor are EDM participants the primary users of the drug.  While it is 
generally true that experimentation with new ideas, fashions and drugs 
arise in subcultures these "innovations" are rapidly adopted by the 
mainstream society.

One would really like to have more data here, but I can't believe 
intuitively that the multi-billion dollar MDMA industry is solely supported 
by dancers.  Those who attend music and dance events are a very small 
percentage of the population.  Even if every one of us downed five pills a 
day, seven days a week, this would account for a fraction of overall 
ecstasy sales.  If all of us were to be locked up tomorrow, MDMA sales 
would not, I believe, be significantly diminished.

Clubs and other EDM events, however, are easy targets for the 
government.  This is all somewhat analogous to my grandmother's experience 
during prohibition.  She loved to dance, and the best music and dancing was 
to be found at speakeasys, where illegal drugs (booze) were sold.  Although 
my grandmother disliked alcohol, and rarely drank, she would be hauled off 
to jail in a paddy wagon for her late night activities.  Her father, 
however, who was from Europe, thought is was crazy that Americans would 
prohibit him from drinking beer.  He sent his kids to a local neighborhood 
brewery regularly for buckets of brew, as did all his neighbors.  My great 
grandfather, therefore, was a bigger "criminal" than my grandmother, but 
she was the one that ended up in jail.  She, however, did not stop 
dancing.  Folks were not easily controlled in those days.

The larger issue is, of course, our culture's ambivalent and irrational 
treatment of recreational or pleasure-giving drugs.  As we all know, drugs 
of various types have been in use recreationally, or for religious and 
other purposes, since the beginning of time.  Most recreational drugs that 
are now illegal were readily available and legal a hundred years ago.  It 
is not surprising that with advances in technology synthetic drugs like LSD 
and MDMA should hit a market that has in the past, and will in the future, 
demand substances that enhance pleasure or perception.  Nothing really new 
here.  The traditional, accepted, legal drugs like alcohol and nicotine are 
to my mind inferior and often more dangerous than many of the illegal drugs.

Given the realities of humankinds' love of mind altering substances, my 
position has always been that criminalization does not work.  For that 
subset of users who have addictive problems, treatment is the only 
option.  For the majority of users who do not have addiction problems harm 
reduction and education are the only way to keep people safe, as well as 
some product safety control.  But taking this position is dangerous these 
days, and difficult to argue in the current resurgence of Puritanism.

I'm not going to engage in self-flagellation here.  I have nothing to be 
ashamed of, and I personally will not succumb to fear-based government mind 
control.  If the government wishes to shut down dance clubs and events of 
all sorts, well, they really needn't find drugs at any venue to do 
so...eh?  They can bring their own, and "discover" them.  You can strip 
your patrons naked to prevent drugs from entering your venue, pass out 
Miller Beer T-shirts, and dance to "God Bless America" all night -- won't 
make a difference.

I do think that those who really care about our community should not buy or 
sell illicit drugs at parties.  There have been promoters who have been 
involved in these activities in the past, either directly or 
indirectly.  No drug dealers will ever be permitted to sell drugs at a 
Moksha party and dancers, in my mind, should not support on-site 
sales.  This would take much of the heat off of the scene.

Finally, it is ironic that some really dangerous drug use has emerged in 
the dance community and elsewhere as a result of economic pressures, 
irrationally focused drug enforcement, and relatively easy manufacture -- 
crystal meth.  It's cheap.  It's "American"  -- we give speed to our troops 
(interesting aside, we have not fought any war in the twentieth century 
where the troops on both sides have not been on speed  -- think on that for 
awhile).  You can find it in rural communities as well as urban.  And to my 
mind, it is now destroying the gay dance community.  Crank abuse is what 
folks should be worrying about at present, not E or bud.  But, hell, none 
of this makes any rational sense.

Love,

Apollo





Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

well, actually,

On 5/4/03 7:40 PM, "JBlaze112@aol.com" <JBlaze112@aol.com> wrote:
 
> Now i never said anything about being "depressed" ... i'm more leaning
> towards the feeling of being.... FUCKING PISSED OFF. I'm serious, weather
> these secret anti-rave laws get enforced or not, they simply should not
> exsist. It's outrageous, and It can't be forgiven or overlooked. I think it's
> about time we got midevil on some draconian politician ass. where's your head
> at?? don't let the walls cave in on you.

i agree with you.  these laws shouldn't exist.

unfortunately, we don't have enough people that care making noise.  when
we're in a climate like we are today, a few hundred people sending emails to
their local congressman isn't going to make much impact.  no one knows what
it would take to make the pro-rave movement (or whatever we call it now) as
large as the civil rights movement of the 50's or the anti-war movement of
the 60's, if it ever will.

i think people ought to have the right to do what they want, as long as it
doesn't involve murdering other people, which is what many people think drug
dealers are, something i don't agree with either, but hey.

it's funny you mention this, because the book i'm writing, a science fiction
book that combines something like star trek, groove, and stephen king's the
stand, has a main character that comes to the same realization that you do.
these laws shouldn't exist.  it's the turning point to something i haven't
fully created yet, and i don't know if i'll actually ever finish it, but i
do work on it regularly, i got it up to 200 pages, then viciously hacked it
down to 83 pages, and now i'm back up to about 90 pages.

anyway, this wasn't really intended to be a bsp, i was just trying to say, i
do care, but i think it's a precarious balance for one to care too much or
too little.  either way too far and we risk not being very effective.

later,

DF

Subject: Re: [sfraves] grrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr   >:Q

In a message dated 05/04/2003 5:41:00 PM Pacific Daylight Time, 
sfraves@deepfog.com writes:

<< unfortunately, we don't have enough people that care making noise.  when
 we're in a climate like we are today, a few hundred people sending emails to
 their local congressman isn't going to make much impact.  no one knows what
 it would take to make the pro-rave movement (or whatever we call it now) as
 large as the civil rights movement of the 50's or the anti-war movement of
 the 60's, if it ever will. >>


    I'm not saying that I expect there to be a movement of masses of people 
that we, the SFraves list, personally organize ourselves. You don't need 
anyone else to help you fight the government, you don't have to write 
letters, you don't have to have a parade you don't have to storm the white 
house (although those are very effective actions) All you need is yourself. 
All you need is art, and music and spirituality and symbolism. You can, in 
fact, make a difference just by walking down the street, you can make a 
difference by the way you dance, the way you write, the way you talk, and how 
you treat other people.
    You personally are the most powerful source on the earth that you will 
ever know. You can make a difference just by the way you look at people.
    For instance whenever someone gives you an attitude that reminds you of 
the way the government treats us.... you can give them a look like you'd like 
to kill them but you don't believe in fighting.   And whenever someone gives 
you an attitude that is remenisant of the old rave scene that we all know & 
love, you can give them props and encourage them to keep it up. With that 
philosophy alone you could effect hundreds of people a day. It's all subtle 
you know... it's all in metaphors, there are things going on around you that 
you have the power to change, and it's works in chain reaction. I suppose 
it's like the idea of "think globally, act locally" but it's even more subtle 
than that. locally does not nessesarily mean your community organization, 
your church and your sociology class. 
    the real revolution happens in your mind. People don't just read an email 
and all of the sudden get all fired up and gather into a big crow of maniacs 
to change the world forever.
    i think it was in the matrix that morpheous said something like "the 
world you live in, is one of illusions. and the war we fight, is a spritual 
one"
  I think of the rave scene as sort of a global *underground railroad* 
because we use it to gather and exchange ideas, style, faith and 
inspirations. The african-american slaves used to sing songs that gave clues 
and told stories, sometimes metaphorically on how to escape the plantations 
and how to make it to safety (i.e. folowing the north star all the way to 
canada) these songs took place right under the noses of the slave owners, who 
probably dismissed it as some sort of "nigger talk" excuse my french. Well 
guess what? they were dead wrong, and this movement started a chain of events 
that led to the civil war, and eventually the end of slavery  and racial 
segregation. 
    well the rave scene is similar in which it is used to exchange ideas 
about freedom (mostly metaphorical) and it happens right under the noses of 
the government. Our government probably dissmisses it as a crazy new age 
hippie drugfest. But guess what? They are dead wrong as well. Sure we can sit 
here and try to look at it in their point of view and make excusses for them 
why they treat and think of us so badly. but common, what is there to be 
guiltly about?? Don't you think all of us, as ravers, have done a tremendous 
amount of good in the world in the recent years? don't you think the 
inspiration behind a lot of that good, comes from our happiness that we get 
energy from the rave scene? 
    Anyway the point is that the rave scene is a *SLOWLY* evolving 
underground railroad to true freedom. If you don't think the rave scene is 
evolving then why don't you go look up some of the SFraves archieves from 3 
or 4 or 5 years ago and tell me if you think they are just as inteligent and 
revolutionary as the disscussions we are having now. maybe they were for 
their time but our inteligence is on the incline, at a drastic pace. even the 
hip hop scene is catching on. do you think Conscious hip hop would be the 
same today if not for the influence of the rave scene? i doubt it. it might 
not even exsist as a genre if not for our support. 
    I'm gonna go out on a limb here and say that the rave scene is a bit like 
Christ. In a sense that it's easy to say that it's dead and it's not coming 
back, and technically be right. And I suppose there's a sense of security in 
knowing you're right. but to take that chance... to not know for sure, but 
believe anyway, in something that you can't see with your own two eyes, to 
have courage and faith in, not religion, but music, and dance and 
revolution....that's... that's some shit. 
- word


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

OK... so the venture actually started out in the aftrernoon!  Alex aka =
Alej aka evilempires (if U remember him from back in the day on SFR) =
picked me up in his hoopty & YAAAAAAAAAY Erica was in the car 2 (was he =
name Elena on SFR?)!!  BUt yeah... that was Dope seein' those 2 again!!  =
I missed them soo much!

So we went 2 a House waring 4 Vinny & Tash & hmmmmm... that was fun!!  =
Saw alota old friends again & it was Dope!!!  Hello 2Day... Fuckwork =
came by & we got 2 catch up & totally talk about everything!!  Love That =
Dude!

DJ D spun a Groovy Old School Trance set!!  It was fun!  I mean... I got =
2 hang out w/ Jeff something bost last name la la la from Stargazers & =
LoL... That was fun hangin' out w/ him 'cause we ain't seen each other =
in a Loooooooong time!  & he was spinning this totally Dope Set that =
start out like progressive house then went in 2 like this totally =
Awesome Trance & played so much old Trance songs that I was diggin'!  So =
Dope!!!

Anywaze, after that... went 2 Another house party!!  It was Amber's =
house warming/ Birthday party!!  That was a totally fun party!!  Hella =
DJs got up on the tables & spun!!!  Micah spun this really Awesome =
Jungle Set!!!!  Amber Spun this Hella Dope Acid set!!  Loved it!!!  =
Shane spun this Fuckin' Bad Ass Jungle set & man.... WHOA!!  Samira =
(from SisterSF) spun this totally CooL Breakbeats set & it was totally =
different from the the breakbeats she spun last time I saw her!!! =20

BUt it was Groovy 'cause like alota people I ain't seen in sooooo long =
were there!!!  OK... if any1 here reading this remembers Memo... he says =
hi & he misses U all!  LoL.... it was So Dope hangin' out w/ Memo 'cause =
that guy's such a dork...LoL!!!  He help me coin the phrase "I'm alwaqys =
confussed yet always amused!!"  Well... since I'm like always confussed =
anyway & it's like my natural state!! =20

But yeah... I also got 2 watch a rat get eaten by a snale!!  that was =
soooooo mondo CooL!  yeah!

Then somehow I found a ride 2 go 2 the City 2 go 2 a Birthday Party!!  =
It was Araya's Birthday (Philip Diaz's wifey wife =3D) & Yeah... that =
was a fun Party 2!!  LoL!!  OK... Sir Nod got like totally mad @ me =
'cause there was 1 point @ the party when like I was on the computer =
looking @ friendster...LoL... Hello 2Day!  LoL

Danny Picard spun some Ambient!!  LoL  It was fun there also!!  Totally =
got 2 catch up w/ alota people there I haven't seen in month!!  LoL  1 =

GhettoMorphisis & yeah... lol... that was fun!!  LoL

been getting reconized by hella people @ these random events who know me =

Love!!!  Unfortunately I soooo wasn't able 2 go 2 the Club, club, & Rave =

la la la la! =20

From sfraves-return-101821-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon May 05 19:50:52 2003

From: BodhiInSF@aol.com
Message-ID: <1d4.90d2c2c.2be81a80@aol.com>
Date: Mon, 5 May 2003 15:50:24 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="part1_1d4.90d2c2c.2be81a80_boundary"
X-Mailer: 6.0 sub 10577
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] STARTING FROM SCRATCH: What shall we do?

--part1_1d4.90d2c2c.2be81a80_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

  Raving as we know it is pretty much dead. In Eastern thought it's called 
impermanence, a law of the universe where there is the "dying" of one 
phenomena and the rebirth of another, like without a sunset, there can never 
be a sunrise.
  Going underground isn't really going to work. First of all, the 5-0 is 
pretty much on to us, and I assume they are prepared and willing to find them 
out and shut them down. Who among us are willing to face 20 years in prison 
to throw a UG? Those parties that may be able to slip under the radar of the 
law will become very dangerous. These will be parties where the drug problem 
will be worse, parties that will most likely be thrown by drug dealers and 
other shady characters, attended by mostly by kids and will just exacerbate 
our situation.
  I absolutely agree this anti-rave law sucks Great Dane dicks and is 
blatantly unconstitutional and a paranoid reaction by the powers that be to a 
legitimate problem, plus like I said it will put raves further in the hands 
of the people that got us in the situation we are in today. We need to stand 
up against this Orwellian legislation. But we need to think here for a 
moment, what kind of scene are we fighting for? Are we fighting for a scene 
that has been pretty much taken over by drug dealing? are we defending a 
scene that has too much capital venture promoters, rock star DJ's and egos 
bigger than the planet Jupiter? Are we wasting our energy spinning our wheels 
in the mud and getting all worked up over a scene that facilities 15 year old 
e-tardness? Personally count me out! I haven't been to a party for almost a 
year now, partly because i don't have the money; unemployed now, partly 
because I felt I need to back off and re-center my self, but most of all, I 
was beginning to feel very uncomfortable going to parties attended by a lot 
of kids, some almost young enough to be my kids, not that raving with kids 
was the issue, but seeing them fucking themselves up and feeling being there 
I was supporting their destructive behavior and giving a nod to the promoters 
who were either totally down with this or too busy counting their money to 
give a shit!
  The scene I will get fired up is a scene where the promoters love techno, 
not how big their parties are and how much money they are making, a rave 
scene where the DJ's care about the people, not their images, a rave scene 
where the people think community, not just themselves and go off and hide in 
their little cliques, a rave scene where PLUR is the reason to go, not to 
take 5 pills and lay on the floor all night and get light shows, a rave scene 
where spirituality, how ever you choose to define spirituality and express it 
is the vibe, not narcissism.
  There will never be drug free parties, let's not bull shit the point. The 
only people we are BS'ing is ourselves if we think otherwise. Where ever 
there will be people, sure enough there will be drug use of some kind. That's 
not really the issue. I'm not pro drug use nor am I anti drug use, I'm pro 
responsible drug use by mature adults. My personal opinion, and this doesn't 
have to be everyone's truth, truth is fluid and not so ridged and black and 
white, is that in certain situations drugs can be a positive experience for 
people, and in certain situations it can be a negative experience for people. 
For some people, drugs = trouble. Drugs don't mix well with adolescence 
because their bodies and minds are still developing. Most drug addictions 
begin in the teenage years. We all need to know what situation is best for us 
and respect each other's attitude about drugs. I believe the war on drugs is 
a sham and a black hole for this country and I believe that drugs should be 
decriminalized, and certain drugs like pot, even MDMA, LSD and shrooms (all 
psychedelics) should be outright legal for adults. I should be able to sit in 
the privacy of my home and smoke my dank in peace without worrying about the 
cops breaking down my door and hauling me off to jail like I was a terrorist 
or something.
  Raves should be about the music, but if anyone does decide to use drugs, 
raves should be a safe place to do so, around people who will not judge you 
and take care of you. But when you go to a rave and stumble over e-puddles 
and seeing people OD'ing, are we not being our own prosecuting witness?
  Here's what I think we can do. Let's get together and start having forums 
on how to rebirth the electronic music scene, part truth and reconciliation 
style, and part everyone being able to be heard and their views and ideas 
being respected, that from these forums solutions and a new scene will come 
out and we can have a new scene that will not just be a real people's scene, 
but a scene that will be a legitimate rebuttal to the rave antagonists and 
the war on drugs. We can ask Dance Safe, EMDEF, the ACLU, SFLNC and other 
allies to participate and to give us support and wisdom. what do you think?
  While on the subject of drugs and such, I heard the other day William 
Bennett, Poppa Bush's drug czar, the guy who said if we legalized drugs there 
would be 50 million drugs addicts in America, the guy who wrote the Book of 
Morals, admitted to loosing millions at gambling casinos. His excuse was that 
because "he didn't spend the milk money" it was OK. We have a chance to seize 
the higher moral ground here. Let's do it!
 Peace to all, Bodhi ^ _ ^

--part1_1d4.90d2c2c.2be81a80_boundary--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Paradigm X

--=====================_12420649==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Paradigm X

By Jarret Keene, Las Vegas CityLife
May 5, 2003

I'm almost ashamed to admit that one of my most powerful literary=20
experiences as a child took place during the summer of 1981, when I paid 75=
=20
cents at the corner grocery in Tampa, Fla., for a comic book called "The=20
Uncanny X-Men." I had been following the title for many years, but nothing=
=20
I'd read up to that point even hinted at the scary ideas and images inside=
=20
the "SPECIAL DOUBLE-SIZED 150th ISSUE!"

I say almost ashamed, because it was in a comic book that I gained insight=
=20
into the spiritual cost of being different. Sure, I learned about=20
significant things in other books I read that summer. "Animal Farm" taught=
=20
me to beware of fascists in revolutionary clothing. "The Adventures of=20
Huckleberry Finn" taught me how the best adults make for the worst=20
hypocrites. "The Red Badge of Courage" taught me about the horrors of=20
modern war.

But it was the X-Men who demonstrated how being gifted meant being feared=20
and hated. It was and remains a hard lesson.

The X-Men were created 30 years ago by the legendary Jack Kirby (who also=20
created Captain America, the Fantastic Four and the Incredible Hulk). X-Men=
=20
#150 ("I, Magneto ... ") wasn't written or drawn by Kirby. Instead, Chris=20
Claremont and Dave Cockrum did the honors and succeeded in expanding the=20
existential foundation that Kirby laid 15 years prior. The X-Men were=20
misfits bound together by their freakish powers. They were a powerful=20
symbol for the way I felt about my own misfit status. Like the young=20
mutants, I was a "gifted" student enrolled in a "gifted" school where I=20
took "gifted" classes apart from the larger student body, who naturally=20
looked at me with suspicion and a bit of envy. If my powers had consisted=20
of something more than the ability to read a lot, perhaps they might have=20
grown to fear and hate me.

Being different was the red badge I wore growing up, and I wore it proudly=
=20
with others like myself. It was a privilege the X-Men characters could=20
never afford, because their powers consisted of flying, bending metal,=20
becoming metal. They were weapons, like Wolverine, whose powers were=20
heightened by military scientists, making him a weapon of mass destruction.=
=20
Still, they wanted to be accepted, not persecuted, for their unique=20
qualities. It's a universal feeling, particularly among adolescents, as=20
they discover how they differ and =96 more often than not =96 learn to=
 suppress=20
rather than flaunt the talents they're born with.

Persecution is an ideological game, one played expertly and to the hilt=20
during Reagan's '80s and Dubya's '00s. Cold War brinkmanship is another=20
game that has returned to the headlines. It's the game the mutant villain=20
known as Magneto tried to disassemble in X-Men #150, a comic book I still=20
possess today. In it, when the character Cyclops questions Magneto's=20
resolve to protect mutant kind with a pre-emptive attack on humanity and=20
its nuclear arsenal, the super villain replies, "For myself, I am tired of=
=20
seeing things as they are and asking why, of dreaming of things that never=
=20
were and asking why not. I have the power to make my dreams reality. And=20
that I shall do."

As a child, I understood that Magneto had a point, and I found that point=20
frightening. As columnist Patricia J. Williams writes in the April 28 issue=
=20
of The Nation ("Taking the Cake"), pre-emption "is the Bernhard Goetz=20
doctrine, the cowboy rationale, as well as the hip-hop anthem, shoot first,=
=20
ask questions later. It is a scared gangfighter's way of thinking, and it=20
ensures a never-ending cycle of trauma, in which illusions of danger are=20
treated on par with reality, in which waves of endless violence engulf all=
=20
sane limits."

What horrified me as a child is that Magneto's words were often echoed in=20
the speeches of my cowboy president =96 and now as an adult I hear them in=
=20
the words of the New Cowboy. This sense of horror at our leaders' dreams of=
=20
death is something I've longed to encounter in comics =96 and movie=20
adaptations of comics =96 ever since. After all, comics have always been a=
=20
subversive medium, from Marvel Comics' anti-nuclear stance to Crumb's=20
underground revolution to Alan Moore's deconstruction of Victorian England=
=20
in "From Hell." But all the mainstream comics industry and Hollywood have=20
given us is the same crap, specially formulated to sell Happy Meals. From=20
Superman to Batman to Spider-Man to Daredevil, it has been nothing but a=20
consistent, brain-deadening attempt to pander to the lowest common=20
denominator. Sadly, it works.

No more. I can't fully explain why director Bryan Singer's sequel to his=20
shoddy first foray into the X-Men saga is a superior, thought-provoking,=20
thrilling example of genre filmmaking. (It seems the same hacks who brought=
=20
us that cliched showdown atop the Statue of Liberty in X-Men were involved=
=20
in the making of X2.) But I can outline some themes and moments in "X2:=20
X-Men United" that reveal its subversive spirit and bold vision.

The opening scene, for instance, is harrowing. A mutant (whom we later=20
learn is named Nightcrawler) enters the White House, teleporting his way=20
through Secret Service agents and into the Oval Office. There, the=20
president cowers amid 30 or more agents, their guns drawn, waiting for the=
=20
mutant to break down the door. Instead, he teleports through the room,=20
viciously beating the agents into submission, until it's just him and the=20
Big Man, pinned to the desk. Nightcrawler pulls out a dagger, ready to=20
plunge it, but an agent recovers enough to wing the assassin, who then=20
disappears. The dagger is left sticking in the desk; a note attached reads:=
=20
"Mutant Freedom Now!"

When has a Hollywood superhero flick been this hardcore? Singer (The Usual=
=20
Suspects, Apt Pupil) must have ordered his screenwriters and production=20
crew to put their balls on, because from here things just continue to=20
intensify.

The assault renews the political and public outcry for a Mutant=20
Registration Act, a gross erosion of civil rights on par with the Bush=20
administration's own Patriot Act. Leading the anti-mutant crusade is a=20
wealthy former military commander, William Stryker, played by Brian Cox=20
(Manhunter, LIE), who does his best John Ashcroft impression, as a man=20
whose grievances and psychopathology make him a dangerous administrative=20
figure. He sends U.S. Special Forces to attack Xavier's School for Gifted=20
Youngsters, and the images of soldiers shooting mutant children in the neck=
=20
are absolutely terrifying. There's a moment when the clawed Wolverine (Hugh=
=20
Jackman) =96 who alone is left guarding the school while the X-Men search=
 for=20
Nightcrawler =96 shish-kabobs a dark-hooded intruder. It freezes the heart:=
=20
Mutant has killed man, and there's no going back. The war is on.

Indeed, the humans' effort to pre-empt another mutant attack has wrought =96=
=20
as the Israelis and Palestinians fail to acknowledge in their treatment of=
=20
each other and as our own leaders refuse to perceive =96 more violence. As a=
=20
result, the evil mutant Magneto (Ian McKellen, The Lord of the Rings)=20
unites with the X-Men to fight a common foe, the U.S. government, and=20
impending disaster haunts every subsequent frame.

There are other chilling scenes. Teenaged Bobby, or Iceman (Shawn Ashmore),=
=20
briefly shelters Wolverine and two younger mutants at his parents' house.=20
There, he "comes out" to his family that he possesses unique powers, to=20
which his mother replies, "Have you tried not being a mutant?"=20
Heartbreakingly, Bobby's brother immediately phones the authorities, and=20
the group is again on the run. Fear shatters even familial bonds.

Then there's the scene where Magneto lures Pyro (Aaron Stanford, Tadpole),=
=20
Xavier's student, to the dark side. "You're a god among insects," he says,=
=20
flattering the burgeoning pyromaniac. "Don't let anyone tell you=20
otherwise." Mutant power is a curse, until it's used to harm others, the=20
weaker ones, humans. Then it becomes a mark of supremacy.

I could go on. Of course, X2 has everything the rubes expect from=20
Hollywood: lavish special effects and violence. The pill beneath the sugar,=
=20
though, is that the violence serves as a warning about the direction our=20
country is headed. Mindless fear and policies of intolerance will result in=
=20
a cycle of bloodshed from which no one will be spared, not even the=
 innocent.

Who are the innocent? Singer's new movie offers no answers. Rather, X2 is=20
full of troubling questions. If all summer movies were this daring, comics=
=20
enthusiasts would no longer have to suffer inferior Hollywood adaptations.=
=20
Indeed, the American superhero comic book is a mythic genre that has=20
finally been translated into a remarkable film. Let's see if American=20
audiences will embrace or loathe the long-awaited breakthrough.

"X2: X-Men" United opens Friday, May 2.

Jarret Keene is CityLife's A&E editor.

http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=3D15813



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to=20
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great=20
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in=
=20
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of=20
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the=20
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager




--=====================_12420649==_.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] djing is like customer service nrr

--0-218363455-1052169571=:41135
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

look at it this way....you go to a massive party, and like 10 dj's or so will play the same song at least once in their set...so, if you are at the party the whole night, then you'll hear the same song ten times at least...that's pretty good, huh? and it is kind of like shopping at a furniture store or a high end audio shop...10 different sales people will tell you ten different times during the 10 minutes that you are in the store that such-and-such is a great model. at least you know for sure now which one not to buy! :)

I used to belive in antidepressants and all that shit, now its nutrition, yoga, and astrology. Some nice tea wouldn't hurt either, the kind you make from leaves in a little ceramic pot and get at tea shops with sweet little asian ladies. Call or Email an old friend you haven't talked to in a long time, give a panhandler a nice peice of fruit, and if you still feel shitty, go for a hike in some nature, or pick some strawberries, and buy or pick a flower for you or someone you love.

From sfraves-return-101832-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon May 05 23:20:56 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-101832-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 29425 invoked from network); 5 May 2003 23:20:56 -0000
Message-Id: <5.1.0.14.2.20030505151652.02ed4b40@mail.speakeasy.net>
X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.net
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 5.1
Date: Mon, 05 May 2003 16:25:02 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_4926396==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Groove Garden

--=====================_4926396==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I think much of the "rave is dead" talk one hears these days has little to 
do with the realties of transformative dance groups I see evolving in our 
community.  When many people use the term "rave" they seem to be referring 
to the mainstream, commercial-style massives and other events that have 
attracted the attention of the public, government and marketers over the 
past few years.  What I have seen, however, is the creation of a 
multiplicity of EDM families in the Bay that manifest the vibe and 
intention of old school "raves," yet have adapted to their communities and 
changing times.  Let's call them spirit-based dance communities if the term 
"rave" has become meaningless.

Groove Garden is one such community.   GG, the creation of Martin Tickle 
(DJ Dragonfly), has been going down once a month for nearly four years in 
Marin.  In addition, Martin has thrown several parties in San Francisco.

I first met Martin at some Kelly's Mission Rock party.  He was spinning on 
the upper dance floor and I was much impressed with his craft.  We talked, 
and he put me on his email list for future GG events.  Had it not been for 
this chance encounter I probably would never have known about his little 
tribe and its philosophy of putting the dancer's needs first.

I attended several SF-based GG parties over the years, the last a sybaritic 
affair held at Studio Z featuring an amazing crowd of costumed dancers, 
drummers, live acts, male and female belly dancers, and an extraordinary 
vibe -- much like early raves.  I had never, though, gone out to the 
monthly GG party.  My bad.  Guess I thought it wasn't worth the drive for a 
Saturday night party that ran from 8:00 PM to 1:30 AM.

When Fraser Clark arrived in town I notified Martin, and he extended an 
invitation for Fraser to speak at the last GG Saturday night.  We all drove 
out to Fairfax and I had my first experience with this happy tribe up north.

Martin achieved a remarkable thing with GG.  He has integrated a regular 
EDM party into the community around Fairfax.  The party is held in the 
local church.  No police presence.  No security.  People of all ages are 
welcome.

The vibe and aesthetics are certainly Marin:  a sort of New Age cultural 
base transformed by electronica and brought into the twenty-first 
century.  GG is certainly "organic."  Virtually everyone dances in bare 
feet.  An ample and tasty selection of vegetarian foods are available as 
well as teas, ciders and a ginseng/l-carnitine energy drink that was quite 
effective. No alcohol.  No drugs except for some bud smoking in the outdoor 
garden.  Very friendly people and accepting vibe.  And people of an 
astounding range of ages dancing energetically all evening long.

The party begins at eight, and for the first couple of hours there were 
grade-school aged kids dancing with their parents.  Quite nice.  As the 
evening moved on, a more mature and diverse crowd rolled in.  GG is very 
well attended.  One man I talked to was seventy-one.  He had lost a lung to 
cancer, but he came every month to dance.  Another guy I talked with 
outside in the garden was from Santa Cruz.  Mid-twenties.  A year ago he 
had a life-changing experience at a 13Moontribe full moon rave and was just 
learning about the dance community.  I even ran into Mercutio, who I have 
not seen for awhile.

Now, I am an urban dancer used to a more gritty, edgy scene.  But I must 
say this happy, healthy environment was quite appealing.  Women left their 
purses unattended on chairs.  Lots of trust.  No drama.  Lavish 
decorations, including old school oil projections.  A proper chill room 
with ambient music.

The music rocked my soul.  DJ Dragonfly's set -- funky house mixed with 
world beats and music -- was most excellent.  Martin is rather laid back 
when he is not behind the decks.  He is a wild man when he is spinning.  He 
beats on electronic drums over the house, and at one point he had a trained 
opera singer on the PA singing lyrics to some old disco.  All night long 
there were drummers in the back enhancing the mood.  Again, everyone danced 
with much fervor -- both young and old.

Last month Martin and Rhythmystic began a weekly event on Thursday nights 
in San Francisco called Alchemy, dedicated to transforming "the dance 
experience through the infusion of spirit, spark, and groove" at Mission 
and 8th.  Alcohol-free.  Shoes optional.  All ages.  Haven't been yet, but 
I'm looking forward to seeing how GG tribe will do with its own brand of 
spirit-based dance in the City.

When I hear "death of the scene," therefore, I am somewhat bewildered.  The 
community is transforming itself.  I just happened upon Groove Garden.  I'm 
sure there are many such intentional dance families out there.  Not mass 
advertised.  Not at clubs.  Developed through email lists and personal 
invitation.  Different vibes.  Different folks.  But all dancing to EDM, 
integrating the dance floor into their lives, and in a small but consistent 
and ultimately powerful fashion changing the world.

Much love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager




--=====================_4926396==_.ALT--

From: Mary Morris <morrism@washpost.com>
Date: Mon, 5 May 2003 19:53:20 -0400
MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: [sfraves] anti-rave legislation covered in 5/15 rolling stone





sorry if this has already been posted, i didn't notice it on any of the
digests:

page 30

<  Trouble in Clubland: Congress passes controversial anti-rave bill

By Jenny Eliscu  >

Dance clubs, concert halls and even outdoor festivals are in danger of
being put out of business thanks to a new piece of legislation that passed
in
Congress on April 10th. According to the bill, any individual who owns or
operates a venue where audience members are using drugs could be sent to
jail
or subjected to steep fines. Sponsored by senators Joseph Biden (D-Del.),
Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) and Joseph Lieberman (D-Conn.), the bill was tacked
onto
the Amber Alert Act, concerning child abductions - a move opponents say was

intended to avoid close scrutiny. (The new law is a revision of an earlier
proposal known as the RAVE Act, an acronym for Reducing Americans'
Vulnerability to Ecstasy.)

"It isn't just a threat to the rave community," say William McColl,
director
of National Affairs for the Drug Policy Alliance, "but to any community
that
isn't liked by the majority - hip-hop events, gay and lesbian circuit
parties, even rock & roll shows like the Grateful Dead or Phish." McColl
acknowledges it could be years before anyone is prosecuted but says the law

may scare off promoters and keep them from holding raves.

Biden was unavailable for comment, but his office directed Rolling Stone to

speak with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America.  "We're not anti-rave,"

says that group's spokesman, Howard Simon. "This isn't like John Lithgow in

Footloose telling people, 'Good God, don't dance.' This could help
authorities to go after the few bad apples turning a winking blind eye to
drug use."

Donnie Estopinal, the New Orleans promoter who was unsuccessfully
prosecuted
in 2000 under the federal "crackhouse statute," doesn't see it that way.
"This law will definitely have an effect on whether promoters can get
access
to venues," he says. "Just the threat of being prosecuted is enough to
scare
people away.

"We already search the hell out of everybody," he continues. "It's harder
to
get into a rave than it is to get on an airplane. We're forced to treat our

customers like criminals before they even get in the door."

(sorry for any typos)

PROPS and THANK YOU to ROLLING STONE!

i think the writer does a fine job of explaining to the general public what

just happened legislatively to us and why we, and not just us, should be
concerned.

if you agree, please write to rolling stone and say so:

letters@rollingstone.com

fax:  212-484-3434

thank you!  thank you!

respectfully,
mary m :)

>As a child, I understood that Magneto had a point, and I found that point 
>frightening. As columnist Patricia J. Williams writes in the April 28 
>issue of The Nation ("Taking the Cake"), pre-emption "is the Bernhard 
>Goetz doctrine, the cowboy rationale, as well as the hip-hop anthem, shoot 
>first, ask questions later. It is a scared gangfighter's way of thinking, 
>and it ensures a never-ending cycle of trauma, in which illusions of 
>danger are treated on par with reality, in which waves of endless violence 
>engulf all sane limits."

This quote really bothers me.  I'm thinking Patricia neither watched Cowboy 
movies nor listens to Hip-hop.  The Cowboy culture and gangsters do both 
use violence as a means to an end, but the similarities stop 
there.  Hip-hop and gangsta rap are not one in the same.  There is no 
Hip-hop anthem which promotes violence of any sort, that I know 
of.  Furthermore, I doubt Patricia was a former gang member; I think any 
one could tell you that danger is not an illusion.

I couldn't read the whole article because it has spoilers, and I haven't 
seen X2 yet.


sarilion

back.

with their substance use and learned to say 'no' or 'enough' a little more
often.  this country has a horrible problem with that not just with drugs,
but alcohol and food.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Groove Garden

apollo,

On 5/5/03 7:25 PM, "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:

> I think much of the "rave is dead" talk one hears these days has little to
> do with the realties of transformative dance groups I see evolving in our
> community.  When many people use the term "rave" they seem to be referring
> to the mainstream, commercial-style massives and other events that have
> attracted the attention of the public, government and marketers over the
> past few years.  
> 

i think we are actually talking about the same thing, and probably agree
more than we may know.  sometimes when i get into posting a lot, i probably
put off an air that i know everything and i'm always right.  neither are
true, though sometimes i'll drive a point into the ground and it looks like
such.  

> When I hear "death of the scene," therefore, I am somewhat bewildered.  The
> community is transforming itself.  I just happened upon Groove Garden.  I'm
> sure there are many such intentional dance families out there.  Not mass
> advertised.  Not at clubs.  Developed through email lists and personal
> invitation.  Different vibes.  Different folks.  But all dancing to EDM,
> integrating the dance floor into their lives, and in a small but consistent
> and ultimately powerful fashion changing the world.
> 

i think this is happening all over the country, to some degree, but more,
perhaps in san francisco.  back to my opinion that the rave scene is
essentially dead, death in itself is also a rebirth of something new .. a
transformation of sorts.  i'm not suggesting it's all over and we all
retreat to our bedrooms and never go out anymore, it's just not like it used
to be.  and hey, maybe that's for the better!

BACK IN THE DAY!!! LOL!! GROOVY lalala ...

anyway, that's my 2 cents.

fog out

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 96204 invoked from network); 6 May 2003 03:02:39 -0000
Message-ID: <20030506030235.99472.qmail@web12308.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 5 May 2003 20:02:35 -0700 (PDT)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: sarah_schumm@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] RE:PLEASE TELL ME I AM A SHITY PERSON/ alternatives to prozac

> now its nutrition, yoga, and astrology.

I dunno about astrology, but I can definately vouch for the other two... if you
extract yoga out into simple "a good workout" instead of a specific exercise.

After a long night of dancing, especially to hard house or happy hardcore, I
get home flat out exhausted, but I feel SOOOOOO good; especially after
showering and getting a bit of sleep.

And as for foods, it's basic chemistry.  Chocolate and coffee contain tons of
mood-enhansing psychoactives (look 'em up on erowid... theres a LOT more in
there than just caffeine!).  And turkey, red wines, some cheeses and some nuts
are notably high in tryptophan, which gets converted into, you know it,
seratonin, that neurotransmitter we know and love so much.  LOTS of foods
contain tryptophan, or others.  The ones I listed stick in my head because
they're so high in it.  That's why the warning labels on some anti-depresssants
(mostly MAOIs, but some SSRIs) tell you to avoid the big three: turkey, red
wines, and cheeses.  The idea is, that your doctor is controlling your doseage
very carefully, and extra seratonin, in those circumstances, is actually bad.

Case in point:  Sarah herself last night, on the chocolate-covered espresso
beans!


cya,
john
