Of course 15 yos should be munging pills - we need to train the youth to rely on chemically induced mood swings. Once we have a generation of pavlov dogs that we control we can launch an attack on the white house and start enlightening the water supplies of the masses. Plus, if we're lucky we can cause widespread erectile disfunction and they won't be able to breed.

Totally unnecessary that, sorry. Reality is, I never saw as many 15yo mungers until I came to this country, and it is pretty disturbing. I was talking to a good friend of mine once about what you can do to talk to your children about drugs, and he said 'All I could really hope for was that I could persuade my kids to wait until they are 18', and I agree with his statement. So much more damage is done to young adults from every kind of drug consumption, and I think that if you can just wait a few years you'll be a lot more mentally able to handle your drugs, and you won't hack up your body and mind so much. I think so little is known about the consequences of drug use during puberty and the stakes are so high that it makes little sense to go crazy.


Another question... who here thinks that they would be the same person if they had regularly munged down pills from the age of 13 onwards?

[ie weekly, or whatever you think is excessive... or perhaps we should try, 'if you had used the same level of drugs at 13 as you did at 23']

Matt

Subject: [sfraves] RE:PLEASE TELL ME I AM A SHITY PERSON/ alternatives to prozac

LOL! , for the record, I didn't actually eat the beans, everybody just 
thought I did because I was acting like a nut case! This is what happens 
when someone with a natural tendency towards adhd and a saratonin imbalance 
gets over stimulated. I felt like shit today! When you become an old lady 
like me you will need to do yoga too!

At 08:02 PM 5/5/2003 -0700, you wrote:
> > now its nutrition, yoga, and astrology.
>
>I dunno about astrology, but I can definately vouch for the other two... 
>if you
>extract yoga out into simple "a good workout" instead of a specific exercise.
>
>After a long night of dancing, especially to hard house or happy hardcore, I
>get home flat out exhausted, but I feel SOOOOOO good; especially after
>showering and getting a bit of sleep.
>
>And as for foods, it's basic chemistry.  Chocolate and coffee contain tons of
>mood-enhansing psychoactives (look 'em up on erowid... theres a LOT more in
>there than just caffeine!).  And turkey, red wines, some cheeses and some nuts
>are notably high in tryptophan, which gets converted into, you know it,
>seratonin, that neurotransmitter we know and love so much.  LOTS of foods
>contain tryptophan, or others.  The ones I listed stick in my head because
>they're so high in it.  That's why the warning labels on some 
>anti-depresssants
>(mostly MAOIs, but some SSRIs) tell you to avoid the big three: turkey, red
>wines, and cheeses.  The idea is, that your doctor is controlling your doseage
>very carefully, and extra seratonin, in those circumstances, is actually bad.
>
>Case in point:  Sarah herself last night, on the chocolate-covered espresso
>beans!
>
>
>cya,
>john

Subject: [sfraves] [sf] we are 2 yrs old

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
under the radar // 2 year anniversary // http://utr.praemedia.com/
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Terrible 2's !
With the Grace of God, and a healthy ecconomic climate, u.t.r.// is 
celebrating 2 years of a random thought process. From our humble beginnings 
at Fuse in North Beach, to 26Mix in the Mission, not to mention the 
one-offs, u.t.r.// has been the longest running experimental electronic and 
acoustic music event in San Francisco.

U.T.R.// has hosted:
Jonah Sharp, O.S.T. ,Broker/Dealer, Richard Devine, Taylor Deupree, Gold 
Chians, Todd Sines, Sagan, Kit Clayton, Safety Scissor, Sutekh, Sote and a 
multitude of Bay Area improvisational musicians, to name a SMALL fraction of 
all of the artists who have graced our little show. Our goal in the phuture 
is to continue to bring you new art activities, starting with this one:

Terrible 2's!

Tuesday, June 3rd, 2003
u.t.r.// 2 year anniversary event

LIVE PERFORMANCES:
- DAT Politics
- Blevin Blechdom
- Lesser
- Lance Grabmiller

DJ PERFORMANCES:
- Wobbly
- Zygote
- VERY Special Guests TBA

FOR VENUE LOCATION, GO TO: http://utr.praemedia.com/ 2 weeks before the 
show, and we'll turn you to on to the space of the phuture.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
under the radar // dj night at julip
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

UNDER THE RADAR DJ Night at Julip
http://www.julipsf.com/
839 Geary Street ( between Larkin and Hyde )
9:30pm - Close
no admission

Sounds from a Pretty World: Zygote and Friends serve up Plunder Jazz, 
Abstract Weird-Tempo and Experimental Pop Musique with an electro twist. 
Come early, as the night is usually packed out with super models and jet 
setters of the IDM world........

SPECIAL GUEST May 7th, DJ "Clarity""

Clarity began spinning in the North Bay at the age of 19. Realizing her true 
love for techno in 1998 she quickly swept across rave scene dropping as hard 
and heavy as she could get away with. Playing at parties like Harmony, 
Children of the Sun, Happy Kids, and Flower Shop she definitely had wide 
variety of music lovers surrounding her and with the support of many of 
those promoters she was able to play out at a lot of parties before having 
any DJ recordings out. With a high demand for trance and house, being a 
techno DJ in the community was a challenge.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
under the radar // thank you // http://utr.praemedia.com/

Subject: [sfraves] Amber alert should only be directed towards minors not us.

    Does everyone here realize that this Amber girl was only 9 years old, and 
from texas? And her abduction had nothing to do with parties or drugs? I want 
to make sure everyone knows that, i know most of you do but sometimes these 
tricky politics can decieve us. i think it should be demanded that this bill, 
if it's going to be continued to be called the Amber alert bill, only pertain 
to minors, and have nothing to do with drugs. 
    It can't be accepted or forgotten that this add on IS the RAVE act (which 
didn't pass on it's own) in deguise.

    the add on is totally unessesary, it's a perfectly well intentioned bill 
all up untill the RAVE ACT add on, and then it's an outrage. They are using a 
good cause to overshadow a hiddeous dislike for the rave scene. It would be 
like issueing a 911 bill about an alert for terrorists and then at the end 
saying in small letters... also middle easterners can no longer fly in planes,
 and then passing the bill.
    If the bill is truely about KIDNAPPING which it claims to be, then we 
should demand that it only pertain to youngsters and NOT everyone who goes to 
parties. and if the government outlaws minors from going to raves then so be 
it. I didn't start going to raves till i was 18 and i'm glad i waited. 
    So anyway i know not all of us have time to protest and do political 
demonstrations and write letters right away. I for myself can say i will 
NEVER again support our government untill this perticular bill gets set 
straight. I'm not moving away to another country, and i'm not gonna do 
something stupid that puts me in jail. but i will symbolically, as an artist 
be anti-(US)government for the rest of my life until things like these get 
set straight. i'll try to write letters, protest and vote, but beyond that 
i'm going to make noise artistically because I'm.... in film school. and i 
have the tools to influence people. (appallo made a good point how films can 
metaphorically be a political statement, such as X-men) 
    I think the government has gone & done it with this bill. it's over the 
line. they have fuct with the wrong people and they're gonna pay for it. how 
it's going to happen i can't tell you for sure but things are going to 
change... and we have the rest of our lives to figure out how. (and if that 
fails we can raise our children to suceed where we have failed) 
    I know a lot of you feel trying to change the government is hopeless but 
I know that we all have friends who have friends who have friends who have 
friends, and i think that every one of us can now agree that the government 
has throuroughly betrayed us. First by introducing the RAVE ACT (which didn't 
pass) and then by deguising it behind a bill that they knew was going to 
pass, as an add on. It's time we plan on taking over america, and getting rid 
of our horses ass policies that make me want to puke. i know it's sounds 
wierd to say "take over america" so lightly in a sentance like it can 
actually be done but i think it can and i'll tell you how in my next email. - 
 johnny bzzzzzzz

>From the Creators of Power Puff Girls 1 and 2, Enter the Dragon 1-3 and countless other record breaking events.

 

Shaolin Presents.Our BIGGEST party ever!

June 13, 2003

HIGH OCTANE <~~mini-MASSIVE

============================

 

LOCK N LOAD

The Lock N' Load project consists of two Dutch producers / DJs: Frank van Rooijen and Niels Pijpers. One fine day the Club Caviar boys came to visit the Lock N' Load studio, heard the old version of a song and offered to do a remix of it. In collaboration with Lock N' Load they delivered this stunning result and Niels decided to release "Blow Ya Mind". After all on Blue White Records, within a period of three weeks, it became the No. 1 club record in the Netherlands, and Europe followed soon after that, the United Kingdom was ready to be conquered. Through no. 1 positions in both the UK Club and UK Dance chart it had an amazing entry at 6. Help us welcome Lock N' Load to Sacramento.

Chris C.

Now firmly established as one of the Biggest and most popular DJ / Producers on the UK Hard House/NRG scene, Chris has masterminded the emergence and rapid success of his 3 Labels, Mohawk, Aztec and Nile. Positioning the former today as one of the genres top 5 marques. With over 30 single releases and 2 Albums to his name on various labels including Tidy Trax, Tinrib, Eve, Honeypot, Phoenix Rising, GBT, Bulletproof, etc...Chris' reputation as one of Britain's finest exponent of Hard House, both behind the decks and in the studio, continues to grow.

Whistler

Victor Cape a.k.a. Whistler shines as a highly respected DJ on the Pacific Northwest dance scene. Known for his tight mixing skills and uplifting personality behind the decks, Whistler blends energy and emotion from Hard Melodic Trance, Epic Anthems and Hard House to take his listeners on a dance floor rollercoaster ride. If being a DJ wasn't enough, he also manages Lovetribe which has quickly become one of the most well respected event productions in Seattle. It's been over a year and a half since Whistler's last performance in Northern California. So we're excited to bring him out for his first Sacramento performance!

 

 

Dyloot

Arguably Nor-Cals BIGGEST Trance DJ/Producer watch him work his MAGIC over the crowd.

 

Tom Slik Vs. Tracer

Two of Nor-Cals Biggest Trance DJs wage war for the first time in Sacramento.

Denise Vs. Paul the Fanman

First ever Teacher vs. Student battle between the establish Denise and the BIG up n comer Paul. Lets see if he learned some tricks on his own.

Dragnfly Vs. Scepter

Shaolins two BIGGEST DJs go head to head to see who really is the SHAOLIN MASTER.

Bazooka Joe Vs. Reckless Ryan

Showmanship is the only way to describe the performance these two put on. Turntablist House at its best. Watch as these two leave you in a wicky-wick-AWWW!

Valerie Sparks vs. The Doctor

Nor Cals Best Hardcore Female DJ goes against this up n coming Junglist.

Sascha 23 Vs. Gauge

The founder of Xtort bumps heads with one of Shaolins Most talented Producer in a must see set with original Shaolin tracks.

 

 

IMPORTANT!!!

All High Octane Presale Holders will get into our next event (Aquatech) FREE!

Free: Glowsticks, Glow Bracelets, Glow mouth pieces, Stickers, Tasty Candy, CDs and Gift Bags.

ALL RESPONSIBLE AGES!!!

7pm - 5am

Tons of Lasers, Lighting and Visuals. Plus dancing AIR PEOPLE and vendor village.

www.shaolinproductions.net <http://www.shaolinproductions.net>

Black police showin' out for the white cop
Ice Cube will Swarm
On any motherfucker in a blue uniform
Just 'cause I'm from the CPT
Punk police are afraid of me, huh
A young nigger on the warpath
And when I finish, it's gonna be a bloodbath
Of cops dyin' in L.A.
Yo, Dre, I got something to say ...

Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!

SCENE I :

Pull your goddamn ass over right now
Aw, shit, and what the fuck you pullin' me over for?
'Cause I feel like it, just sit your ass on the curb and shut the
fuck up!
Man, fuck this shit
All right smartass, I'm takin' your black ass to jail

M.C. Ren, will you please give your testimony to the jury about
this fucked up incident?

Fuck the police and Ren said it with authority
Because the niggers on the street is a majority
A gang - that's wit whoever i'm steppin'
And a motherfuckin' weapon is kept in
A stand-by for the so called law
Wishin' Ren was a nigger that they never saw
Lights all flashin' behind me
But they're scared of a nigger so they mace to blind me
But that shit don't work, I just laugh
Because it gives 'em a hint not to step in my path
To police, I'm sayin', "Fuck you punk!"
Readin' my rights and shit - it's all junk
Pullin' out a silly club so you stand
With a fake-assed badge and a gun in your hand
But take off the gun so you can see what's up
And we'll go at it, punk, and I'm a' fuck you up
Make you think I'm a' kick your ass
But drop your gat and Ren's gonna blast
I'm sneaky as fuck when it comes to crime
But I'm a' smoke 'em now and not next time
Smoke any motherfucker that sweats me
And any asshole that threatens me
I'm a sniper with a hell of a scope
Takin' out a cop or two that can't cope with me
The motherfuckin' villain that's mad
With potential to get bad as fuck
So I'm a' turn it around
Put in my clip, yo
And this is the sound
Yeah, Somethin' like that
But it all depends on the size of the gat
Takin' out a police would make my day
But a nigger like Ren don't give a fuck to say...

Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!

SCENE II :

Yo, Man, whatcha need?
Police, open now (oh shit), we have a warrent for Eazy E's arrest
Oh shit
Get down and put your hands up where I can see 'em!
Man, what did I do?
Just shut the fuck up and get yo' motherfuckin' ass on the floor
But I did'nt do shit
Man, just shut the fuck up

Eazy E, why don't you step up to the stand and tell the jury how
you feel about this bullshit?

I'm tired of the motherfuckin' jackin'
sweatin' my gang while I'm chillin' in the shack an'
Shinin' the light in my face and for what?
Maybe it's because I kick so much butt
I kick ass, or maybe it's 'cause I blast
Oh a stupid-assed nigger when I'm playing with the trigger
Of an Uzi or an AK
'Cause the police always got somethin' stupid to say
They put up my picture with silence
'Cause my identity by itself causes violence
The E with the criminal behavior
Yeah, I'm a gangster, but still I got flavor
Without a gun and a badge, what do you got?
A sucker in uniform waitin' to get shot
By me or another nigger
And with a gat, it don't matter if he's smaller or bigger
(Size don't mean shit, he's from the old school, fool)
And as you all know, E's here to rule
Whenever I'm rollin', keep lookin' in the mirror
And ears on cue, yo, so I can hear a
Dumb motherfucker with a gun
and if I'm rollin' off the eight, he'll be the one
That I take out and then get away
While I'm driving off laughin', this is what I'll say ...

Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!

The verdict :

The jury has found you guilty of being a red-neck, white-bread,
Chicken-shit motherfucker
"That's a lie! that's a goddamn lie!"
Get him out of here!
"I want justice!"
Get him the fuck out of my face
"I want justice!"
Out right now!
"Fuck you, you black motherfuckerrrrrrrrrrr!"

Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!
Fuck the police!

Subject: [sfraves] BSP Cosmic Beats presents iGroove Sun. May 25th 

>From the Creator's of Green, Beat Freaks, and
TranceFormers, Cosmic Beats is proud to bring you an
event to get you moving...


Cosmic Beats Announces:
iGroove
Sunday, May 25th 2003
Memorial Day Weekend
Fully Permitted SF Location
7pm - 2am , 18+ to dance / 21+ to enhance
$15 Presales / $20 Door Tickets

Cosmic Beats is always dedicated to providing top
notch talent from the globe, nation, and local dance
scene combined with only top notch production! Come
celebrate your holiday weekend with us, and shake your
body to the following DJs:

CZR (Moody, Subliminal, Funk Parlor, Fused - Chicago)

Cosmic Beats is pleased to announce the return of one
of our favorite DJ/Producers, CZR! Since his signing
to IHR and Subliminal Records, CZR has remained one of
the most prominent producers in all of house music,
releasing such massive tracks as "Bringin' the Funk"
and "Bad Enough" and collaborating with such prolific
artists as Bob Sinclar, Conga Squad, Angel Alanis and
Daryl Pandy. Don't miss out as CZR makes his first
visit to the San Francisco bay area in over a year,
primed to drop his signature Chicago style funk and
give the bay area house heads what they have been
begging for!

RAOUL ZERNA (Tech Asylum, Solmatic, Duty Free,
Moonshine, RaoulZerna.com - LA)

One of the busiest and most influential producers/DJ's
in the House music movement, Raoul Zerna's deeply
infectious and unique style has not gone unnoticed.
With over 30 releases to his credit, producing and
remixing tracks for some the biggest record labels in
the world, Raoul has attracted major media attention
and licensing deals. His recent dance floor singles
"Love Sequences" and  "The Hype" were used on Mixer
magazine's compilation mixed by Scott Hardkiss and
were also featured on MTV's hit show "The Blame Game".
Always ready to raise the bar, Raoul Zerna has
recently decided to create and develop his own record
label "Tech Asylum" for his favorite House sounds.

JOEY MAZZOLA (Solmatic, JoeyMazzola.com)

Joey Mazzola is the bay area's favorite house DJ. From
his quickly adopted Solmatic Records to radio time on
House Nation, you know that Joey Mazzola's heart lays
in pushing the music that he loves and setting off
dancefloors with flawless mixing and scratching.

HAPPY KID MARTY (Happy Kids)

Get ready to get down as the bay area's funkiest of
DJs drops your favorite disco flavored house anthems
and a stage presence that will leave the crowd with
their hands in the air screaming for more!!

RECKLESS RYAN (RecklessRyan.com, BasslineFM, KSJS,
Zero Magazine)

Reckless Ryan is quickly becoming one of the bay
area's top house DJs with scratch tricks and quick
mixing!

MATT THOMAS (Cosmic Beats, Remix)

Ever since his return from San Diego, DJ Matt Thomas'
popularity has quickly been on the rise. From his
solid mixing abilities to his quality track selection
to his boyish good looks, playing out multiple times a
week has become the norm!

FELIPE AVELAR (www.djfelipeavelar.com)

Rocking the decks time and time again, Felipe Avelar
has proven himself to be true true showman and
purveyor of only the finest house beats.

DAVID ANTHONY (Cosmic Beats)

Between throwing countless quality events and drinking
many drinks at the stick, its a wonder David Anthony
has time for mixing at all! Don't miss out as the man
behind Cosmic Beats shows why the ladies love him!


$15 Presale Tickets will go on sale Friday, May 9th
at:

Berkeley - Skills DJ Workshop
Fremont - Straight Hits VinylShop
San Francisco - Frequency 8
San Jose - Hit Factory
Santa Clara - Solid Grooves
Online - www.spinfoil.com

Door Tickets will be available for $20. 

For Directions, call our 24 hour info line:

415.263.6732

From sfraves-return-101868-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed May 07 03:23:38 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-101868-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 40979 invoked by uid 1103); 7 May 2003 03:23:38 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 40965 invoked from network); 7 May 2003 03:23:38 -0000
Message-ID: <20030507032333.27315.qmail@web12308.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 6 May 2003 20:23:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: sarah_schumm@yahoo.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] re:STARTING FROM SCRATCH: What shall we do?

> a few young kids are inadvertantly killing their own scene by using 
> drugs, I hope something happens simalar to what happened with punk 
> scene and we start seeing "Straight Edge" ravers.

Well, I can't really comment on much of the punk scene HERE, as I mostly quit
going to shows when I started going to parties.  But if it's ANYTHING like the
punk scene on the east coast (I'm thinking mainly of Florida, Boston, and
Balitmore here.) then I can confidently say that there aren't any less people
getting "fucked up" in that scene than in ours.

Oh, the CHOICE of drugs is sometimes different.  And where/when they choose to
do them is sometimes different.  But there are just as many punks getting
blitzed every weekend as there are ravers.  About the only thing that the
straight edgers do is try to ostracize and exclude the obviously-fucked up
people (And many didn't even do THAT, they were quite happy to socialize with
someone who was high, they'd just stay sober themselves), and make them be more
discrete.

(Now, there WERE the occasional entirely-straight-edger shows, where you just
did NOT show up non-sober, but those were the exception.  And I don't think we
want any poor kid getting a boot party because he took a pill at the wrong
partie.)

Though I've mostly stuck with punk & ska, when I was younger, and raveing, now,
I've bounced in and out of the scenes surrounding a good dozen genres of music.
 Reggae didn't turn me into a stoner, punk didn't turn me into a tweaker,
raving didn't turn me into an e-tard, and grunge CERTIANLY did not turn me into
a heroin junkie.

Though the drugs of choice, and the places it's acceptable to do them, might
vary from scene to scene, it's been my observation that there are people who
will:

1) Never do any drug (either EVER, or ANYMORE)
2) People who experiment, but don't really use
3) People who will use occasionally and casually
and
4) People who will get fucked up as often as possible and screw up their lives

... And you'll find ALL four, in EVERY scene, and by and large, the choice of
music will not affect the fact that all four are present.  About the ONLY
differences that I've noticed in rave scene are, the drugs of choice, and that
users are not ostracized, and they can be non-sober openly, instead of hideing
it as in some others.


cya,
john

At 08:23 PM 5/6/2003 -0700, you wrote:
> > a few young kids are inadvertantly killing their own scene by using
> > drugs, I hope something happens simalar to what happened with punk
> > scene and we start seeing "Straight Edge" ravers.

Err. I should have said I BET something happens...
http://www.frii.com/~lust/pure10.html
The reason I said that is because I'm sometimes feeling those same emotions 
that turned me into a "Straight Edger" back in the day, we didn't call it 
that yet though. I was on a punk kick because I just learned about 924 
Gilman St. Wouldn't it be cool if raver kids had something like that?


>Well, I can't really comment on much of the punk scene HERE, as I mostly quit
>going to shows when I started going to parties.  But if it's ANYTHING like the
>punk scene on the east coast (I'm thinking mainly of Florida, Boston, and
>Balitmore here.) then I can confidently say that there aren't any less people
>getting "fucked up" in that scene than in ours.

That's true, I want to know why we are getting picked on... "E" its so 
scary...OOOOHHH... it makes you want to hug people...Dangerous!

>  (And many didn't even do THAT, they were quite happy to socialize with
>someone who was high, they'd just stay sober themselves), and make them be 
>more
>discrete.

That's the kind I was... and what I was hoping for when I wished for 
"straight edge ravers" our scene has more than a few people who do this... 
bless them.


>(Now, there WERE the occasional entirely-straight-edger shows, where you just
>did NOT show up non-sober, but those were the exception.  And I don't think we
>want any poor kid getting a boot party because he took a pill at the wrong
>partie.)

Have you met "Giggles"? You know somebody is out of control when they scare 
SCOOBY!


>Though I've mostly stuck with punk & ska, when I was younger, and raveing, 
>now,
>I've bounced in and out of the scenes surrounding a good dozen genres of 
>music.
>  Reggae didn't turn me into a stoner, punk didn't turn me into a tweaker,
>raving didn't turn me into an e-tard, and grunge CERTIANLY did not turn me 
>into
>a heroin junkie.

Dude...I know you. If anybody is a role model for "responsible" drug use 
it's you. If everybody took a page from your book, we wouldn't have 
problems with drugs any worse than tripping over spent nitrous shells :)


>Though the drugs of choice, and the places it's acceptable to do them, might
>vary from scene to scene, it's been my observation that there are people who
>will:
>
>1) Never do any drug (either EVER, or ANYMORE)
>2) People who experiment, but don't really use
>3) People who will use occasionally and casually
>and
>4) People who will get fucked up as often as possible and screw up their lives

group 4 is the kind I worry about, if it's not illegal drugs it's legal 
ones, or an eating disorder, or cutting, I think If our society spent less 
time and effort trying to prohibit 1,2,3 from getting drugs, and more time 
and effort helping group 4, before they get to that point, we would be in a 
lot better shape.


>... And you'll find ALL four, in EVERY scene, and by and large, the choice of
>music will not affect the fact that all four are present.  About the ONLY
>differences that I've noticed in rave scene are, the drugs of choice, and that
>users are not ostracized, and they can be non-sober openly, instead of hideing
>it as in some others.
>
>
>cya,

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

All I would like to say is Melissa aka grooveprincess311@yahoo.com you are 
and I just want to tell you that I love you and this is my Love Poem to 
hopefully get you back into my arms again. Please i am cry in tears for you 
to come back 

(THIS IS MY LOVE POEM THE THE GIRL I AM WILLING TO SPEND THE REST OF MY LIFE 
WITH)

Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me forever. Love me when 
I wake up to you on my side. 
Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me forever. Love me when 
we kiss. 
Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me forever. Love me when 
I pick you up off the fool and spin you in circles. Love me now or love me 
never but if you love me love me forever. When we fight and have a bad day. 
Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me forever. When I am 
there for you to cry to and when I am here to listen about your life. 
Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me forever. When I ask 
you to be my girl till the end of time. 
Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me forever. 
I love you Melissa. Please love me now and forever.

--part1_ba.3dfd4430.2bea15b6_boundary--

Subject: [sfraves] The Declaration of IndepenDANCE

    "All men are created equal and there are certain unalienable rights that 
governments should never violate. These rights include the right to life, 
liberty and the pursuit of happiness. When a government fails to protect 
those rights, it is not only the right, but also the duty of the people to 
overthrow that government. In its place, the people should establish a 
government that is designed to protect those rights. Governments are rarely 
overthrown, and should not be overthrown for trivial reasons. In this case, a 
long history of abuses has led the colonists to overthrow a tyrannical 
government." - Thomas Jefferson

    Respectively, things may seem trivial so far, but I think we can count 
this recent scandal as strike one...

Date: Wed, 07 May 2003 07:11:04 -0400
From: Deepfog <sfraves@deepfog.com>

MIME-version: 1.0

Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
User-Agent: Microsoft-Entourage/10.0.0.1309
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Wed)

They had a great thread going on yesterday on the DCRaves list about a club
that has a dress code, when the website said something about it being for
people dressing the way they want.  I guess they meant you can wear what you
want, as long as it's not around them.  Tuck that shirt in, Osby, or you'll
get no candy today!

I think that thread brought an interesting point to light in my mind ... the
rave scene originally wasn't necessarily about going to a drug party with
music.  I think people do that at normal clubs all the time, despite all the
hype and security, and always have.  It was more about getting away from
clubs that had strict dress codes and always managed what the DJ would play
tonight instead of letting it be more free-flowing all the way around.  What
do you think?  

Anyway, thanks to cypha on the DCRaves list for his funny signature at the
end of his message, which was funny too.


-- 
"You mess with the bull, you get the horns"
- Principal Dick Vernon

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: cross-posting considered harmful

Hey folks,

I don't mean to sound like a curmudgeon here, but if you're going to
cross-post messages to multiple lists, or send the same message to a
group of friends, please use the Bcc field. Not only is cross-posting a
pain in the ass for list admins to deal with, but exposing your friends'
addresses to public mailing lists isn't really a great idea, either.
Thanks for your cooperation.

User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Love Poem To Melissa (in perl)

quoth Rayn:
> Can someone write a conditional perl script for this poem?  I don't
> know perl or I'd do it... I think its appropriate in this case ;)

It's more iterative than conditional, really...

#!/usr/bin/perl -w
# vim:et sts=4 sw=4 cindent:

use strict;

my $who = 'Melissa';
my $term = 'forever';
my $refrain = sprintf('Love me now or love me never but if you love ' .
					  'me love me %s.',
                      $term);
my @whens = ('I wake up to you on my side', 'we kiss',
             'I pick you up off the fool and spin you in circles',
             'we fight and have a bad day',
             'I am there for you to cry to and when I am here to ' .
			 'listen about your life',
             'I ask you to be my girl till the end of time');

printf("Love Poem to \%s\n\n", $who);

foreach my $when (@whens) {
    print "$refrain\n";
    printf("Love me when \%s.\n", $when);
}

printf("I love you Melissa. Please love me now and \%s.\n", $term);

0; # or should the exit code be non-zero?

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Love Poem To Melissa *YOU KNWO WHO YOU ARE I LIVE
	YOU*

The poem to Melissa is nice. I was touched by it.

Remember this, your actions must speak louder than your words. What appeals
to her lies deep in yourself. Learn from your mistakes but do not live in
the past. Be honest with your feelings and thoughts. If you cannot do that,
then a relationship cannot exist until you do so.

If you love her, you must have the patience to allow her to adjust (to let
her go). Be yourself and work with your emotions through beautiful music and
beautiful people. Place a picture of Melissa in your car on the dash or
wedged up in the rear view mirror and look into her eyes while you listen to
beautiful music. You'll feel your heart and your spirit. Nothing can ever
touch that.

In time, you will heal and reach a higher purpose. Should Melissa give you
her spirit once again, you both will be stronger.

Good luck!

Best regards!

MODA
Eric Reynolds

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re:Love Poem To Melissa *YOU KNWO WHO YOU ARE I LIVE YOU*

I don't know Melissa, and I'm sure she had her faults. But I'll bet that you 
were probably being an ass that's why she left you. Rarely do women just 
pick up and leave because they want to hurt their loving, caring boyfriends. 
It happens, but it's not usual. More often than not, the dude brought it 
upon himself.  Try to see how you can improve yourself so your next 
girlfriend won't have to deal with your crap.  Also getting on a rave list 
with this snivelling mess of a poem, hoping that she'll come running back to 
you, is a big mistake, and it makes you look to her like a whimpering 
pitiful piece of dung.  Instead of wanting to come back to you, she's 
probably thinking "oh my god get me away from this clingy, suffocating 
wretch." Your best chance to get her back is to run in the opposite 
direction. Give her space, and work on being an emotionally strong man any 
woman would respect and esteem. As a matter of fact, FORGET ABOUT HER!  Get 
on with your life. You've got some work to do. Harsh words, I know. But I'm 
not trying to make it sound pretty to you or even being mean. The quicker 
you can come to terms with the stark reality, the quicker you can get on 
with the business of self improvement.  Take a long hard look at yourself. 
It's not about Melissa at all. It's really about you.



-- Emperor

A man who has been felt deep pain





-- Emperor

"It is one of life's mysteries how an ounce of understanding, cleanses an 
ocean of mistrust and hate"
(The Outer Limits)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Love Poem To Melissa *YOU KNWO WHO YOU ARE I LIVE YOU*

#!/usr/bin/perl

$actions[0]="I wake up to you in my side.";
$actions[1]="we kiss.";
$actions[2]="I pick you up off the fool and spin you in circles.";
$actions[3]="we fight and have a bad day.";
$actions[4]="I am here to listen about your life.";

$psycho_quotient=rand;
$target="Melissa";
$loveme=1;
$forever=1;

foreach $action(@actions) {
	if ($loveme eq $forever) {
		print "Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me forever.\n";
		print "Love me when $action\n";
		}
	}
if ($psycho_quotient < .5) {
	print "I love you $target. Please love me now and forever\n";
	}
else {
	print "I love you $target. Dread Lord Lucifer demands your blood.\n";
	}

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Wed)

yea, thinking back to the very first parties i went to, i don't remember 
harder drugs being really prevalent, except a nitrous tank and people 
smoking out here and there. the way people dressed was way varied too... 
you had people from lots of different scenes, all colors, all freaks, 
converging in one place and it was truly diverse... it might have been 
looked at by some people as an alternative to going to a club... then 
again i was maybe 15 at the time and there was only one club i could get 
into at that age anyway. i wouldn't have been able to make the comparison.

after maybe a year or so that began to change, and you'd have tons of 
people tripping at a given event... that was widespread for a long time, 
before e really made its way to the midwest...

-joshua



Deepfog wrote:

>They had a great thread going on yesterday on the DCRaves list about a club
>that has a dress code, when the website said something about it being for
>people dressing the way they want.  I guess they meant you can wear what you
>want, as long as it's not around them.  Tuck that shirt in, Osby, or you'll
>get no candy today!
>
>I think that thread brought an interesting point to light in my mind ... the
>rave scene originally wasn't necessarily about going to a drug party with
>music.  I think people do that at normal clubs all the time, despite all the
>hype and security, and always have.  It was more about getting away from
>clubs that had strict dress codes and always managed what the DJ would play
>tonight instead of letting it be more free-flowing all the way around.  What
>do you think?  
>
>Anyway, thanks to cypha on the DCRaves list for his funny signature at the
>end of his message, which was funny too.
>
>

Yeah, I went for years and didn't even know E existed until that 20/20
report, then it was everywhere.  But I miss my desert parties :(  I went
to 99% of my parties completely sober as to not become a stat because it

-----Original Message-----
From: enemy_skies [mailto:enemy_skies@nodeOne.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, May 07, 2003 12:55 PM
To: Deepfog; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Wed)


yea, thinking back to the very first parties i went to, i don't remember

harder drugs being really prevalent, except a nitrous tank and people 
smoking out here and there. the way people dressed was way varied too...

you had people from lots of different scenes, all colors, all freaks, 
converging in one place and it was truly diverse... it might have been 
looked at by some people as an alternative to going to a club... then 
again i was maybe 15 at the time and there was only one club i could get

into at that age anyway. i wouldn't have been able to make the
comparison.

after maybe a year or so that began to change, and you'd have tons of 
people tripping at a given event... that was widespread for a long time,

before e really made its way to the midwest...

-joshua



Deepfog wrote:

>They had a great thread going on yesterday on the DCRaves list about a 
>club that has a dress code, when the website said something about it 
>being for people dressing the way they want.  I guess they meant you 
>can wear what you want, as long as it's not around them.  Tuck that 
>shirt in, Osby, or you'll get no candy today!
>
>I think that thread brought an interesting point to light in my mind 
>... the rave scene originally wasn't necessarily about going to a drug 
>party with music.  I think people do that at normal clubs all the time,

>despite all the hype and security, and always have.  It was more about 
>getting away from clubs that had strict dress codes and always managed 
>what the DJ would play tonight instead of letting it be more 
>free-flowing all the way around.  What do you think?
>
>Anyway, thanks to cypha on the DCRaves list for his funny signature at 
>the end of his message, which was funny too.
>

> #!/usr/bin/perl
>
> $actions[0]="I wake up to you in my side.";
> $actions[1]="we kiss.";
> $actions[2]="I pick you up off the fool and spin you in circles.";
> $actions[3]="we fight and have a bad day.";
> $actions[4]="I am here to listen about your life.";
>
> $psycho_quotient=rand;
> $target="Melissa";
> $loveme=1;
> $forever=1;
>
> foreach $action(@actions) {
> if ($loveme eq $forever) {
> print "Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me
forever.\n";
> print "Love me when $action\n";
> }
> }
> if ($psycho_quotient < .5) {
> print "I love you $target. Please love me now and forever\n";
> }
> else {
> print "I love you $target. Dread Lord Lucifer demands your blood.\n";
> }
>
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Dude Ranch Duds for Cowboy clubbing

Well howdy folks,
I was invited to a party this weekend, a small club-ish affair, but the theme is
cowboy attire.

I'm from Texas, y'all, but I don't have any western wear. Now I am getting some
ideas about apparel.

Some of those western shirts are nice, but they look kind of hot/sweaty, esp. if
you are dancing.

And how about those cowboy boots? Can you actually dance in them? I get tired of
my Nikes coming untied; maybe boots are the answer! LOL...

I don't think a cowboy hat would be too comfortable while raving/clubbing, but
maybe I am wrong about that, too. I'm just afraid it would go flying off my head
when I am getting groovy.

Anyway, I was just looking for some feedback on "Texas attire" or cowboy
get-ups.  Where can a guy go to get some "dude ranch" duds? I want to look the
part for the cowboy theme party, but not sure about spending all of the
hard-earned bucks.

Then again, I could re-invent myself during the shopping process. And y'all
could just call me "cowboy Tex." Lookout line dancing, here I come! I am just
feeling ironic because I moved here and now the "western theme" follows me.

And I'm kind of feeling like getting in the mood of the party; it's fun to
"Dress up" sometimes.
Gregory VP

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] hooray for sage! (new mix-cd out 5/20 :)





your grrl sage was just named resident of Sonar, a great baltimore club=

owned by dj's lonnie fisher (ultraworld) and lovegrove (sonic soul)!  w=
e're
stoked!  =3D)

here's some interesting info off a press release about Sage, and a
tracklisting for her new mix-cd below ...

Sage's recent troubles and triumphs are revealed in her new mix CD due =
out
May 20th 2003, entitled Drum & Bass Elements 01. Mixed by Sage on Moons=
hine
Recordings. Through her extreme dedication and love of Drum and Bass sh=
e
was
able to handle her father's long illness and passing while keeping her
career moving forward. "This has been the most difficult few years of m=
y
life. I just feel grateful for all the support I=B9ve gotten. I come fr=
om a
huge Irish family and honestly every single one of them would cut off t=
heir
right arm for ya! Looking back, the amount of help I've received from
colleagues in the dance music industry as well as from fans is
overwhelming.
I can=B9t help but to feel very fortunate."

Perhaps it was her musical training or just innate ability, but it was
apparent from the start that Sage's musical sensibilities made her an
exceptional DJ. Noel and UFO!, as founders of the well known DJ collect=
ive
'Phunckateck', immediately recognized her skills and invited her to be =
part
of their crew.

Sage started her musical endeavors at the age of 4 in her native Kansas=
,
with the piano. Her love of music and her talent soon had her graduatin=
g to
the violin at the age of 6. Drums later became her instrument of choice=
 as
she began playing in punk bands during her pre-teen and teen years in
Ireland. Having worked in record stores, played in jazz and indie rock
bands, she has always had an appreciation for all musical genres. From
Choir
to Music College that she attended on scholarship, it was seemingly
pre-destined that Sage would choose a career in music.

Still in touch with her roots, she is currently working on an indie roc=
k
band project called Meathe with fellow well-respected techno DJ/produce=
r
John Tejada, which provides her an outlet for drumming and singing as w=
ell
as playing guitar and bass on occasion.

Besides being a DJ and producer, she currently runs her own record labe=
l.
Phylum Recordings (one of the world's only all female owned record labe=
ls)
with partners Elektra and Susie Lee. With a well-received mixed CD unde=
r
her
belt entitled Stateside Sessions, Volume One, Mixed by Sage, and two ve=
ry
successful singles on Phylum, Sage continues to receive accolades from
peers
and fans alike.

Since 1997, Sage has been closely connected with the skateboard communi=
ty.
In 1999 she was approached by the world's largest skate shoe company DC=

Shoes and asked to join their team of DJ's. Since then, they've feature=
d
her
in 2 ads, and she has modeled for them in their catalogue. She carries =
the
DC logo everywhere she goes as DC's one and only female representative.=


This upcoming year will see Sage touring extensively around the US and
Canada to promote her new mix CD, hitting some of the towns where she
crashed with friends and fans on her long trips to and from Ireland.

Alongside DJ's Irene and Mea, she has been asked to participate in a
documentary due out in the Fall/Autumn 2003. World Party and Moonshine
Movie's "Three Chicks and A Bag of Tunes" will outline the day in the l=
ife
of all 3 women as working DJ's in the electronic music scene.

Press, peers and sponsors all love Sage, see what they say below:


"(Sage is) one of the hardest working DJ's in the scene, it's a true
testament to her character how she can travel, DJ, produce, mode, and s=
till
come off as one of the most genuine and truly inspirational performers
around. With that the best is yet to come for America's first lady of d=
rum
&
bass. Watch out!"


                                                            - Chris Mun=
iz
                                                            (Urb, XLR8R=
,
                                                            Knowledge, =
DJ
                                                            Times)


'She has this charisma about her. Laura is easily one of the best in th=
e
drum n bass field, she rips. She's out spinning, so we're supporting a
woman
who doesn't just model out clothes and we get to work with someone who'=
s
cool as f--k."


                                                            - DC Vice
                                                            President D=
amon
                                                            Way


"There's an element about her that people really like, and are attracte=
d
to.
I met Laura years ago at a small party in San Francisco. She has great
charisma, and an amazing sense of style. That charisma shines best when=

Sage
is behind the decks and working a club, blending hard and heavy drum 'n=
'
bass bangers together to bring the energy to a fever pitch. Her taste i=
n
music is eclectic and discriminate, and her mixing conveys dynamic
precision."
                                       Dieselboy

raving/clubbing, but

my head
when I am getting groovy.

Anyway, I was just looking for some feedback on "Texas attire" or cowboy
get-ups.  Where can a guy go to get some "dude ranch" duds? I want to
look the
part for the cowboy theme party, but not sure about spending all of the
hard-earned bucks.

Then again, I could re-invent myself during the shopping process. And
y'all
could just call me "cowboy Tex." Lookout line dancing, here I come! I am
just
feeling ironic because I moved here and now the "western theme" follows
me.

And I'm kind of feeling like getting in the mood of the party; it's fun
to
"Dress up" sometimes.
Gregory VP

> They had a great thread going on yesterday on the DCRaves list about a
club

> people dressing the way they want.  I guess they meant you can wear what
you
> want, as long as it's not around them.  Tuck that shirt in, Osby, or
you'll
> get no candy today!
>
> I think that thread brought an interesting point to light in my mind ...
the
> rave scene originally wasn't necessarily about going to a drug party with
> music.  I think people do that at normal clubs all the time, despite all
the
> hype and security, and always have.  It was more about getting away from
> clubs that had strict dress codes and always managed what the DJ would
play
> tonight instead of letting it be more free-flowing all the way around.
What
> do you think?

if you want to feel safe in the world, then you can relax once you learn that tons of people wear uniforms to let you know sort of what they are like and what they are associated with, so you can pick and choose your every movement with ease...for example, people who aggressively loiter in front of stores and public bus and train stations sort of look similar in dress, and after a while, you will be able to recognize an aggresive, potentially angry person who means you harm to just your regular passerby...another example is the strategic use of eyebrow highlighter by people like myself...kind of pretty in the right light, also, sort of slutty in an ambush sort of way. :)

there's also genuine cowboy stores, that sell all cowboy stuff.  there's 
one in Chico, but I'm not sure where they'd be in the bay.

a well fitting cowboy hat won't come off your head while you're dancing, 
but don't expect a nicely made hat to be cheap.. in fact, a lot of cowboy 
stuff is made out of leather, which isn't nearly as cheap as cotton or 
synthetics.


sarilion

ps I'm a repressed cowboy

You know the funny thing is a couple of years ago I would actually go to
parties every now and again in dark blue jeans, a cowboy hat, my hair in
ringlets and a pink sequined tube top..sort of a rhinestone cowgirl if you
will...lol It was fun mainly because people would freak out and think you
were a total weirdo for wearing such a thing. I guess I liked to stand
out..kind of like when I would dress up in hot pink and roller skates for a
goth event my friend threw ;)

Jennifer

From: Sarilion [mailto:sarilion@sarilion.org]
Sent: Wednesday, May 07, 2003 6:09 PM

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Dude Ranch Duds for Cowboy clubbing


there's also genuine cowboy stores, that sell all cowboy stuff.  there's
one in Chico, but I'm not sure where they'd be in the bay.

a well fitting cowboy hat won't come off your head while you're dancing,
but don't expect a nicely made hat to be cheap.. in fact, a lot of cowboy
stuff is made out of leather, which isn't nearly as cheap as cotton or
synthetics.


sarilion

ps I'm a repressed cowboy

UNDER THE RADAR DJ Night at Julip
http://www.julipsf.com/
839 Geary Street ( between Larkin and Hyde )
9:30pm - Close
no admission

Sounds from a Pretty World: Zygote and Friends serve up Plunder Jazz, 
Abstract Weird-Tempo and Experimental Pop Musique with an electro twist. 
Come early, as the night is usually packed out with super models and jet 
setters of the IDM world........

SPECIAL GUEST May 7th, DJ "Clarity""
VISUALS by: Killamac (freebeats collective)

Clarity began spinning in the North Bay at the age of 19. Realizing her true 
love for techno in 1998 she quickly swept across rave scene dropping as hard 
and heavy as she could get away with. Playing at parties like Harmony, 
Children of the Sun, Happy Kids, and Flower Shop she definitely had wide 
variety of music lovers surrounding her and with the support of many of 
those promoters she was able to play out at a lot of parties before having 
any DJ recordings out. With a high demand for trance and house, being a 
techno DJ in the community was a challenge.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
under the radar // thank you // http://utr.praemedia.com/

just awful. I'm also compared to some kind of

that doesn't even make sense. I'm sorry, you guys are
just gonna have to chill. don't chill with me, don't

out. I call CF communist, you respond with
descriptions of sex with Stalin?

Stalin's dead, dude. either you can't tell the
difference between a communist organization and a
homosexual necrophiliac communist organization, or

Crunch in a Russian uniform. either way, I think this
is too much.

said that I too have had some of the best times of my
life at CF events. and saying ppl lost their way is
not such a dramatic criticism, really. losing your way
is something that happens to good and bad alike.

apologies for any hurt feelings.

How about some basic too...hehe..
*ahem - cracks knuckes*

10 a$ = "Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me forever. "
20 b$ = "Love me when "
30 c$ = "When"
40 PRINT a$, b$, "I wake up to you on my side."
50 PRINT a$, b$, "we kiss."
60 PRINT a$, b$, "I pick you up off the fool and spin you in circles."
70 PRINT a$, c$, "we fight and have a bad day."
80 PRINT a$, c$, "I am there for you to cry to and when I am here to listen
about your life."
90 PRINT a$, c$, "I ask you to be my girl till the end of time."
100 PRINT a$, "I love you Melissa. Please love me now and forever."
110 beep
120 PRINT "To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org"
130 beep
140 end

> How about some basic too...hehe..
> *ahem - cracks knuckes*
>
> 10 a$ = "Love me now or love me never but if you love me love me forever.
"
> 20 b$ = "Love me when "
> 30 c$ = "When"
> 40 PRINT a$, b$, "I wake up to you on my side."
> 50 PRINT a$, b$, "we kiss."
> 60 PRINT a$, b$, "I pick you up off the fool and spin you in circles."
> 70 PRINT a$, c$, "we fight and have a bad day."
> 80 PRINT a$, c$, "I am there for you to cry to and when I am here to
listen
> about your life."
> 90 PRINT a$, c$, "I ask you to be my girl till the end of time."
> 100 PRINT a$, "I love you Melissa. Please love me now and forever."
> 110 beep
> 120 PRINT "To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org"
> 130 beep
> 140 end
>
>
> - Charlie
> charlie@ravepictures.net
> [www.ravepictures.net]

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DJ Science on An Epiphany Of Sound

Howdy all,
I'd like to welcome you all to listen in to An Epiphany Of Sound today
as we bring you the stylings of DJ Science.  He's sure to serve up some
tasty 2-step and breaks today, and maybe drop some of the music he's
been working on himself.  We do it during the normal timeslot, 9a-noon
today.  Do tune in, 90.1 FM in the bay area, or
http://kzsulive.stanford.edu online.

If you're interested in getting into your favorite club for free, I've
got giveaways for 6 different club events this weekend ranging from
booty shaking house events to butt kicking tech-style events.

Talk to you!

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 89308 invoked from network); 8 May 2003 16:04:51 -0000
Message-ID: <20030508160450.82660.qmail@web41009.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 8 May 2003 09:04:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jessica McMahan <ceridwen_ruad@yahoo.com>
To: Moksha Tribe <moksha_tribe@yahoogroups.com>,
  SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>, EGP <evil_glowstick_people@yahoogroups.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Friendster Happy Hour & Elastiq

So where were all y'alls lazy asses last night?? ;) 

Zack and I drove all the way to the city to go to the Friendster
"meet-up" and well, out of the 5 people that showed up (we arrived
around 7:30), I knew them all (since we planned on meeting there). Not
even a DJ showed up! I had a blast, tho!!! That bar was hella cute!
Looked like a cave near the back and was a total hole-in-the-wall. The
bartender was awesome. Tequila stories, free drinks, even my first SF
shooting! 

Yes, everyone, someone was shot 5 times right at the corner of 6th &
Market last night. And we got to witness all the craziness. A wonderful
beginning to a fun night...

I got rightly trashed on tequila shots (bartender thought I was very
brave *hehe*), loaded up the friends and went to Il Pirata for some
Justin Hale and AndyW goodness. I met more people at this place then
the Friendster meet-up... Mmm Peyton. 

And I got to talk codshit all night! LOL

So... went home and ended up sleeping in an hour past my alarm. Luckily
I made it to the BART just in time for the next train that would still
get me to work on time. I am SOOOOO hungover. Luckily, the others in
the office understand and we're taking it easy today. I'm still
lightheaded & fuzzy. Hell, I was still drunk when I woke up.

Happy Thursday everyone!!! The weekend begins... At least for me.
Jessica

PS - and Ryan... where were you?? You're the one who announced this
thing... slacker. ;)

=====

NO CROSSPOSTING.

bad bad bad... 3 different groups in one email. There's this thing called
*bcc* BCC those lists. Crossposting creates problems for list admins and
returns junk mail to people like me saying *bla bla bla you're not sub'd to
this wank off list bla bla bla* >:(

Subject: [sfraves] Re-run BSP Good Morning

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

GOOD MORNING FROM PORTLAND, OR      

 

What a day for house music. What a day for deciding to book a deep house
dj who can and will work your crowd. Why you ask should I book this
person there is plenty of good talent around. This is why, because I am
a kind hearted soul who enjoys walks on the beach and throbbing sound
systems. I do not have a self inflating ego I prefer to just enjoy the
beats and dance my poor white man dance. Another good reason is this no
travel costs. I am going to be in your area in about 2 months and just
need bookings with a small fee to go get my fix of vinyl from your local
shops. If you need to hear the beats here they are please do take the
time to listen as I have taken the time wait patiently while the mix
uploaded. To listen click the following link or paste it into your
browser. Http://www.flavoredclubbing.com/strawberry/ohmix2.ram 

 

 

 

 

 

If after all this you are reading and smiling but you are not a promoter
please take the time to pass on my mix or name to your favorite
promoter. 

 

 

 

Now for a little about me. I am originally from Tucson AZ where I was
initiated into the rave scene in 1992 and then continued to party and be
stupid until 1995 when I got my first turntables. Living in the middle
of nowhere forced me to teach myself all that I know. In 1997 I moved to
the Bay Area and from there continued to the great NW. I now call
Portland my home and will continue to do so until I am lured to another
city with a promise of a better life for me. So please take the time to
think would you like a dj from Portland on your flyer? Would you like a
dj who can work a crowd? Would you like this dj for only small fees and
no travel costs? Well would you? Now quick hit the reply button and let
me know your dates and I will send you a contract and then when I get
the notarized contract back I will mark my calendar and see you on that
date. Pretty simple so what's stopping you? Oh yeah it is me stopping
you because I am still typing.....

 

Goodbye and remember Peace, Love, and Roller Skates

 

 

 

Jason Philips

OH Records

Problematic Beats

 


------=_NextPart_000_0009_01C31558.CC84DAB0--

> >you are dancing.
> >
> >And how about those cowboy boots? Can you actually
> dance in them? I get
> >tired of
> >my Nikes coming untied; maybe boots are the answer!
> LOL...
> >
> >I don't think a cowboy hat would be too comfortable
> while
> >raving/clubbing, but
> >maybe I am wrong about that, too. I'm just afraid
> it would go flying off
> >my head
> >when I am getting groovy.
> >
> >Anyway, I was just looking for some feedback on
> "Texas attire" or cowboy
> >get-ups.  Where can a guy go to get some "dude
> ranch" duds? I want to
> >look the
> >part for the cowboy theme party, but not sure about
> spending all of the
> >hard-earned bucks.
> >
> >Then again, I could re-invent myself during the
> shopping process. And
> >y'all
> >could just call me "cowboy Tex." Lookout line
> dancing, here I come! I am
> >just
> >feeling ironic because I moved here and now the
> "western theme" follows
> >me.
> >

From: JBlaze112@aol.com

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, sacraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: AOL 5.0 for Windows sub 103
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Track Listing?

This disco house type song starts out with a filter effect, you know that 
muffled sound like you are hearing the music from the parking lot before you 
get to the party? and then it oh so slowly but gracefully smoothly clears up 
into a deep throbing funky disco house beat. and the lyrics just say 
something like "Live your life... be freeeee"  "be, freee"  "be, free"  and I 
believe those are the only lyrics to the song. the lyrics sound all sparkly 
too, like they are coming from the sky or something it's a fucking dope song. 
They play it for about a minute or two on the radio sometimes. The party 
station lol   Somebody tell me who this is by and what's the name of the 
track so i can find it!
    Also there's another song i'm looking for which has the "Rock the casbah" 
beat in the back ground but it's been totally remixed all housy and with new 
lyrics. This song I MUST find as well.

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Stop Media Monopoly

--=====================_12179883==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

On June 2, the Federal Communications Commission is planning on
authorizing sweeping changes to the American news media.  The rules
change could allow your local TV stations, newspaper, radio stations,
and cable provider to all be owned by one company.  NBC, ABC, CBS and
Fox could have the same corporate parent.  The resulting concentration
of ownership could be deeply destructive to our democracy.

Congress is supposed to guard against monopoly power.  But the
upcoming rule change could change the landscape for all media and
usher in an era in which a few corporations control your access to
news and entertainment.  Please join me in asking Congress and the
FCC to support a diverse, competitive media landscape by going to:

http://www.moveon.org/stopthefcc/

You can also automatically have your comments publicly filed at the
FCC.

When the folks at MoveOn.org talk to Congresspeople about this issue,
the response is usually the same: "We only hear from media lobbyists on
this.  It seems like my constituents aren't very concerned with this
issue."  A few thousand emails could permanently change that perception.
Please join this critical campaign, and let Congress know you care.

Thanks.


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

remix.

called House the Casbah, on a white label identifying itself as "JF" (I
think I saw this one at Tweekin the other day, actually). Another one,
released early last year, was by House of Crash, IIRC. I'm sure there
are others...

Subject: [sfraves] sound factory ruling





fyi, from roar! listserv:

http://www.nylawyer.com/news/03/05/050703e.html

News Watch
Manhattan Judge Orders Club
To Have Drug-Sniffing Dog


New York Lawyer
May 7, 2003

A Manhattan Supreme Court justice who earlier this year allowed a Hell's
Kitchen nightclub to reopen two weeks after she ordered it closed, last
week ruled the club must have a drug-sniffing dog at its entrance to remain
open, the New York Law Journal reports.

Justice Emily Jane Goodman initially closed the Sound Factory on West 46th
Street in February after the city filed an ex parte application claiming
that designer drugs such as Ecstasy and Special K had been sold at the
club.
She allowed it to reopen two weeks later because adequate steps were taken
to prevent drug dealing.

In her latest order, Justice Goodman specified 19 measures the club must
take to stay open, including posting security personnel in the bathrooms.
She also ordered the police to respond to any complaints that drugs were
being used in or near the club.


Eric
RPM : ROAR : DCNC
www.rpmonline.org
www.roargroup.org
www.dcnc.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] uniforms and highlighter enlightenment nrr

I think it's when some dude is just hanging out somewhere and decides 
to harass every pretty girl that walks by. Being a guy, I never 
experience this. But then it dawned on me about two years ago that 
females live in a very different world. They get harrassed about a 
thousand times as much than your average guy because there are just 
some ungentelmanly men out there that just believe they can say or do 
whatever they want to any woman they please. But they'll NEVER do it 
when a man accompanies them.

I've walked miles upon miles of crowded city without any stranger 
ever saying as much as a word to me. But many women, especially 
comely ones, get harrassed about every ten feet!

I'm not saying women are weak and can't handle it. On they contrary 
they, are often tougher then men because this type of shit happens 
every day and most guys are just blind to it because it doesn't 
happen to them.

Empathize,

BS

Subject: [sfraves] ***ANNOUNCEMENT OF CHANGE OF EVENT DATE!!!***

--0-835552519-1052497921=:27561
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
Monday, May 9, 2003
Washington, D.C. 

ROAR! : The National Dance and Music Rights Alliance
***Voted Organizer of Most Groundbreaking Event of 2002 by URB 
Magazine***
POWER TO THE PEOPLE! PARTY FOR THE PEOPLE!

Legba Carrefour, Press Liaison 
(202) 546-2128
info@roargroup.org
http://www.roargroup.org
mailing list: join@roargroup.org 

ANNOUNCEMENT OF CHANGE OF EVENT DATE!!!

Dear Friends of Electronic Music and Civil Liberties:

With the recent signing of the RAVE Act on April 30th, the resistance 
to 
government attacks on electronic music is gearing up to fight back. 
ROAR! has 
determined that the situation calls for extreme measures.  Formerly, we 
had 
announced a protest for June 13 to display our dissent with the 
repressive and 
ill-conceived law.  We now see a need for an even larger event is to 
bring the 
attention of the public to this law and the consequences to the 
industry and 
civil liberties. In an effort to make our drive to have the RAVE Act 
repealed 
we are rescheduling ROAR!s second ever and even bigger event to late 
summer.  
Event details, including date and lineup, will be announced by the end 
of May.

Expect a bigger, louder event to communicate just how important this 
issue is 
for us. With your help, thousands will descend on Washington, D.C. to 
the 
National Mall for a massive party-as-protest.  On a day of dancing, 
music, 
speeches, art and outreach, ROAR! will spotlight some of the 
world-renowned 
artists that make electronic music so important and politically 
influential 
speakers who can bring our struggle to a national audience.  Together 
we can 
stop the war on dance music culture and community. 

You can help! ROAR! needs people to join its mailing list, help with 
national 
promotions, spread the word and donate. Visit our website for more 
information.

Also, on May 31, expect a mass national day of action, with public 
protests 
taking place in major cities all over the country.  Display anger at 
attacks on 
your civil liberties by protesting in your own backyard.  Expect event 
information soon!

--

ROAR! is a national organization dedicated to fighting government 
threats to 
the electronic music industry and community. With a history of 
successful, high-
visibility media events, ROAR! educates the public and influences the 
course of 
national legislation with the goal of advancing the freedom to gather, 
dance, 
listen to, perform and promote music in a public setting. We 
seek to preserve both the livelihood of all those associated with the 
electronic music industry and the vibrant culture of those who 
participate, as 
well as civil liberties for all Americans.

For updates on ROAR!, the anti-RAVE Act movement and our summer 
party-as-
protest, look to our website (http://www.roargroup.org) or join our 
mailing 
list (join@roargroup.org).


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
http://www.roargroup.org

---------------------------------

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: SECRET SERVICE JAMS UP OAKLAND HS STUDENTS

--=====================_1767812==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

SECRET SERVICE JAMS UP OAKLAND HS STUDENTS
by JR


"(The Secret Service agent) asked me if I knew my rights, and I said
no.  Then he said that I'm not going to even tell you your rights
because of what you said.  .  That was a threat to the government.  I
ain't going to tell you shit because you are owned by us now, you're
owned by the government.  If you lie or do whatever, I'm going to take
you to federal prison and you're just going to be sitting there and
your parents won't know about it," said one of two 16-year-old
Southeast Asian Oakland High School students who were interrogated by
the Secret Service on April 22.

The students' names aren't being used because they did not want to be
identified.  "He asked us questions like was I a good shooter .  was I
a good sniper .  am I good dealing with guns, and what are my thoughts
on the president.  I was in shock and fear.  It was only me, the
principal, Mr. Mok, and two agents."

The Secret Service agents had the students pulled out of class without
parental knowledge or consent and interrogated them in a school
conference room.

"Apparently there was a discussion going on about the war, and many of
the students were expressing some criticism of Bush and the
administration.  And the fact that thousands of people have been
killed in Iraq and things like that.  In the course of this, some
students made some comments (like) well, maybe he should be sniped or
taken out, or something like that.  And another student said Bush is
wack or something like that," said Oakland High School teacher Larry
Felson.

"The teacher was apparently upset about what had been said and the
next day decided to call the police and ended up talking to the Secret
Service.  All we know is that the next day the Secret Service came in
and interrogated these students, each one of them for 45 minutes or an
hour or something like that."  The other student said, "I was very
scared.  I was crying because of what they said to us.  I was very
depressed at the time."

Police terrorism has been getting a lot of attention in the Bay Area
with cases like the murder of Idriss Stelley, an unarmed young Black
man who was shot over 20 times in downtown San Francisco's Metreon
Theater, to the Oakland police who call themselves the "Riders" in
West Oakland, one of whom fled the country while the other three are
facing charges of kidnapping, beating people, planting false evidence
and writing false police reports among other things, resulting in the
Oakland department having to shell out $10.9 million to 119 victims.
On Martin Luther King's birthday in 2002, the SFPD fondled teenage
girls in Hunters Point while holding their parents at gunpoint, and
they gave another youth a concussion and a fractured jaw when he
voiced concern about how his family was being treated.  On Oct.  11,
2002, the SFPD descended on Thurgood Marshall High in Hunters Point
with approximately 100 swat team members, ATF and sheriff's deputies
to break up a fight between four unarmed students, arresting 11
students and one teacher and terrorizing dozens in their classroom
hallways.

Since then, the OPD has run over the feet of high school students of
color who were protesting the war in their communities and the wars
overseas and arrested me and my comrade Rashida after they threw us to
the ground, terrorizing us, scraping Rashida's face on the concrete,
putting their knees on her neck and head and chipping her teeth.  We
also have to include what the OPD did to the Oakland dockworkers and
people who were protesting the war on the Oakland docks on April 7,
when they shot them in the face and body with wooden bullets, bean
bags with scrap metal in them and concussion grenades.

The Bay Area has long been a testing ground for police and law
enforcement terrorism.  Now they are stepping up their game, and the
Secret Service is bringing their terroristic activities that they use
in the streets of the nation to school campuses.  Oakland High just
happens to be the first in the Bay Area that we've heard about.  "We
are advocates for our children.  We're protectors of our youth, so if
anything goes down, we're supposed to be there supporting them 100
percent, and they should feel comfortable to raise anything," said
Oakland High teacher Cassie Lopez.

And she is right.  Education is supposed to be about us questioning
what's going on around us and dialoguing about the world that we live
in.

"The real reality is that we have a president, no matter what the
polls say, that is very unpopular, particularly unpopular in the East
Bay, where people have spoken out against him.  Many people think that
he is the international terrorist," said Oakland High teacher Larry
Felson.

"Many people think that he should be brought to trial and the rest of
these guys that run this closet government that's not really elected
by the people, and many of the students know that here.  So of course
there is a righteous anger about what the government is doing, and a
lot of people express themselves about it in the classroom.  And
that's why we think that what has happened here is an attempt to
suppress students, suppress teachers and create an atmosphere of
intimidation, and we need to stand up against this," continued Felson.
"It sounds like fascism to me, reaching a point where you don't have
the freedom of speech - you can't voice your opinion.  You aren't even
supposed to have an opinion, the way they're conducting business right
now.  I've always let my kids know that you have a right to have an
opinion about everything that goes on in this world, in your
community, in your neighborhood, in your home," said Lopez.

Mok, who has been the principal of Oakland High School since July 2002
and has been working in the Oakland Unified School District since
1990, said, "I am not sure what the School Board or the superintendent
are going to do.  I know that I talked to the superintendent about the
incident, but he didn't indicate to me exactly what his opinion was,
so I can't speak for him."

"I was following the instructions of the Secret Service.  .  Usually
the protocol is to not interfere with their investigations and just
follow instructions.  And that's what I was doing," Mok added.

Just think, is this the kind of person or the kind of school system
where you want to send your children daily, to be miseducated and
programmed not to think for themselves, like this principal?  Probably
not.  You can call Oakland Unified School District Superintendent
Dennis Chaconas at (510) 879-8200 or the Oakland Board of Education at
(510) 887-0152.  Email JR at fire@sfbayview.com


------------------------------------------


ADDITIONAL NOTES:


What makes the story even more troubling is the fact that when the
Secret Service was contacted by newspaper reporter Harrison Chastang
of KPOO Radio in SF, they admitted to interrogating the students, but
said the school may have overreacted by calling them...  They didn't
have to go that far up the ladder..  As an agency they have to respond
to any threat to the President, however, the school could've handled
the matter internally.  Why they didn't is still in question.  It's
not like the school has a zero tolerance policy..  The two students
were not suspended or expelled from school..  Nor do they have
criminal records, gang involvement or anything like that..  So what
was really going on?

All this takes place in the backdrop of several recent incidents
involving Bay Area folks..  One involves Michael Franti and members of
his group Spearhead.  We reported several issues back how Gov't agents
showed up at the doorstep of one of his band member's house and
interrogated the mother about the group's anti-war activities...  They
pulled out pictures of the band to indicate they have been following
them..and showed their financial records and basically attempted to
scare the daylights out the family...

The Franti incident came at the heels of the FBI paying a visit to a
well known Hip Hop activist named Kawal Ulandalay who works for an
organization called APAL and Filipinos For Affirmative Action.  He had
been organizing airport workers and screeners in the Bay Area, many
who were set to lose their jobs in the aftermath of 9-11.  He got a
visit from FBI agents at 2 in the morning who wanted to know if he was
a Muslim [He isn't] and if he loved this country...  Things are
getting hectic..

Also JR gets major props because he not only interviewed everyone
involved he also got them all on our KPFA Hard Knock Radio show the
other day.
==========================================


The FNV Hip Hop Newsletter c 2002


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: Re: [sfraves] uniforms and highlighter enlightenment nrr

when i was in my late teens/early twenties, i got my consciousness 
permanently raised in this regard...my girlfriend worked as the assistant 
manager of a "head shop" that was located in the gay neighborhood of 
Chicago; i was a slim, long-haired, femme-looking guy with a cute butt, and 
so i got a fair amount of attempted pick-up activity.  i'll grant you that 
gay pick-up lines are at least more tasteful than hetero ones ;o)  but the 
point was that after experiencing people trying to impose a sexual subtext 
on you, you become more aware of how that might feel to others.

--hb

>I think it's when some dude is just hanging out somewhere and decides to

>this.

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 30975 invoked by uid 1103); 9 May 2003 18:54:27 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
