Received: (qmail 30961 invoked from network); 9 May 2003 18:54:27 -0000
Date: Fri, 9 May 2003 11:54:24 -0700
From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@atari.saturn5.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20030509185424.GZ15585@atari.saturn5.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Looking for some good psytrance?



Listening to Ticon's new album, Aero... I am very impressed.  This is
the first trance album I have heard in a while to really excite me.

Good unqiue sounds and beats.  Driving trance tracks can take dubby
detours right in the middle of the track, and go back, without interrupting
the flow at all.  The whole album has more of a "fun" and "driving" instead
of "dark" quality.  Can totally see this as morning music in the best
possible meaning of that word.  Not to be confused with fluffy.  

Best part of this album is production.  One word: Immuculate.  This sound
quality on this album is what other artists should be striving for.  
These guys are pros.

find it online:  http://www.trancetrax.com (no affiliation with this company)

-troy


------------------------------------------------------------------------------
tsheets@saturn5.com                                  <- You have found me   
http://www.saturn5.com/tsheets/audio                 <- my .mp3 tracks
"I just don't have the discipline to be a hippie"    <- Homer J. Simpson

You know..... come to think of it, I've experienced this all of my life. When I was younger, I also had long hair and a cute butt (of course the only thing that has changed is, I cut my hair). Chuckle chuckle! Anyway, I've always gotten harassed by older, less attractive women. Usually the ones, if you could... in your wildest imagination want to, compliment them, you'd say something like......... "Nice Tooth".  Over the years, they've gotten downright rude and obsene.  The only good thing about this is though, (and I know it's the same for women, only they go for the credit cards and Mercedes') is that when I've bartendered, those are the women that tipped the best. Especially, If I flirted with them. Usually, they had the most money. (Of course, they got it from the guys.... when they were younger and had all of their teeth.) Well, I just had to throw my two cents worth in..... that's all I had was two cents. The good looking women got all of the rest!!! (Including the credit cards and the Mercedes) Woe is me..... I guess I'm just like every other poor schmuck that has hormones.  I do have to say in my defense though..... I treat everyone with respect, I have never... ever... cat-called or whistled at any woman (or man) .... ever. I think it's stupid, rude, and otherwise shows much disrespect for people in general and that includes pulling up to somebody's house and honking the horn for them to come out. If that were ever to happen to my daughter (and she knows it) by some guy.... he'd be wearing a body cast when I got done with him. After which I would be strongly lecturing his parents on appropriate child rearing behavior and, I'm the least violent guy you'll ever meet.  Peace out    Piper  

DJ Howlin' Bob <djhbomb999@hotmail.com> wrote:when i was in my late teens/early twenties, i got my consciousness 
permanently raised in this regard...my girlfriend worked as the assistant 
manager of a "head shop" that was located in the gay neighborhood of 
Chicago; i was a slim, long-haired, femme-looking guy with a cute butt, and 
so i got a fair amount of attempted pick-up activity. i'll grant you that 
gay pick-up lines are at least more tasteful than hetero ones ;o) but the 
point was that after experiencing people trying to impose a sexual subtext 
on you, you become more aware of how that might feel to others.

From sfraves-return-101992-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri May 09 21:32:24 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-101992-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 28145 invoked by uid 1103); 9 May 2003 21:32:22 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 28131 invoked from network); 9 May 2003 21:32:22 -0000
From: gregvp@attbi.com
To:  sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Fri, 09 May 2003 21:32:17 +0000
X-Mailer: AT&T Message Center Version 1 (May  7 2003)
X-Authenticated-Sender: Z3JlZ3ZwQGF0dGJpLmNvbQ==
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Can't hardly wait for outdoor seasonal parties

I was just thinking about how much I am looking forward to warmer weather and
the great outdoor parties that various people throw around here.

I have so many happy memories of my seasons here, although my arrival has only
been since October 2000. It is fun to dance under the sun because it is not
overly hot and humid, like Texas, where outdoor dance parties are rare (you must
have air conditioning in Houston to survive).

Every outdoor party has its own vibe just like indoor rave parties. Lake
Elizabeth was popular for one season, and Stafford Lake (Marin County) gets
used. Last year we had at least two crews choose the McLaren amphitheater in SF
and it was a great place to party.

There is even a different scene from sfraves, the Flagger community. In gay
social circles, these guys have parties in Dolores Park with trance music
(usually Gryder & Hughes as DJs) and they move to a different rhythm than
glowstick heaven by twirling around big, beautiful flags in time to the music. I
want to check out one of these parties, too. I hope they have them this year in
San Francisco.

Anyway, I am just getting excited about seeing old acquaintances under the
bright summer skies and meeting new people as well. 

See you in the park,
Gregory VP

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Liquidcafe.com celebrates the 5 year anniversary of the popular SUNDANCE 
park picnic summer series.  This summer we have an incredible lineup of 
talent you won't want to miss.

Presenting the season kick off we've all been waiting for over the past few 
months...


SUNDAY JUNE 8,  2003...

                                 SUNDANCE PARK PICNIC
                           :::::   Summer Series 2003   :::::
                          ** PART 1 the summer kick off **

COME AT NOON!!!

An Outstanding lineup with
Two Stages featuring 8 hours of music
For your listening pleasure...


// *HANSEL'S FOREST [Stage 1]


JONATHAN GREATHOUSE (San Francisco)
- Deep Sexy Grooves

DJ PAT (WUE, Fresno)
- Wetter and Harder

KENDRA FRENCH (Feelgood/Plush, Sac)
- Deep House

GAVIN VARITECH (Neverending, Sac)
- Tech-House

PAUL GORDON (Liquidcafe.com, Sac)
- special 70's disco set

HOTH (Sacramento)
- Deep Acid Trance

MENER (Sacramento)
- Bangin House & Old Skool rave vibe

TERENCE (Big Mama's House/S:one, Sac)
- deeper progressive house-ness



     ***

//  *HUMPTY'S BUNKER HILL  [Stage 2]



MIKEY J (Eklektic, Sac )
- Incessant pounding n thrashing

E.M.P. (Summit Sound, Sac)
Drum n Bass & Dancehall riddims


JIMMY ZIMMS (Naughty Vibez/Infected Logic, Sac)
- High Octane acid breaks

DR_XENO (Walnut Creek)
- Funky breaks

JASON WHO (Naughty Vibes, Sac)
- Funky breaks



*Line up subject to change



========

Infoline: 916.466.9113/415.303.7404
Online: www.liquidcafe.com/events.html

ADMISSION: Free, zip, zippo, zilch.


**This is a narcotics-free, all ages family event held in a public park, 
carry yourselves accordingly.

----------------------
IMPORTANT
----------------------
The Park prohibits bottles. Bring disposable cups!!!



------ snip and save the following -----------

WHAT TO BRING:

DISPOSABLE CUPS!
Blanket
folding chairs
Sunscreen
Food, portable BBQ grills, and/or snacks
Beverages
your parents
Your Kids
Lots of smiles and happy faces

WHAT NOT TO BRING:

Illegal substances
Bad attitudes
Troublemakers
Negative vibes
your grumpy mother-in-law;)
Worthless paraphenalia - masks, binkies, glowsticks on a string, etc
Anything that could ruin the party for everyone.

-------------- snip -------------------

Subject: [sfraves] (BSP,NRR) DETROIT - Sunday Night @Skylark

Greetings from "DETROIT"!

thank you all who attended last Sunday night's fantastic kick-off to our weekly toasting to the spirit of musical tradition and innovation that is Detroit. We are excited by the turn out and just how well the mix of music connected with the crowd for a really great vibe. This sunday we'll be hosting the second edition of "Detroit" with more garage rock, motown, techno, jazz, hip hop and electro funk, all mixed up with everything in between (Expect to hear a few prominent "influences" as well)!

The party starts at 9 this Sunday night, May 11, at the Skylark, 3089 16st., San Francisco. This weeks featured DJ's include Baby Daddy (Rob Goppold) and 12 Mile (Brian Stein).

thanks - The Woodward Posse

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Looking for some good psytrance?

i'd like to encourage ppl who like those kind of *fun* and *driving* qualities 
in goa to check out some of the nu-nrg being released these days. some of it

>===== Original Message From Troy Sheets <tsheets@atari.saturn5.com> =====
>Listening to Ticon's new album, Aero... I am very impressed.  This is
>the first trance album I have heard in a while to really excite me.
>
>Good unqiue sounds and beats.  Driving trance tracks can take dubby
>detours right in the middle of the track, and go back, without interrupting
>the flow at all.  The whole album has more of a "fun" and "driving" instead
>of "dark" quality.  Can totally see this as morning music in the best
>possible meaning of that word.  Not to be confused with fluffy.
>
>Best part of this album is production.  One word: Immuculate.  This sound
>quality on this album is what other artists should be striving for.
>These guys are pros.
>
>find it online:  http://www.trancetrax.com (no affiliation with this company)
>
>-troy

Alex <apot@uclink.berkeley.edu> wrote:i'd like to encourage ppl who like those kind of *fun* and *driving* qualities

>===== Original Message From Troy Sheets =====
>Listening to Ticon's new album, Aero... I am very impressed. This is
>the first trance album I have heard in a while to really excite me.
>
>Good unqiue sounds and beats. Driving trance tracks can take dubby
>detours right in the middle of the track, and go back, without interrupting
>the flow at all. The whole album has more of a "fun" and "driving" instead
>of "dark" quality. Can totally see this as morning music in the best
>possible meaning of that word. Not to be confused with fluffy.
>
>Best part of this album is production. One word: Immuculate. This sound
>quality on this album is what other artists should be striving for.
>These guys are pros.
>
>find it online: http://www.trancetrax.com (no affiliation with this company)
>
>-troy

background. Ya'll should pick up this album it's revolutionary to modern 
hop-hip and it pushes the limit as far as it can go with vocabulary at a 
speed and rythm so fast that it's almost creepy... especially coming from the 
slums of the east bay of all places.  check out deltron on Kazaa and tell me 
if you don't think hip hop has evolved drastically. (peep the techno 
influence too it's definately there in the background)

i'm in thinking and writing mode....actually, i am having a horribly nutritional and intellectual deficet (sp? big minus) day....so, i was just thinking though, with the permission of myself, and, well, i could and do think when there are zillions of possibities being thrown my way, but, mostly, i prefer to just be in my own thoughts without all that other stuff and askings and worldly sort of thing going on...if you can't make any decisions and (someone is taking up some of my mental space now...so, i am sharing, and she and also a he too, knows that we are all sharing thoughts about things and other things all at the same time, but i am still writing to you...)okay, back to what i thought was kind of important....if you don't know what you really want, and you feel like you just don't know and won't know now, and maybe not ever, at least you know full well what you don't want, and if you know what you don't want, you can just follow that, and then, you won't feel so lost, and you will actually still know yourself even in these most pressing times for everyone when there is no one to speak with except for me for some reason, and couldn't i be the one to do blah, blah, blah with you and for you even though you probably know deep in your heart that i don't want to have a thing to do with you, but why not just go for it anyway? i know that in some way, i am actually reaching the most important part of you, beyond just your privileged ear, eyes and the pure entertainment factor of my fine literature.  alright, i know what i want at least. :)

From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Bored on a night with no party...

... or more accurately, no party with music I'm in the mood for and that's
within my price range...

And I get a bit of amusement from going through the really old rave pictures on
the various websites, and from my own camera, and:

1)  Seeing pics of people I used to see at parties all the time; but they never
show anymore; and I never got their contact info, thinking: "I'll just see 'em
at the next party.".  :-(

2)  Seeing pics of people you know... before you knew them.  And you wonder...
"I was standing two feet away from them, and I didn't say hi???" or, more
annoyingly, "I TOOK all these pictures, with them in the background, for a good
YEAR before I MET them?!?!?"  *smacks self*

3)  Seeing pics of still others... before they were jaded and they still went
to "candy" parties...  Including people that no one would ever guess would BE
at; and whom I had forgotten WERE at...  Happy Kids partys!  ;-P


cya,
john

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."

surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: [sfraves] [sf] us, warmdesk, dat p. and you

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
under the radar // ::  http://utr.praemedia.com/
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
ANDERSON CONGRESS, THE LUXURY TAX & No. 0056
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Tuesday, May 27th
26Mix (mission, between 26th and ceaser chavez)
$3 Donation, 21+

Another installment of u.t.r.'s flagship weirdness. Join us as we warm-up 
for our 2 year anniversary event installment plan. We have some very special 
shows lined-up for you, featuring u.t.r. friends and family.

Here to present another brain-spanking journey into over-drunken week-night 
madness:

LIVE

Anderson Congress:
>From his hide-out deep in the Richmond District in San Francisco, AC 
delivers you some of the most forward thinking electronic music on the west 
coast. With sounds that move between sonic glitch work-outs and mad rhythmic 
ass-shaking beats, AC will work you into a frenzy before you can say 'audio 
mulch'.

The Luxury Tax:
Inventors and virus agents of "gutter bass". LTX has been an active crew, 
releasing no fewer that 3 projects within the last year alone. Their unique 
sound blends cut-up (mashed?) drum and bass, hip-hop, and 'glitch' noise 
with a healthy since of irony and humor. As a project spawned from alcohol 
consumption, drugs and a strong sense of audio geography one would never 
know that these abstract sounds come from a  Corporate Customer Service Rep. 
and a PhD student.

No. 0056:
This Sacramento artist is here to rip you another ear-hole. Mean beats from 
meat streets.


-------------------------------------------------------------
WARMDESK / PIN-UP MOTEL + SPECIAL PEOPLE
-------------------------------------------------------------
Tuesday, May 27th
26Mix (mission, between 26th and ceaser chavez)
$5, 21+

WARMDESK: (LIVE)
warmdesk is the project of chicago-based producer william selman. selman is 
a freelance multimedia designer who is currently studying for a master's 
degree in computer science. the sound of warmdesk combines dense, noisy 
harmonics and dub-like bass with rhythmic patterns and samples from everyday 
life. the desire is to create a multi-faceted "spray" of sound grounded by a 
pulse of beats and concrete sounds--ideally, not too far from minimal techno 
and tech-house. formerly a drummer, selman's strategy is to allow rhythm to 
intuitively develop through repetition instead of the current obsession with 
changing its timbre and structure every measure.

warmdesk has released material on several labels, including bip-hop, static 
caravan and fallt. he is nearing completion on a full-length cd for the 
well-regarded deluxe label (home of electric birds, blechtum from blechdom 
and matmos's early endeavors).

PIN-UP MOTEL: (LIVE)
PIN-UP MOTEL is:
Dan Racanelli (Keyboards)
Jameson Edwards (Guitar, Vox, Keys)
Martin Przybyla (Guitar, Bass, Vox)
Alex Feldman (Drums)

ZYGOTE:(DJ'ing)
Stephen Ruiz (aka Zygote) uses the mechanized process of electronic music 
production and combines the expression of complex human feelings to create 
sound art. The tools of his output are computers, tape recorders, wires and 
other conduits of noise. His sound transcends the inhuman element of 
"technologically enhanced" production methods so vital in the world of 
electronic music producers, and in it's place submits raw and unfiltered 
emotion. While exploring the idea of personal expression through the cold 
exterior of machines, he takes the concepts of compositional indeterminacy, 
generative music and evolving cellular automata and humanizes them. The end 
result is populist music of emotional depth that illicits response via 
technology. Having trained in percussion and guitar, his compositional 
methods are rooted in structured narrative that are constantly being mutated 
under the pressure of new forms of expression.

Stephen has releases on Under the Radar Records and Alectric Records 
(Canada) and is the founding organizer of The "Under the Radar" experimental 
music and video events in San Francisco

-------------------------------------------------------------
TWO YEARS AND RUNNING
-------------------------------------------------------------
Tuesday, June 3rd, 2003
Julip: 839 Geary (between Hyde and Larkin)

u.t.r.// 2 year anniversary event

DAT POLITICS:
Dat politics flash by the way of music but also texts some pixellised and 
pop snapshot focused on failed flirt and gastronomy, After work with 
innovative  and respectable labels as A-musik, Mille Plateaux, Skipp or 
Tigerbeat6, now the laptop-band collaborates with the electro-trash label 
from the Berlin-based trio Chicks On Speed to diffuse their domestic and 
terribly exotic new sonic adventures.

BLEVIN BLECHDOM:
Blevin Blectum - nee Bevin Kelley - one-third of Sagan, ex-d84 and formerly 
50% of Blectum From Blechdom. Currently Blevin plays solo and in Sagan (with 
fellow musician J Lesser and video artist Ryan Junell). Her first solo CD 
was released on Phthalo in 1999. Her second solo CD Talon Slalom was 
released May 2002 on Seattle's Deluxe Records. She makes electronic music 
with samplers and computers mostly.

LESSER:
Starting off with the templates of drum and bass but tweeking them beyond 
recognition, Lesser's music delivers crunchy snares and overdriven bass 
frequencies with a heaping helping of skeptical humor, gritty digital noise, 
and DIY instrument-building ingenuity. Soldering together new instruments 
out of the refuse of 80's mixers and synths, J Lesser avoids the standard 
sounds and strategies in favor of a confrontational, schizophrenic and often 
hilarious rethinking of conventional "intelligent: electronic dance music.

Lance Grabmiller
Born in Kansas City , Missouri in 1975. Studied viola, cello, alto 
saxophone, tenor saxophone and music composition (in that order) before 
putting all formal studies on hold with the discovery of his first four 
track tape recorder at the age of 14. Using various tapes, effects, objects, 
microphones, amplifiers, razor blades and any instruments that could be 
begged or borrowed, he created quite a din in the Midwest, most notably in 
his collaborations with Shannon Fields which included such bands as Alice's 
Offspring, Requiem (which included a revolving cast of dozens) and HSoA 
(with Martin Nieznanski), the last of which culminated in a gigantic 
performance noise nightmare that nearly destroyed the Gizmo in Galesburg, IL 
in 1994.

Co-organizer of the Under the Radar events.


DJ PERFORMANCES:

Wobbly:
Wobbly is a multi-talented artist who excels in music, painting, singing, 
writing, dancing and even woodworking. Once dubbed "Mr. High on Life", his 
colorful high energy is like electricity as it provokes intense emotion in 
his audience.

Wobbly is practical and youthful. He possesses charisma and magnetism. He's 
been a natural artist since early youth, but has restrained himself until 
recently, as his creative drive is pushing him to give to the world what 
lies inside of him. He developed himself as a portrait painter. This year, 
he's gone beyond that as he fulfills his philosophical nature in the avenue 
of music, writing and singing. He wants to live a long life and be creative. 
His fulfillment will not come until he's completed the full cycle of his 
inborn talent. His high creativity in all areas has funneled into music 
where he finds himself at this time, with his artistic ability as a painter 
having a profound effect. It appears as if his painting background shows up 
in his music as he paints pictures with his words. His broad background is 
embraced in his inspired voice.


Zygote:
*see above

Subject: [sfraves] Watch out!!!!!

------=_NextPart_000_0004_01C31866.1BBEDD50
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Below is a letter from our system administrators our inboxes here at my
work are flooded with virus emails. Please beware and watch your
computer so you do not get this virus. In 5 hours I have deleted over
150 emails containing the virus and luckily our anti-virus software here
is removing all attachments. Peace

 

  Jason Philips

  OH Records

  Problematic Beats

 

Summary

A new virus, FIZZER, started widespread infections overnight.  This
virus is similar from our perspective to Klez, meaning it doesn't cause
us much harm, but it's leaving a lot of garbage behind to clean up.

 

What's Going On?

Fizzer is a "hybrid" virus, meaning it blends together components of a
wide variety of other viruses in an attempt to infect systems.  It
appears to be particularly aimed at home users, with a focus on chat
rooms and file sharing networks as a component of its attack, as well as
traditional email distribution.  

 

What can I do? 

If you're receiving your email from Columbia, the infected files are
removed when the message is received here at headquarters, though you
will likely receive remnant messages in your inbox.  These messages can
be deleted. 

 

If you're receiving your email from another source (Many Sales offices
or Sourcing offices), make sure you are running the latest versions of
your antivirus software with the latest pattern files.  Similarly, at
home, make sure you're running anti-virus software, and download the
latest pattern files from the manufacturer of the software.

 

What are you doing?

We've already updated all of the file servers and email servers in the
environment with new anti-virus pattern files and are actively scanning
for this new virus.  We will pass along any new information as it
becomes available. 

 

We automatically delete the payload of the virus as it enters the
environment, so it isn't harming us, however we can't block the email
messages without running the risk of impacting good messages getting
through to you.  

 

Thanks!

Brennan O'Brien

IS/Security

            


------=_NextPart_000_0004_01C31866.1BBEDD50--

From sfraves-return-102044-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue May 13 02:50:34 2003

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_9723929==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Ottawa's move to decriminalize the use of pot angers the
  U.S. government

--=====================_9723929==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Ottawa's move to decriminalize the use of pot angers the U.S. government

Pubdate: Sat, 10 May 2003
Source: Toronto Star (CN ON)
Copyright: 2003 The Toronto Star
Contact: lettertoed@thestar.com
Website: http://www.thestar.com/
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/456
Author: Peter Gorrie


U.S. drug czar John Walters frowns on Canada's plan to decriminalize
marijuana possession.

The move could unleash a flood of pot into the United States, he warns, and
provide funds for terrorists. In retaliation, the Americans might insist on
careful inspection of all Canadians crossing the border, causing long delays
and disrupting business.

"You expect your friends to stop the movement of poison to your
neighbourhood," Walters says.

Canada suggests, in return, that Walters and his boss, President George W.
Bush, chill out.

The pot plan, to be introduced in the House of Commons before the summer
recess, includes a strategy to combat trafficking and smuggling, Justice
Minister Martin Cauchon says. When the Americans see the total package,
they'll like it, he insists.

Paul Cellucci, the U.S. ambassador to Canada, was initially as hostile as
Walters but has toned down his criticism. We'll wait and see, he says now.

Why all the fuss over what amounts to a minor amendment to Canada's Criminal
Code - a change backed by dozens of studies and, polls suggest, enjoying
wide public support, even in the United States.

Why do American officials fear Canada will inflict a major setback on their
war on drugs when we're proposing to do what 12 U.S. states did more than 25
years ago?

Experts say the controversy is as much about perception as facts.

Not surprising, they say, given the history of the marijuana law and the
current anti-drug fervour in Washington.

In 1923, few Canadians had heard about pot, let alone ingested it. But that
year, almost as an afterthought, it was included on the list of prohibited
drugs in an amendment to the Criminal Code.

"Cannabis Indica (Indian Hemp) or Hasheesh" was hastily inserted into one
copy of a previously prepared schedule of illegal drugs. No one explained
why. No one in Parliament bothered to ask.

It was, several observers now say, a solution without a problem.

What pressure there was seemed to originate in the United States, where
opponents of "Mary Jane" were beginning to issue dire warnings.

Famous feminist and reformer Emily Murphy - fresh from her triumph in
persuading the Supreme Court of Canada that women were persons, not merely
the property of their husbands - might have persuaded some officials that
dope was the devil's work.

"Persons using this narcotic ... become raving maniacs and are liable to
kill or indulge in any forms of violence to other persons, using the most
savage forms of cruelty," she wrote in a 1922 book, which described
marijuana as "a new menace."

Murphy was, in fact, approvingly quoting Charles A. Jones, then Los Angeles'
police chief, whose rant was a thinly disguised attack on "Hindoo"
immigrants from India.

Despite their concerns, the Americans didn't make pot illegal until 1937.

No marijuana charges were laid in Canada until 1934. The annual total never
exceeded a handful until the flower-powered mid-1960s. After that, while
use, charges and convictions all soared, the nightmare of murders committed
by dope-addled addicts didn't become reality.

In 1972, a report commissioned by the U.S. government recommended: "Casual
distribution of small amounts of marijuana for no remuneration, or
insignificant remuneration not involving profit no longer be an offence."
Around the same time, in Canada, the Le Dain Royal Commission reached a
similar conclusion.

Neither Ottawa nor Washington acted on their reports. But in 1973, Oregon
decriminalized possession. In the next four years, 11 other states followed.

Then decriminalization fell by the wayside, says Paul Armentano, of the
National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, a Washington pro-pot
lobby group. After 1980, it was snuffed out by Ronald Reagan's war on drugs.
Spurred by the Americans, the United Nations toughened a 1961 convention
that makes it a violation of international law to legalize pot.

Even so, lobby groups and independent researchers around the world continued
to study the issue. All the research showed marijuana use doesn't lead to
hard drugs, and tough penalties aren't a deterrent. The studies invariably
opted for decriminalization.

Australia and most European nations eliminated criminal penalties for
possession, although no country has yet challenged the U.N.'s ban on
legalization.

The issue is being revived in the United States, but the focus is now on
using marijuana to relieve the suffering of people with cancer, AIDS and
other painful diseases. Nine states have gone this route; more are
considering it.

Over the past three decades, Canadian politicians, including Prime Minister
Jean Chretien when he was justice minister in the early 1980s, have talked
about loosening our pot law. With Chretien trying to build a socially
progressive legacy before he retires early next year, it appears Ottawa
might partially reverse what it did eight decades ago.

The current situation is confusing. The possession law is rarely enforced
and, when it is, penalties are wildly inconsistent. Ottawa has approved
medical use of marijuana, but the nearly 300 people in that program have no
clear way to get their supply.

On top of that, the Supreme Court is considering a challenge to the 1923
law. It heard arguments on Wednesday.

Ottawa's message is that marijuana it will continue to be illegal.
Decriminalization means simply that those caught with a small amount -
probably less than 30 grams - will face a modest fine, like a parking
ticket, rather than a court appearance and the possibility of jail and a
criminal record.

Growing, possessing and selling larger quantities will still be a crime. In
fact, the plan - expected to cost about $400 million - will include tougher
measures against traffickers and major producers.

"It's going to lead to a better policy that makes sense for Canadians and
will alleviate the concerns of the Americans," says Mike Murphy, a
spokesperson for Cauchon.

Last fall, a Senate committee recommended legalization, which might allow
pot to be produced, sold and taxed like alcohol. But that step is not in the
cards.

Marijuana "is harmful and it will continue to be treated as an illegal
drug," Murphy says.

Canada is not prepared to challenge the international convention against
legalization, and the public isn't ready for it, officials say.

Ottawa's main aim is to reduce harm, says Richard Garlick of the Canadian
Centre on Substance Abuse, an independent, federally funded research group
in Ottawa.

"Everyone agrees the biggest harm from the existing regime is the
criminalizing of tens of thousands of otherwise innocent people.
Decriminalization succeeds in addressing that; it's as far as you need to
go."

Marijuana has some health effects. Heavy users are prone to respiratory
ailments and, possibly, cancers. It can become addictive.

But, the experts say, those impacts pale in comparison with the damage to
the 600,000 Canadians saddled with a criminal record - which can hurt their
employment prospects and keep them out of the United States - just because
they were caught will a little dope.

In the 12 U.S. states where marijuana possession is decriminalized, use has
actually dropped slightly. The biggest increases have been in states with
the toughest enforcement.

The Americans spend about $17.5 billion (U.S.) a year on policing and
prosecutions, according to the Washington-based Drug Policy Alliance. Police
forces say the expense is far out of proportion to any benefits; the money
and manpower could be put to much better use.

Legal experts say the pot situation brings the law and police into
disrepute. The law is not consistently enforced. While the rate of marijuana
offences has nearly doubled over the past decade - with 70 per cent of those
simple possession charges - less than 1 per cent of Canada's 2 million to 3
million users are caught. Most of them aren't penalized.

More than half the people caught with small quantities of marijuana lose
their stash but get off with a warning. Nearly half of those charged aren't
convicted; many avoid court through community service and education
sessions. Those who go through the courts often get an absolute discharge.

Ottawa's plan, "will lead to more consistent application of the law," Murphy
says. "When it is consistently applied, then people will respect that law."

This "consistent application" might lead to more people being penalized for
possession, says Garlick. If police only have to issue a ticket, they're
more likely to enforce the law, he says. In Australia, the number of
offences tripled after decriminalization.

U.S. officials say relaxing the laws would boost profits for traffickers who
support terrorism. Others argue the opposite.

"It is drug prohibition that generates huge profits for these groups," the
Canadian Foundation on Drug Policy says. "Without prohibition, the drug
trade could not finance terrorism to any significant degree, since profits
from the legal sale of drugs would be a small fraction of what they are
now."

Walters and others warn that Washington would likely express its displeasure
by imposing tough inspections at the border. In particular, analysts say, it
might refuse to exempt Canadians from stringent security measures to be
imposed in 2005.

That worries business groups, including some, like the Fraser Institute,
which support decriminalization.

At a time when disagreements over issues like the Kyoto accord on climate
change and the attack on Iraq have strained relations, they say, we don't
need another dispute, particularly one that could curtail trade.

Canada must be strategic, says Michael Walker, the institute's
executive-director: It might be better to move by stealth, rather than bold
action.

"If we do it in a way that creates a backlash and people start to lose jobs,
there wouldn't be much sympathy for it. We don't have to decriminalize to
achieve the results people want."

"It's another irritant at a bad time," says University of Toronto political
scientist John Kirton. "Even more damaging, in some respects, than the
disagreement over Iraq is the fact it comes in a social-policy issue that's
quite central to the core constituency of President Bush as he moves toward
re-election."

But Daniel Drache, of York University's Robarts Centre for Canadian Studies,
says the threat of retaliation is overblown.

Even if Canada dropped its pot plan, there's no guarantee the U.S. Congress
would approve any exemption from the 2005 security rules, he says.

Drache is convinced, however, the Americans will choose trade over
punishment.

"They're more interested in doing business. If Canadians are committed to
this, it will go through and there will be no repercussions."





Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager




--=====================_9723929==_.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] Sat May 17th - Electronica-Optica VJ Conference

Just a friendly reminder to everyone...


2 new artist have been added to the night festivities.

Don't forget the free workshops and screenings.

Final schedule has been included in this e-mail.

Thanks for the support =3D)





Coming this Saturday...

ELECTRONICA OPTICA :: VJ & VISUAL ARTIST CONFERENCE
SATURDAY MAY 17, 2003 =80 150 Folsom, San Francisco, CA
2 Year Anniversary Celebration



To celebrate two years of total visual madness, Electronica-Optica is
presenting their first annual VJ & Visual Artist Conference. Initially
planned to be a party, this event has grown into a full blown conference
featuring workshops, screenings, and performances.

Lots of questions are being raised these days about VJs and the re-blooming
of the visual artist culture. This is your opportunity to experience
first-hand the new sensations and creative possibilities. Whether you're an
audio or video artist, or even just a fan of the electronic arts, there's
something wonderful here for you to experience.



*** Full conference details & schedule on-line at:

*** http://www.electronica-optica.com/events/



o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o



:: FREE Workshops (2pm-8pm):


=20
* 2:00 pm =AD 3:00 pm :: VJ MARKET PANEL DISCUSSION
Topics range from aesthetic and cultural expression to practical market
projects and strategies. With hosts: Radley Marx (Electronica-Optica), Jon
Schwark (LightRhythm), and Grant Davis & Michael O'Rourke (Dimension 7)


* 3:00 pm =AD 4:00 pm :: CYCLING '74 (including Jitter & Max MSP)
High-End audio/video interaction and integration (by Andy W & Mike Migurski=
)


* 4:15 pm =AD 5:15 pm :: REASON vs. ARKAOS VJ  <-- HOT TOPIC!!
The essential first steps in audio/video digital production for DJs and
producers (by Steve Taormina, Robotspeak)


* 5:30 pm =AD 6:30 pm :: M-AUDIO & EDIROL
Professional VJ equipment demos (by Grant Davis, Dimension 7)


* 6:45 pm =AD 7:45 pm :: EJ SYSTEM & MS PINKY
Turntable mixing and scratching tools for VJs (by Grant Davis and Andy W)





:: FREE Visual Screenings & Film Fest (2pm-8pm):


* 2:00 pm =AD 3:00 pm :: VJTV - BEST OF VJTV - Season One

Featuring interviews and visuals by Arcane, Addictive TV, VJ Culture,
Robotkid, VJ Luna, Suryummy, Absurde Collective, Jon DeKron, gMunk, Honeygu=
n
Labs, WDDG, and VJ Pixielight.



* 3:00 pm =AD 4:00 pm :: VJTV - BEST VJTV - Season Two

Featuring Visualaudio, 47, Johnny Dekam, Imaginary Forces, Madame Chao,
Blasthaus, Amoeba, Yeast, Tina Z, Speed Tribe, C-TRL, Just-D Phantasmagoria
Video, Swipe, VJ V2, and Overlay06/Alpha Channel.
=20


* 4:15 pm =AD 5:15 pm :: YEAST FILMS / RAYA =AD Develop

A visual commentary mixing shot footage and dialog from India and other
countries, examining the economic and social impact of uni-culturalism.
Music by Nitin Sawhney.



* 5:30 pm =AD 6:30 pm :: BITZ & BYTZ=81 Screenings
=20
An assortment of 5-10 minutes work from visual artists and producers from
around the world. Featuring visuals by Addictive TV, D-Fuse, Benton C,
eMovie Collective, Mickey T, Epsilon Labs, SquareSquare, Mindcandy, and
more!



* 6:45 pm =AD 7:45 pm :: DIMENSION 7 - I Am

A pre-screening of this locally produced epic release, over 3 years in the
making.





:: Night Performances (8pm-4am):


1 - 2 am   ::  VISUALAUDIO =AD Chicago
               Live Audiovisual Performance
               www.visualaudio.net


12 - 1 am  ::  EQ! (Punctuated Equilibrium)
               Digital / Analog AudioVisual Collective
               http://www.ragestation.com

               Final Scratch DJ & VJ Crew
               http://www.four7.com

               featuring VJ Culture, Alaric, & Suryummy
               Live Audiovisual Performance
               www.dimension7.com

               VJ team vs. DJ Live Mix
               www.lightrhythmvisuals.com

               Digital VJ/DJ Mix
               www.eoptica.com

               VJ team vs. DJ Live Mix
               www.electroradio.com

               VJ vs. DJ Live Mix
               http://www.traviswinn.com




o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o
o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o



\/ Workshops

The daytime conference will begin with a discussion panel featuring Radley
Marx (Electronica-Optica), Jon Schwark (LightRhythm), and Grant Davis &
Michael O'Rourke (Dimension 7). Each will be addressing different areas of
this emerging culture and sharing experiences and expectations for the
coming year. Topics will range from aesthetic and cultural expression to
practical market projects and strategies.

The afternoon workshops will be filled with a fun assortment of software an=
d
hardware demonstrations for VJs, DJs, visual artists, and newcomers to this
growing culture.

For DJs and new music producers, there will be a essential workshop for
sequencing video clips along with your music, using Arkaos VJ together with
Reason (the easy-to-use music production software that is quickly becoming
more popular than DJs). Equipment demos include VJ turntable-tools for
mixing and scratching video just like records.

For veterans, the Cycling =8C74 workshop will demonstrate the extreme high-en=
d
of what can be created and manipulated by digital video artists. Dimension =
7
will also be showing showing a variety of highly-developed equipment by
Edirol and M-Audio used in professional-level production.

Anyone is free to attend and take part.  This will be an excellent
opportunity for hands-on exploration and discovery.



/\ Screenings

Running concurrent with the workshops will be a series of visual screenings=
.
Just like a film festival, the screenings offer exclusive presentations of
short works and full-length visual projects from the visuals community.

The day will kick off with episodes of Electronica-Optica=B9s public access
series: VJTV. The full-length features include Yeast Films=B9 cultural music
sequence =B3Prophesy=B2 and a sneak-peak at the locally produced CG project, =B3I
Am=B2 by Dimension 7. The high point of the afternoon will be Bitz & Bytz, an
amazing assortment of 5-10 minute submissions by visual artists from around
the world including Addictive TV, D-Fuse, eMovie Collective, SquareSquare
and many more.



\/ Audiovisual Performances

The night celebration will feature performances by several outstanding
artists from the Bay Area and the mid-west. Headlining the night will be
VisualAudio, ESP, EQ!, and 47 - audiovisual performing artists that base
their show on the video as much as the music (or more). Other performances
will feature VJs and DJs playing together for exciting in-the-moment mixes
that spawn a powerful experience for the eyes and ears.


/\ Admission & Location Information

This conference is hosted at the Dimension 7 Studio,
located at 150 Folsom Street, in downtown San Francisco.

The workshops and screenings are FREE and run from 2pm to 8pm.

The night celebration goes from 8pm to 4am in the same space.
A donation is requested for attending the night performances.




\/ Detailed Information

http://www.electronica-optica.com/events/




o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o


/\ About

Electronica-Optica was formed by Radley Marx and Emmett Feldman as a means
to be creative visual artists and to help build a strong market
infrastructure for the emerging VJ industry.

Electronica-Optica is partnered with Media Box to produce VJTV, a monthly
one-hour television series that plays across North America and features
guest artists and visual content.

Radley Marx has worked in the west coast rave scene as a DJ and designer
under the alias Elemental and currently heads Electronica-Optica,
co-produces VJTV, and is developing his own live show as VJ Oz.

Emmett Feldman is currently working on original audio and visual material a=
s
Suryummy, as well as working with a variety of audiovisual groups including
ESP and LightRhythms.

Dimension 7 (D7) was formed in 1993 as one of the original visual artist
collectives and grew to become a full service production company. D7's live
production team combines multiple video projections, special effects, live
camera feeds, and laser animation to create what D7 calls "Immersive
Environments."

o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o
o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o


--B_3135630433_5152114--

"Underground" became a style of music that was actually popular like "rock" 
or "jazz"

it's just better for people to be hearing than pop music because it's more 
educational and full of truth. so in the event that what was 
underground...becomes popular, i think, is a good thing not a bad thing.

Subject: [sfraves] srr: Wear sunblock

--0-974479714-1052849893=:76819
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Some of you, no doubt, have seen me running around at day parties with a big tube of sunscreen, applying it to exposed areas on pale ravers. Well, yesterday I got burnt, bad. I was just walking my dog, when I got distracted, now I am all red and sore. It sucks. Wear Sunscreen. BTW, I don't know if there is any info on this, but since most antidepressants fuck with your ability to not get sunburned, regular or recent use of mda or mdma probably does too, so for those of you who choose to partake, be extra careful.

Moksha Tribe

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the

Subject: [sfraves] more rolling stone coverage of anti-rave legislation





rolling stone, may 29, 2003

on page 52

(part of "the new clubland" feature, pages 51-57, including stories:

"rock is the new dance! step aside techno: bands take over the clubs" by
jon caramanica

"you can't do that here" five towns where the man is cracking down on
nightclubs, by tricia romano

"the new dj booth" inside the modern dj's control room, by d.p.

"the debauched nineties" writer frank owen describes new york when clubs
were clubs

"swing meets house music" louis jordan in da club!, by d.p.

"yoko ono, dance diva" forget paul mccartney - clubland loves yoko!, by
matt diehl

and more)


< 'you can't do that here'
is this new york city or footloose? meet five cities that try to stop the
dancing

with the recently passed Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act, federal
authorities now have another tool to shut down raves. but wait, there's
more - in the past few years, the following cities have been enforcing
their own anti-party bylaws:

1.  new york:  former mayor rudy giuliani dusted off the prohibition-era
cabaret law in the mid-nineties to clamp down on clubs - it says that a
venue must have a license if more than three people are "moving
rhythmically" to music.

2.  charlotte, north carolina:  promoters are required to apply for a
permit to stay open after 2:30 a.m.  all dance events with teens in
attendance have to close by 11 p.m. on weekdays and midnight on weekends.

3.  chicago:  promoters, property owners and even djs can be fined up to
$10,000 for hosting or performing at an unlicensed, for-profit dance event.

4.  orlando, florida:  all clubs serving booze must close by 3 a.m. and are
not allowed to reopen to host raves.

5.  milwaukee:  a town infamous for fining partygoers for once "aiding and
abetting" unlicensed promoters (charges were later dropped) imposes an 11
p.m. curfew for minors on weekends.

tricia romano >


the title and subtitle of the first story upset me greatly because they
sound so dismissive of something we love and care about, but i am glad that
they are continuing to cover the anti-rave legislation.

if you'd like to write to rolling stone to thank them for bringing the
anti-rave legislation to the attention of its readers, please write to them
at:  letters@rollingstone.com.  fax 212-484-3434

thanks.

respect,
mary :)

Subject: [sfraves] girls and world news nrr

--0-1061789340-1052874072=:95953
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

i've been meeting a lot of very interesting girls lately from all over the globe. sometimes, i wonder what would make a wonderful sweet lady leave her home where there is clean air and possibly a good family and go somewhere else, and then, i read the news. there are constant bombings going on everywhere. little wars within small communites. children being murdered or put at risk for torture. poverty. i remember almost tossing away a small crust of bread once in front of a russian girl some time ago, and she was very, very upset with me, because her family had been spending a lot of time waiting for hours in line for loaves of bread of any kind, and i should be sure to eat the whole thing. i still toss away my burnt toast though. i really like beautiful girls a lot. especially when they are nice to me and when they are real. we don't live in a perfect world though, as i am sure you have noticed. i am thinking of a couple of girls i know now. i don't know if i'll be able to bring them to some of the places i like to go to, because the disrespect rate is so completely high just about everywhere, and if it is bad for me, i think it might be ten times worse for them. just my personal admiration of them. i suppose beauty is in the eye of the beholder. don't honestly know what these ladies see in me. wishing the world were a different place. :)

Subject: [sfraves] Attention Spammers (NRR)

1)  Yeah, the fact that I subscribe to SFRaves *IS* a pretty good indication
that I like electronic mucic.  *BRAVO*  You get a cookie.

2)  But the fact that I like electronic music does NOT mean that I give two
shits about your crappy-ass CLUB night.

3)  If I did, I'd probably seek out and subscribe to a list along the lines of
SFClubs.

4)  Regardless of weather anyone likes clubs or not, harvesting email addresses
from peoples' posts to a mailing list, and adding them to your spam list
without their permission is bloody rude, loathesome, and just fucking lame.

5)  No rave promoter has ever been that disrespectful.  The only RAVE crews
that I get email from are the ones whose lists I have explicitly and
intentionally signed up for.

6)  Yes, all this DOES include you ex-rave promoters who have now dropped down
to being club promoters.

7)  See #4

8)  Don't think for an instant that because I'm a raver, I don't report your
spam to Yahoo's filter service and every spam blacklist and mail-abuse service
I know of.

9)  PLUR does not extend to spammers.

10)  See #4

11)  That is all.


cya,
john

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re:  rave project

I did my final powerpoint project on raves a year and half ago.  You should 
have seen the look on the whole class, especially the professor - they were 
riveted!  Basically my approach was to give a break down of the different 
elements of Raves  i.e.  origins, dj's, flyer art, attire, rave culture, 
media coverage, positives & negatives. I tried to cover it all.  For many in 
my class, it was the first time they learnt about the culture behind raves. 
Most of them only knew about raves from the crappy media coverage. Make sure 
you have some really kick ass flyer art, they'll be mesmerized.


Good luck....oh yeah, I aced the final :)



-- Emperor

ocean of mistrust and hate"

Subject: [sfraves] live hip hop with jazzy punch

--0-1839229525-1052931478=:83531
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

hey everyone. if you like hip hop, live grooving hip hop, be sure to catch 40 Watt Hype at the Tongue and Groove this Saturday night, 17 May 2003.  here's a bit of a bio on them, they absolutely rock, and feature a wealth of talent that will blow your mind. also performing are go kart go, the nukes, calahan, blood red rose and lockstar
 
40 Watt Hype offers up a road tested, Organic, All Orignals, 8 piece music group. Several features and write-ups in district, local, statewide and internet press have brought the band to forefront of innovation in the newest hip hop styles. News organizations recognize the skill of the talented band, and the likability of a style that was once limited in its audience appeal. 40 Watt Hype has built a reputation as an impressive, active, working band, and is a favorite among local mainstream (104.1, 101.1) and college (90.7) DJs.

The 8 piece set up avoids the limitations of DJ based hip hop and allows for the band to groove in the moment and prove its musical skills. 40 Watt Hypes tight musicality goes beyond the predictability that Hip Hop has come to be. The horn section evolves sensibly between solos and riffs while Percussionist JD rocks the steady beat on the congas.
Accessibly adding to the true hip hop form and bringing a legitimate sense of musicality, MC/Vocalist Awall fluidly doubles up on percussion and timbales to flawlessly contribute to the massive sound. Twylight MCs from his lyrical volumes with ease and control, and His comfort with the stage proves his music to be a lifestyle, not simply a front for performance.

The bands creative drive reflects in refreshing Leslie-styled chord tones and jazz progressions. 40 Watt Hype have become true innovators of the new hip-hop form with their music, lyrics and stage presence.

Thanks to the help of bands like Ozomatli and 40 Watt Hype, full band-based hip hop has found a larger audience in California where it is given the sensibilities that only a California band can provideAn ironic blend of energy, attitude, laid back style and hype wrapped in jazz based Hip Hop. It is, ultimately, music with a heritage.

40 Watt Hype consistently headlines to sold out venues. With thousands of visits to their website, and an extensive mailing list, buzz on the street is that 40 Watt will bring the Showwhether playing for Blackalicious, The Warped Tour, or Fishbone. 40 Watt Hype is comfortable performing regularly with any style of music: hip hop, latin, ska, rap rock and reggae, finding an audience in each.

Winning over audiences at every stop, a 40 Watt Hype show is not to be missed



---------------------------------

Subject: [sfraves] a history of techno/electronica in general?

------=_NextPart_000_00B1_01C31A00.9BB2E2E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

hey all
I was having a discussion with a friend last night, and he said he
couldn't stand techno.
I asked him why, and what he'd ever heard that was techno...
He said that he couldn't stand it since it had been popular in the early
90's... 'You know, those songs like [Haddaway's] What Is Love or [La
Bouche's] Be My Lover'.
o.O
Is that really what most people think of as techno?
I said i would find him a history of techno as *I* understood it, since
he knows i like trance and EDM in general.
 
Where *does* that early-90's dance stuff fit in?  I said it was more of
an updated disco than anything else... and that it wasn't related to
Aphex Twin [who he knows, and likes, but he says 'well no, that's
*ambient* techno'... errrr] or electronica as i understood the terms...
I realize I could be wrong, and I know i've seen a history before, but
I'd like something to show/tell him when I next see him, so that he
knows that my idea of techno is quite different from early-90's
pop/club/dance hits.
 
hrm, whatever happened to the 'history of house music' series here,
anyway?
 
later
-james

------=_NextPart_000_00B1_01C31A00.9BB2E2E0--

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] live hip hop with jazzy punch

--0-401791759-1052931378=:42123
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

hey everyone. if you like hip hop, live grooving jazzy hip hop, be sure to catch 40 Watt Hype at the Tongue and Groove this Saturday night, 17 May 2003.  here's a bit of a bio on them, they absolutely rock, and feature a wealth of talent that will blow your mind. a unique experience not to be missed.  also performing are go kart go, the nukes, calahan, blood red rose and lockstar. hope to see you there!!!! bliss out peeps----miss g
 
40 Watt Hype offers up a road tested, Organic, All Orignals, 8 piece music group. Several features and write-ups in district, local, statewide and internet press have brought the band to forefront of innovation in the newest hip hop styles. News organizations recognize the skill of the talented band, and the likability of a style that was once limited in its audience appeal. 40 Watt Hype has built a reputation as an impressive, active, working band, and is a favorite among local mainstream (104.1, 101.1) and college (90.7) DJs.

The 8 piece set up avoids the limitations of DJ based hip hop and allows for the band to groove in the moment and prove its musical skills. 40 Watt Hypes tight musicality goes beyond the predictability that Hip Hop has come to be. The horn section evolves sensibly between solos and riffs while Percussionist JD rocks the steady beat on the congas.
Accessibly adding to the true hip hop form and bringing a legitimate sense of musicality, MC/Vocalist Awall fluidly doubles up on percussion and timbales to flawlessly contribute to the massive sound. Twylight MCs from his lyrical volumes with ease and control, and His comfort with the stage proves his music to be a lifestyle, not simply a front for performance.

The bands creative drive reflects in refreshing Leslie-styled chord tones and jazz progressions. 40 Watt Hype have become true innovators of the new hip-hop form with their music, lyrics and stage presence.

Thanks to the help of bands like Ozomatli and 40 Watt Hype, full band-based hip hop has found a larger audience in California where it is given the sensibilities that only a California band can provideAn ironic blend of energy, attitude, laid back style and hype wrapped in jazz based Hip Hop. It is, ultimately, music with a heritage.

40 Watt Hype consistently headlines to sold out venues. With thousands of visits to their website, and an extensive mailing list, buzz on the street is that 40 Watt will bring the Showwhether playing for Blackalicious, The Warped Tour, or Fishbone. 40 Watt Hype is comfortable performing regularly with any style of music: hip hop, latin, ska, rap rock and reggae, finding an audience in each.

Winning over audiences at every stop, a 40 Watt Hype show is not to be missed



---------------------------------
Do you Yahoo!?
The New Yahoo! Search - Faster. Easier. Bingo.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] a history of techno/electronica in general?

I always considered that stuff like Amber and La Bouche et al pretty
much the new versions of say Debbie Gibson and Madonna.  Pop Dance
really.  Nowadays it'd probably fall on Brittany Spears and company its
just that they made it way more mainstream.  Madonna still somewhat fits
into the category but ever since she pulled in *thinks*  Was it Brian
Eno or William Orbit?  She got a lot more flavor for more underground
dance beats and sounds as opposed to the pop like sounds she used to
have.

-----Original Message-----
From: Me [mailto:jcd27@speakeasy.net] 
Sent: Wednesday, May 14, 2003 10:07 AM
To: 'SF Raves'
Subject: [sfraves] a history of techno/electronica in general?


hey all
I was having a discussion with a friend last night, and he said he
couldn't stand techno. I asked him why, and what he'd ever heard that
was techno... He said that he couldn't stand it since it had been
popular in the early 90's... 'You know, those songs like [Haddaway's]
What Is Love or [La Bouche's] Be My Lover'. o.O Is that really what most
people think of as techno? I said i would find him a history of techno
as *I* understood it, since he knows i like trance and EDM in general.
 
Where *does* that early-90's dance stuff fit in?  I said it was more of
an updated disco than anything else... and that it wasn't related to
Aphex Twin [who he knows, and likes, but he says 'well no, that's
*ambient* techno'... errrr] or electronica as i understood the terms...
I realize I could be wrong, and I know i've seen a history before, but
I'd like something to show/tell him when I next see him, so that he
knows that my idea of techno is quite different from early-90's
pop/club/dance hits.
 
hrm, whatever happened to the 'history of house music' series here,
anyway?
 
later
-james

At 10:07 AM 5/14/2003 -0700, Me wrote:
>h
>
>Where *does* that early-90's dance stuff fit in?  I said it was more of
>an updated disco than anything else... and that it wasn't related to
>Aphex Twin [who he knows, and likes, but he says 'well no, that's
>*ambient* techno'... errrr] or electronica as i understood the terms...
>I realize I could be wrong, and I know i've seen a history before, but
>I'd like something to show/tell him when I next see him, so that he
>knows that my idea of techno is quite different from early-90's
>pop/club/dance hits.

One source that is still available in paper is the "All Music Guide to 
Electronica" (Backbeat Books, SF, 2001).  Basic, contains biographies and 
reviews of producers, Djs and the like plus style essays and genre maps as 
well as a bibliography.

>
>hrm, whatever happened to the 'history of house music' series here,
>anyway?

Many people have asked me to continue the series, and I hope to do begin 
again this summer.  BTW, an excerpt from House Music 101 will be included 
in the Summer edition of Fifth Estate.  I've just proofed and rewritten the 
piece.  FE is doing an issue on music and dance.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: RE: [sfraves] a history of techno/electronica in general?

Madonna brought in William Orbit to produce, on Ray Of Light... and now
she's been working with Mirwais.
hrm

Pop Dance, which is fun and fluffy and [nowadays] dominated by European
artists, is generally about as disposable as music gets, in my mind...
like a lot of the stuff they play on 92.7  ;)   Pop in general, Britney
et al... has elements of the cheesy dance stuff, but usually skews more
toward pure pop 

What should a raver's relationship with the fluff be?  Do we bother
trying to differentiate it for our not-into-electronica friends, or just
lump it together with EDM and think quietly to ourselves that it will
improve with time, eventually bringing the sound[s] we love to the
masses?

later
-james

Subject: RE: [sfraves] a history of techno/electronica in general?

	The thing is that people like popular dance music for a reason.
There is a market and will be always a market for crap music. The reason
is the simplicity if you don't have to think about it then it can be
easier to escape from everyday life. Most good dance music in the
underground even in sillier moments has a side of it that is more
thoughtful or at least more thought went into the creation of it. It
requires more brain power to process real music as compared to crap. It
is the true evolution of the lazy man or woman. If you don't have to
think then why exercise the energy. I know of a lot of producers major
names in the underground scene who have alias that they use when working
with pop stars they may not love the music but the paychecks are nice.
As a producer I have been tempted to try and make more commercial beats
under an alias so I could put a little more food on the table for my son
but I cannot bring myself to it. Well I am babbling now and have
probably stirred up all kinds of fun topics now you all can talk about
it and I will have something to read at work. Peace

Jason Philips
OH records
Problematic Beats

Subject: [sfraves] nrr: If you like crazy people...

--0-219109743-1052940490=:98798

I got a free movie pass to "House of Fools" because the promoters thought I would go out and tell all my friends how awesome it was on mailing lists and such... Well IT WAS Awesome and I am telling you to go see it. It was so good it actualy made me like Brian Adams again. It is about this Insane assylum in Russia that gets taken over by rebels in the Chechen war, and it sounds like it would be really sad, but it's really funny too! Guys if you take a girl to see this they will be impressed and think you are really sensitive, while you get to watch this insane hottie run around with guns and bombs and stuff blowing up! Its Great! It also deals with the healing power of music... WITH AN ACCORDION!

Subject: [sfraves] thank you plastic surgery nrr

--0-230854338-1052945113=:14507
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

being well past my prime and loosing all of my estrogen from time to time, i am just grateful for plastic surgery. without things like breast enhancement and face lifts, i would really look like hell today. it is kind of scary, being kind of like a drag queen of sorts, and yet trying to maintain a healthy view of the world. at least i look so real, no one can tell that i won't be bearing children. for reals. adoption is in the cards though! i would hate not to have enough time to create. i would be miserable. also, on another subject, i found some really good cheap wine and some cheap saki, and i have gone through like a bottle of wine per week for a few weeks now. i don't know how much is too much really, and it is not my usual thing. i don't know if i should just have a special one glass per week, or the recommended glass per day. when i was having my blood pressure checked yesterday though, everything, including my pulse, which is usually racing because of nerves and caffine, was normal. i am completely healthy with the exception of  a few aches and pains. of course, i am deteriorating. i am old. :)

From: Kevin James <djkevinjames@yahoo.com>
To: Jack Triumph <jacktriumph@hotmail.com>, SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-DAV40AkK5LqN3300004aea@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] ATP: Which DJ "CD_Player" is better

 I'd recomend the cdj 800, or the 1000 if you can
spend a little more. 

  The Dennon does have more features, but its alot
more complicated to figure out. Also the pitch control
is less acurate than the Pioneers.  After playing
around on it for about 20 minutes it became very clear
to me that I didn't like it at all, and I prefered the
Pioneers. Pioneer Cdj's  are pretty much the standard
for most clubs too.

  You should go to your local Guitar Center and try
them all out. I'm sure they will let you play around
on them for a while. Thats what I did and I ended up
picking the Pioneer 800 (although I didn't buy it
there). I love it!

 Hope that helps

Kevin James

i've been meeting a lot of very interesting girls lately from all over the globe. sometimes, i wonder what would make a wonderful sweet lady leave her home where there is clean air and possibly a good family and go somewhere else, and then, i read the news. there are constant bombings going on everywhere. little wars within small communites. children being murdered or put at risk for torture. poverty. i remember almost tossing away a small crust of bread once in front of a russian girl some time ago, and she was very, very upset with me, because her family had been spending a lot of time waiting for hours in line for loaves of bread of any kind, and i should be sure to eat the whole thing. i still toss away my burnt toast though. i really like beautiful girls a lot. especially when they are nice to me and when they are real. we don't live in a perfect world though, as i am sure you have noticed. i am thinking of a couple of girls i know now. i don't know if i'll be able to bring them to some of the places i like to go to, because the disrespect rate is so completely high just about everywhere, and if it is bad for me, i think it might be ten times worse for them. just my personal admiration of them. i suppose beauty is in the eye of the beholder. don't honestly know what these ladies see in me. wishing the world were a different place. :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Attention Spammers (NRR)

I agree.  Not only are spammners who spam your email address book evil, 
but so are those who spam your guestbook!!!  I had to close down my 
guestbook because all that was on there was spam!!  At one point, 
someone spammed my guestbook to such an extent with one posting about an 
event, that one had to scroll down quite a bit just to get through it!!! 
 Now, I'm quite alright with a little "word up ____, this is ____ 
artist/dj, hit up my site" but not three page-down's worth of detailed 
information about some massive.  the worst thing is i emailed those guys 
to tell them to not spam my guestbook, and in turn they added me to 
their spam email list!!!  
Now, I openly boycott all spam.  If you have a cool event that is 
underground and all about the music and you want me to know about it 
fine, but i'm not going to go to your club event either if you send me 
huge, banner-filled, graphical spam.  I highly encourage others to do 
the same.  It's not hard for me, because for some reason a majority of 
the spam for club nights i get is for events in Vegas, where I have 
never been =P

Toodipip for now =)
Carl Spanoghe
www.nomadicDJ.com

From sfraves-return-102110-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu May 15 02:41:19 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-102110-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 87025 invoked by uid 1103); 15 May 2003 02:41:19 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 87011 invoked from network); 15 May 2003 02:41:18 -0000
Date: Wed, 14 May 2003 19:49:15 -0700
Message-Id: <200305141949.AA224460882@ghettoblasta.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
From: "Baby Daddy" <babydaddy@ghettoblasta.net>
Reply-To: <babydaddy@ghettoblasta.net>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: <IMail v7.13>
X-IMSTrailer: __IMail_7__
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] a history of techno/electronica in general?

a good book to check out on the history of techno is "Techno Rebels" by Dan Sicko.  Another is "Generation Ecstacy".
A pretty good movie is "Modulations" which has been on video for years and is now on DVD.

One thing to consider is the differences between the
originations of "electronica", "house" and "techno"...
electronica is a marketing term but you could say that it means
any kind of electronic music, and thats been brewing for most of
the last century.

"house" is argueably an outgrowth of disco but its generally
agreed that it came out of the black/gay chicago dance club scene
in the early 80's.  there's a couple versions of the story on
how the name came into being, i.e. started in a club called 
the Warehouse, or another is that rare italian disco tracks were
remixed into extended custom anthems for each club i.e. the "house" track.  A lot of the music your friend was saying he didn't like descends from this kind of 4 on the 4 pop/house music. 

"techno" got started in Detroit in the late 80's when they took house beats and added distinctively electronic sounds to give it a futuristic feel.  those records made by a few black guys in Detroit got really popular with the London party scene which was picking up on the Ecstacy thing via Ibiza and the next thing you know, the rave was born.  later came ambient, hardcore, trance and jungle...
and AphexTwin's label, WARP, was one of the early importers/imitators of the Detroit Techno sound, and is definitely in the vein of "Ambient Techno" (his early stuff that is!)

>>>hey all
I was having a discussion with a friend last night, and he said he
couldn't stand techno.
I asked him why, and what he'd ever heard that was techno...
He said that he couldn't stand it since it had been popular in the early
90's... 'You know, those songs like [Haddaway's] What Is Love or [La
Bouche's] Be My Lover'.
o.O
Is that really what most people think of as techno?
I said i would find him a history of techno as *I* understood it, since
he knows i like trance and EDM in general.

Where *does* that early-90's dance stuff fit in? I said it was more of
an updated disco than anything else... and that it wasn't related to
Aphex Twin [who he knows, and likes, but he says 'well no, that's
*ambient* techno'... errrr] or electronica as i understood the terms...
I realize I could be wrong, and I know i've seen a history before, but
I'd like something to show/tell him when I next see him, so that he
knows that my idea of techno is quite different from early-90's
pop/club/dance hits.

hrm, whatever happened to the 'history of house music' series here,
anyway?

later
-james

	charset="iso-8859-1"

X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.50.4133.2400
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4133.2400
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] a history of techno/electronica in general?

A good book if you want to go WAY back would be Last Night A DJ Saved My
Life.  The book is more about the history of the DJ then the history of
house or electronica but its a good read if your interested in the subject.
The Authors are Bill Brewster and Frank Groughton.  Its kinda long (410
pages) but worth it if your REALLY into this sort of thing.

Drew the Hopeless Wonder

YOU!! If you wanna make sum easy cash  and your tired of being broke for
parties then just sign up for this and all that goes on is you act as a
companies distributor of their goods (Well you DONT have to sell
anything, you just set up a site that has products on it and they pay you
for it!!)  I bet your thinking this is sum scam thats gonna rip you off,
but it doesnt cost you anything (What do you have to loose)? This FREE
to join program pays you $2000.00 per month, after only 90 days of
joining without you having to sponsor anybody or doing anything. But, for
every nine people you do introduce to the business, you will receive an
extra $2000.00 per month, so 
therefore, If you sponsored  nine people, you would be making $4000.00
per 
month. Hard to believe for most people "BUT" true. It cost nothing to
join so go 
ahead and see what all the fuss over this company is about.

From sfraves-return-102124-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu May 15 16:47:59 2003

Date: Thu, 15 May 2003 09:47:53 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20030515164753.GP906@pion.local>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <200305141949.AA224460882@ghettoblasta.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <200305141949.AA224460882@ghettoblasta.net>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] a history of techno/electronica in general?

quoth Baby Daddy:
> and AphexTwin's label, WARP, was one of the early importers/imitators
> of the Detroit Techno sound, and is definitely in the vein of "Ambient
> Techno" (his early stuff that is!)

I might just be reading that wrong, but just in case, let me correct
something: WARP is /not/ Richard D. James' label. It was started in the
late 80's by Steve Beckett and Rob Mitchell in Sheffield, England. RDJ's
first release on WARP was as Polygon Window, about 4 years later.

By that time, WARP had already developed a completely unique sound with
artists like Seefeel, the Sabres of Paradise, Nightmares on Wax,
Broadcast, and The Black Dog; distinctly divergent from the Detroit
sound at that time. Before he hooked up with WARP, RDJ had already
released some of his work on R&S (and its sub-labels) alongside the
likes of Derrick May and Juan Atkins. There's some overlap there, but to
call the WARP guys imitators of the Detroit sound just ain't right. ;)

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen
