X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Handbills (and flyers) littering SF Streets and Signposts

Do you leave flyers on people's cars? Here's an article about the city's
perspective in cleaning up both the streets, including the flyers that
litter the ground from SF Nightclubs...


http://www.kron4.com/Global/story.asp?S=3D1270734&nav=3D5D7lFidI

 War on Handbills Fought in SF
=09Email to a Friend
=09Printer Friendly Version
=09Video On Demand
=09VIDEO: War on Handbills Fought in SF

Posted: May 8, 2003 at 5:35 p.m.

SAN FRANCISCO (KRON)  --  In the never-ending battle to clean up our
streets, a new war is being declared against those thousands of posters
and handbills pasted everywhere.

They're illegal. Critics say: it's free speech.

They can be seen everywhere. An empty lampost, a telephone pole or wall
just invites them. Hundreds of posters, handbills or advertisements
plastered throughout the streets of San Francisco.

They're stapled, glued, or pasted on.

Sometimes dozens of the same ad in one place. In time, they become
shredded or torn.

And it drives environmental officers crazy.

"They have no permit,=94 says Environmental Officer Jody Monahan. =93And th=
ey
wheat paste or glue to utility boxes, lamp posts, utility posts."

City public works crews spend untold hours cleaning off the illegal
missives, not to mention the costs to restore the damaged paint.

It is a big production to clean off a poster from one garbage can.

Environmental workers say dance clubs are also illegally leaving posters
on cars in The City's South of Market area.

They eventually end up on the ground.

City officials say there are legal ways to put up these announcements and
posters, but there are restrictions like how big they can be, where they
can go. And then there's the annual $20 registration fee.

The code requires a registration number on the lower right hand side of a
poster.

There's a 70-day limit. And besides a $20 fee, there's a $100 to $1000
security deposit for posting up to 500 signs.

The code also says any violations of the rules could result in fines from
$50 to $500.

And public works is now aggressively going after those fines. One of the
city's biggest offenders is the anti-war group International Action
Committee. It says its volunteers are told to be considerate when posting
the signs.

But they also believe it's a free speech issue.

"People will put it on whether DPW likes it or not,=94 says Bill Hackwell o=
f
the IAC. =93I know they find people doing it illegally. They cite them.
That's part of it. We end up in court. Big waste of time. We usually beat
them."

Environmental officers are working with the city attorney now to
strengthen the codes.

And, as for those posters for parties or dances. They'll also go after the
hotels or clubs where the event is being held.

The city says it=92s going after Hyatt for the cost of cleaning up flyers
advertising an event there. Free speech or not, in San Francisco, you're
going to pay to advertise.

Many cities have similar rules about posting notices. Recently the city of
Burlingame was challenged by a citizen who was angry over yellow ribbons
that were illegally tied on lamp posts in support of American troops.

The city simply declared a yellow ribbon week so they would be legal.

The citizen did not pose any further challenges.

(Copyright 2003 KRON 4 News. All Rights Reserved.)

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

Subject: re: [sfraves] Who is the ghetto tech dj of the bay? 

haha... 
well, sucks for one there need be a question like that even posed-
cuz there is definitely a few of us here!  that said I suspect I've been doing it the longest- since 99, and have played the shit all over town at clubs and undergrounds, once at this back country event called Bruinslair, and twice so far up at Burningman.  I've opened up over at the Booty Bar when that shit was still going at Compression, and have represented at Incognita a few times too.

Also, for almost a year now I've been busting out a little bit of that at my weekly at the Skylark, which is currently every sunday night.  (We had some birthday party show up there two weeks ago and they were ready to get freaky.  Good thing I brought a few extra booty records that night!)

for examples of my style, check out http://ghettoblasta.net
the site is badly need of an update, but the mix links still work.

Can't forget my bro Jon Schatz AKA The Lord Of the Bling.  He tore it up at the last B-Family underground!  We've been known to throw down some booty tag team sets that are not to be fucked with, so keep a look out for that shit.

anyway, I've been really really keen on getting more folks interested in this music.  Anyone who's curious holla back and I'll put you on a mailing list and etc.  And of course, I'm available for parties just about anytime (for the next two weeks I'll be out of town in, of all places, Detroit!) 

p.s. Andy W, if you are reading this, YO DUDE! hit me back with a mix or something. I'll get you on at the skylark for sure.

PEACE, Rob AKA Baby Daddy

What *I* wanted to do, is go wait in line with a friend for the midnight
showing, even though I didn't have tickets.  Then I was going to have another
friend call me on my cellphone, and pretend to be on the east coast, where, of
course, it would have already been midnight three hours earlier, and everyone
would've already seen it.

Then, I would have had a very loud, obnoxious, yuppy-esque, three-way cellphone
"conversation" between myself, my friend in line, and my friend supposedly on
the east coast....

"Dude Alex, it's Jim in New York calling, he just got out of The Matrix... it's
2:30am there, you know..."

"Yeah... oh my GOD!!!  Guess what???  Jim says that Neo and Trinity are
actually BROTHER AND SISTER!"

"No... you see... Agent Smith *IS* the Oracle!  The whole "resistance" has been
his secret plan all along!"

"But wait... Cypher really DIDN'T die in the first movie...  The agents copied
him and turned him into those dreadlock dudes!!!"

"WOAH!!!  Guess who really *does* DIE at the end?!?!?"

Heh...  It'd be even funnier to have a microphone hidden on me, and ANOTHER
friend taping everyone's reaction with my camcorder, from a discrete distance. 
Of course, oh a movie night like last; Sony probably has it's own SWAT team,
complete with snipers, to take you down if you bring a camcorder anywhere NEAR
the Metreon.


cya,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: the matrix

--- nomadicDJ <nomadic@nomadicDJ.com> wrote:
> I have to say . . . this trilogy is turning out to
> have the workings of a true modern masterpiece

modern masterpiece my butt. I saw the first movie 11
times in the theaters. I won't see the new one ever
again. you couldn't even pay me to watch that crap.

sorry, just my opinion. the american sci fi wu xia
aspect is cool. you could rent it on DVD, skip all the
bits where people talk, enjoy the kung fu scenes and
have great fun. but the original had narrative punch
and mystical fervor. it meant something!

this new one -- BLEAH.

there was one thing I liked about it. they brought
some imagery of raving into the mainstream in a way
that suggested they had a clue. this is fairly
unusual! they presented it as tribal frenzy coupled
with organized resistance. I thought that was cool.

but the story? the pacing? the dialogue? the
characters?

the movie itself was (in my ever so vocal opinion)
lamer than a millipede with a thousand crippled legs.


Giles

I would rather collect cans in a shopping cart than get involved with this kind of crap.

OK, I figured everybody knows this by now, but just in case you didn't, when you want to sign a guestbook or a site requires an email addy you obuscate it like this: say you were jon_doe@yahoo.com then you put in jon_doe@NOSPAMyahoo.com real humans can find you, bots cannot. And if you think there are real humans creating mailing lists for spammers, Then send me a dollar, and send a dollar to 5 friends...and you will be rich! ( OK for those of you who don't know: I am kidding about that dollar thing, send me $10!)


--
Sarah Schumm <sarah_schumm@yahoo.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: the matrix

I've seen it twice, and my brain is SO broken right now.  Some questions
is answered, new questions are asked... and the new questions are doozies.

This is a movie that I think needs to be seen a few times.  The first time
you go you expect a surreal action-fest like the first one.  That's not
what you get, so you're disappointed, but the story and the ideas are
stuck in your head and they keep nagging you.  You see it again, focusing
on the ideas and implications, and you have a SERIOUS mindfuq to deal
with.

If Revolutions doesn't resolve my questions I'll need to check into a
mental ward come November.  =P

C.

IF YOU DONT HAVE ENOUGH OF YOUR OWN $$ TO THROW A PARTY... THEN YOU 
SHOULDN'T BE DOING PARTIES. Simple as that.

dollar hit on 2 parties I figured "Fuck I could have spent that $$ on some 
gear and pressed some tracks" and gotten alot further then some faint 
memories of parties that were a pain in the ass and a bunch of headache.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] nrr: the matrix

I think we're giving too much away to the people who haven't seen it,
even though we're not really going into details but its enough.
Seriously though, I was craving the 3rd one at the end of the movie.
There are many unanswered questions that were "not by design" ;)  Watch
it again, things from the first one are answered in reagards to a
certain character which aren't touched on in Reloaded until the very end
sequences.  Other characters are still very much alive at the end of
Reloaded that were only shown for a few scenes, etc...  Reloaded made
more questions than answers for me and I'm dying for the third.  Of
course nothing is going to truly beat the mindfuq we were given in the
first... Yet.. Think... :)  I think you were expecting a shocking truth
like the first one and were so busy looking for it you missed a lot of
the subtleties.  Its almost following the format of another trilogy of
movies just a different storyline.

And they showed the exit to my house!  Go Whipple Ave!! :)

Having attended your parties, it wasn't a wholly bad deal. :)

I have this great memory of the sound guys flipping out while I was
playing a Neil Landstruum record at the FL at second and jackson...
they're like "what the fuck is going on with the bass" not even
considering it might have been recorded that way.

At one of your other events, I have a story I will never forget about the
world's horniest e-tard.  Good thing there were enough people keeping a
benevolent eye on her, cause without them, she would have been... erm...
pretty darn "popular".

I also met a very special girl at that party (not the horny etard, I
swear), which was the start of a great relationship (that I'm no longer
in, but nonetheless very appreciative of).  So don't sell the impact of
those nights you delivered to people short... a good party is an amazing
thing.

andyw

p.s. MacAudioooo... $4k and a few months of stress is NOTHING compared to
what a lot of people I know have dumped into making and promoting thier
music & labels.  Just a thought.

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: FYI - Burning Man Lawsuit


>From another list....

I thought people would want to know about this....

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Black Rock City, LLC Uses "Burning Man" Trademark to Stop Commercial
Sales -- While Selling $225 Tickets Itself

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE / May 15th, 2003, 20:00 PST

Contact: Daniel Burton, (510) 504-8708, dan@spaz.org

BERKELEY, CA -- Black Rock City, LLC, the company holding the "Burning
Man" trademark has filed a VeRO request with eBay, resulting in the
removal of two auctions containing the phrase "Burning Man."  Using
the phrase "Burning Man" in connection with selling a commercial
product, it says, upsets participants in the festival, at which all
commercial sales are banned.  However, Black Rock City, LLC is itself
in the business of selling commercial products using the name "Burning
Man" -- expensive tickets to the festival, which currently retail at
$225 -- more than many of the artists who supported the festival in
its early years can afford.

"Burning Man itself has become a commercial product, and an expensive
one at that," says Daniel Burton, the eBay seller.  "It is
hypocritical of people who are selling $225 tickets to an event
supposedly based on a 'gift economy' to try to censor auction listings
that merely suggest the product is good for Burning Man somewhere, but
don't claim to be tickets or official merchandise."

The two listings, under the ID melchizedek_merchandise, were for pairs
of hand-made fairy wings "by Imagination Creations" and had titles
that read "Fairy Wings & Crown-Ren Fair/Goth/Burning Man" and "Red
Fire Fairy Wings-for Burning Man/Rave/etc."  Burton says he had seen
similar listings in the past and was just trying to tell people what
the wings might be good for.  He was surprised when he was contacted
by Jim Graham (ronjon@burningman.com), Burning Man's "Media Mogul,"
citing the trademark, and thought it was strange that there even was a
trademark for "Burning Man," an ostensibly non-commercial event.

Burton, who has had trouble finding work since he graduated from
college with a Computer Science degree in December 2000, says he would
like to go to Burning Man but cannot afford it.  A past Libertarian
Candidate for State Assembly (2000) and a self-described
"socially-conscious anarchist," he is a strong believer in free speech
and staunch opponent of over-reaching intellectual property law.

"The idea that any one group can own, control, and censor the words
'Burning Man,'" he says, "is completely counter to the original
anarchic spirit of Burning Man.  What happened to the concept that
there are no spectators, that everyone is equally involved?  What
happened to the idea that Burning Man is not just another carnival put
on by some production company where passive audiences pay for
entertainment?  If things have reached the point at which some
official organization puts up fences, charges admission, and censors
use of the words 'Burning Man,' things have effectively reached that
point.  Burning Man has sold out -- not to any corporation, but to a
market of wealthy yuppies and spectators itself."

"Burning Man would like to isolate itself from economic inequality --
but in the outside world economic differences have impact.  People
have to make money to subsist, and lofty notions of a 'gift economy'
won't make that money.  Black Rock City, LLC doesn't even offer
discounted tickets to low-income people, something that almost every
non-commercial social service organization does with its services.  I
was just trying to make enough money to pay rent by teaming up with a
struggling artist and selling her works online, and I'm barely
breaking even -- is this wrong?"

In fact, Black Rock City, LLC is not registered as a non-profit, but a
for-profit joint stock company, owned by six individuals.  Despite all
the talk about participatory decision-making, the LLC agreement makes
no mention of it and gives ultimate decision-making authority to a
council of managers.

"In other words, the participatory part can be eliminated at their
discretion," Burton says.  "There is no excuse for doing things this
way.  Other festivals like the Rainbow Gathering, Autonomous Mutant
Festival and so on have all operated as informal, horizontal networks,
without official hierarchies, for years, remained free, operated on
Federal land without permits, and avoided being shut down, all with no
signs of changing -- and mostly because of the determination of the
organizers, which I don't see in Burning Man."

Burton does not believe "Burning Man" is a term that should be
protected as a trademark and is considering a lawsuit to invalidate
it.  He contends that the term "Burning Man" was in common use
referring to more than just a commercial product long before it was
registered as a trademark.

"I've been around long enough to remember when Burning Man actually
was a sort of temporary autonomous zone," Burton says.  "From the very
beginning 'Burning Man' has always referred to the entire gathering
and the efforts of all who participate in it in creating the spectacle
- -- not just a select organization and the tickets they sell."

Besides this, he says, Black Rock City, LLC actually only holds a
service mark, a type of trademark which only protects services
rendered, in this case organizing festivals, and not physical goods.
"I'm not selling the same type of product at all and there's no way
anyone could mistake these wings for Burning Man tickets or official
merchandise," he says.

Burton plans to challenge the VeRO request on eBay, and says he will
use the phrase "Burning Man" in future listings.  If he can't sell his
merchandise on eBay, he says, he will offer it for sale elsewhere just
to prove his point.  If he can't use the web, he says, he will turn to
peer-to-peer file-sharing and e-mail.  He has other plans which he
describes as "a mix of civil disobedience, hacktivism, and other
unspecified actions which you can neither anticipate nor imagine," if
Black Rock City, LLC does not back down.  He has registered the domain
burningmantrademark.org, which is not online at the time of this
release, but his website can be found at
http://www.spaz.org/~dan/burningmantrademark/

###

From: JBlaze112@aol.com
Message-ID: <177.1aab585e.2bf783f4@aol.com>
Date: Sat, 17 May 2003 08:24:20 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: AOL 5.0 for Windows sub 103
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: the matrix


    did everyone fail to notice how the matrix dances around biblicable 
ideologies? Althought it may be a touchy subject for some, i think it's 
pretty obvious to see the connections.
 In the first movie Neo becomes aware that he is "the one" obviously this 
massiah type character. this is followed by a series of miricle-ish feats 
that leaves the audience (and even characters in the movie in disbelief). 
    Natrally we have a character that tries to betray neo (the guy with 
bloody hand) and a guy that believes in him when all others do not 
(morpheous), a true love (magdali... opps i mean trinity) and of course a 
huge following in the city of zion.
    Now it is allured to that the prophecy is a lie... used to control the 
masses into passivity. And we are left with this apacolyptic, doomsday 
feeling at the end of the movie.
     If the story keeps going in this direction... i wouldn't be suprized to 
see Neo somehow "sacrifice" himself, (perhaps inside the mainframe) to cause 
the freeing of the minds of the humans living in the matrix. Or perhaps 
"pieces" of his "energy" will live on within the people of Zion. 
    other things to notice... Smith seems to allure a satan-esk character, 
(he can control and become any common person) while the french guy is more of 
a "fallen angel" type and if you look closely at the painting that is on the 
tile floor durring the fight with the french guy's henchmen you will see a 
famous piece that is entitled "Gnosis" which is a greek word for the secret 
truth. 
    All in all it's easy to critisize the movies attempt to be hollywood and 
be on the cutting edge of new age philisophy at the same time. and you will 
have your people who will say this or that is lame or I don't agree with this 
or that... But damn you just gotta give it up to the Wachowski brothers for 
actually going through with the idea and sticking to it. This movie is by far 
the most bold blend of science, myth, religion and hollywood elements such as 
action, humor and drama that i have yet to see all at once within a two hour 
time frame.

p.s. even the term matrix before used as a computer term was an idea from the 
chinese I-Ching, also the Achient Mayan calender was a matrix.

p.p.s. there are even more suble insinuations in the movie that involve the 
idea of Vampires, Tribal/Rave-like celebrations, French wine lol, and even 
the idea of "God's perfection VS. the Goddess's intuition" 

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: the matrix

Just saw it last night...all I can say is: Holy
Crack!!! This was a mighty impressive movie, and I
feel the majority of people who enjoyed the first
installment will appreciate this one, too (and be
hungry, as I now am, for the final chapter, which will
be released in my birth month this year. Yay!).
There's plenty of action, beautifully-done special
effects (I have no problem with the use of wires
during the fight scenes...how else can they produce
such effects without going purely digital?), excellent
set design, plot development and interesting twists to
some critical story elements.

When I saw the dance sequence, I instantly thought
"they're raving!" *S* I'd love to see a UG crew put
together an event that emulates that dance sequence
(hint, hint...nudge, nudge...wink, wink), and I'm sure
some of the great crews are already brainstorming on
it *S*

Anyone have the soundtrack yet? Is it even more tasty
than what we here in the movie?

Such a well-done film. I hope everyone will go to see
it with no expectations, and enjoy the feast for what
it is...then it will be entertaining and satisfying
*S*

Peace and pass the popcorn,
Eric

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: the matrix

not just christian myth--i think the Matrix emulates a lot of myth from 
all over the place--especially the epic.  the rave scene, for instance 
(which I thought was awesome, btw)--how many epics have you read that 
describe parties of monumental proportions before battles of monumental 
proportions in or around those walled up citadels?  Plus, Neo's journey 
reminds me of Gilgamesh, and his long journey--meeting with many 
different, and some ancient characters of all types to find the answer 
he is looking for.  Let's hope when he finds it, it doesnt slip from his 
fingers into the sea.  

carl spanoghe
www.nomadicDJ.com

PS on a funnier note, remember the merovingian "cake" scene?  my 
girlfriend completely ruined it for me when we were talking about that 
movie, and she quite hoenstly said "ohhhhh, you thought it was an 
orgasm??  I thought it was diarreah!!!  lol

Okay I went to see it again last night, and not only did it not answer any 
questions i previously had, I have over twice as many.  The scene with the 
architect is crazy. Huge mind fuck.  The problem with the movie is that they 
give you too much info, so in your mind you try and put 2 and 2 together, but 
in that world it doesnt equal 4.  Crazy stuff...

thustar2003@yahoo.com writes:

> Just saw it last night...all I can say is: Holy
> Crack!!! This was a mighty impressive movie, and I
> feel the majority of people who enjoyed the first
> installment will appreciate this one, too (and be
> hungry, as I now am, for the final chapter, which will
> be released in my birth month this year. Yay!).
> There's plenty of action, beautifully-done special
> effects (I have no problem with the use of wires
> during the fight scenes...how else can they produce
> such effects without going purely digital?), excellent
> set design, plot development and interesting twists to
> some critical story elements.
> 
> When I saw the dance sequence, I instantly thought
> "they're raving!" *S* I'd love to see a UG crew put
> together an event that emulates that dance sequence
> (hint, hint...nudge, nudge...wink, wink), and I'm sure
> some of the great crews are already brainstorming on
> it *S*
> 
> Anyone have the soundtrack yet? Is it even more tasty
> than what we here in the movie?
> 
> Such a well-done film. I hope everyone will go to see
> it with no expectations, and enjoy the feast for what
> it is...then it will be entertaining and satisfying
> *S*
> 
> Peace and pass the popcorn,
> Eric

i just wanted to add to this post, because what i have to say at the moment is sort of similar and relevent, and since i go out and meet real people a lot and have real interactions with them, and since i also don't consider every attempt to get my attention to be a beginning or an ending or a possible effect on my life and personal space, since i am not the one who is having the screaming raging issues within myself, i am quite comfortable expressing myself, and listening to my real friends without having to be rude, because, as many already know who have nothing better to do than sit around and spread their bad mood around, it is nice to keep good company with a really nice lady now, isn't it? and when you aren't keeping good company with a nice lady, maybe you won't be feeling so nice anymore, but what does that have to do with me? absolutely nothing. i am sorry if so many in the world are having troubles making friends, but just because someone else hurt your feelings doesn't mean that i am the one who did it to you. just because people have things in common with one another doesn't mean that the person who disrespected you when you were about 6 years old at school, and you never got over it, were mezmorized by it and let it totally shape your personality, like maybe your teacher who taught you to only speak when spoken to, or your parents or guardians who always told you that what you had to say was meaningless so you'd better shut up...just because maybe these things happened to you to make you who you are today doesn't  mean that i or a nice girl you meet out on the town deserves your disrespect. if you disrespect yourself forever, that is your choice, but there are plenty of people who have lives and love to share and who enjoy the company of others, and who also have pain, but who don't feel the need to attempt to inflict it on others. many know already that if you are hungry, you should eat, and that if you don't like your job, you should just go and get another one, for example. there are a  ton of smart sweet girls in the world, and just because you might meet some mean ones, purely by accident, doesn't mean that the nice ones aren't right around the corner. love and slutty dreams to you. ;)

Geri Dahl <eeelips@yahoo.com> wrote:i've been meeting a lot of very interesting girls lately from all over the globe. sometimes, i wonder what would make a wonderful sweet lady leave her home where there is clean air and possibly a good family and go somewhere else, and then, i read the news. there are constant bombings going on everywhere. little wars within small communites. children being murdered or put at risk for torture. poverty. i remember almost tossing away a small crust of bread once in front of a russian girl some time ago, and she was very, very upset with me, because her family had been spending a lot of time waiting for hours in line for loaves of bread of any kind, and i should be sure to eat the whole thing. i still toss away my burnt toast though. i really like beautiful girls a lot. especially when they are nice to me and when they are real. we don't live in a perfect world though, as i am sure you have noticed. i am thinking of a couple of girls i know now. i don't know if i'll be able to bring them to some of the places i like to go to, because the disrespect rate is so completely high just about everywhere, and if it is bad for me, i think it might be ten times worse for them. just my personal admiration of them. i suppose beauty is in the eye of the beholder. don't honestly know what these ladies see in me. wishing the world were a different place. :)

> not just christian myth--i think the Matrix emulates a lot of myth from

> describe parties of monumental proportions before battles of monumental
> proportions in or around those walled up citadels?  Plus, Neo's journey
> reminds me of Gilgamesh, and his long journey--meeting with many
> different, and some ancient characters of all types to find the answer
> he is looking for.  Let's hope when he finds it, it doesnt slip from his
> fingers into the sea.

> >ideologies? Althought it may be a touchy subject for some, i think it's
> >pretty obvious to see the connections.
> > In the first movie Neo becomes aware that he is "the one" obviously this
> >massiah type character. this is followed by a series of miricle-ish feats
> >that leaves the audience (and even characters in the movie in disbelief).
> >    Natrally we have a character that tries to betray neo (the guy with
> >bloody hand) and a guy that believes in him when all others do not
> >(morpheous), a true love (magdali... opps i mean trinity) and of course a
> >huge following in the city of zion.

> >"pieces" of his "energy" will live on within the people of Zion.

more of
> >a "fallen angel" type and if you look closely at the painting that is on
the

a
> >famous piece that is entitled "Gnosis" which is a greek word for the
secret
> >truth.

> >have your people who will say this or that is lame or I don't agree with
this
> >or that... But damn you just gotta give it up to the Wachowski brothers

far

hour
> >time frame.

At 01:13 PM 5/17/2003 -0700, Mystic wrote:
>It's the classic Hero's Journey (Joseph Campbell) that Star Wars was based
>on... and a mjority of myth including the bible fallows... btw has anyone
>seen the free Animatrix epsoides http://www.intothematrix.com/ check them
>out!!!

The Matrix seems to me to be, amongst other things, in the ancient 
tradition of the epic  journey of the soul (eg, the Iliad and the Odyssey, 
Spenser's Faerie Queene).  Matrix, however, deals with the "modern" spirit 
and its attempt to integrate technology with humane, non-quantifiable, 
soulful values.  Perhaps this is the creation of contemporary mythologies.

I believe the "religious" underpinnings of the work, however, incorporate 
both Western and other systems and includes a healthy dose of Buddhism.

One thing I find unsettling in these commercial works, tho, is the damn 
product placement.  How much did Cadillac pay to have their vehicles placed 
in the freeway episode?  Will this motivate young questers to drive Caddys?

Love,

Apollo

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

this
> > >massiah type character. this is followed by a series of miricle-ish
feats
> > >that leaves the audience (and even characters in the movie in

> > >bloody hand) and a guy that believes in him when all others do not

a
> > >huge following in the city of zion.
> > >    Now it is allured to that the prophecy is a lie... used to control
> the
> > >masses into passivity. And we are left with this apacolyptic, doomsday
> > >feeling at the end of the movie.

suprized
> to
> > >see Neo somehow "sacrifice" himself, (perhaps inside the mainframe) to
> cause
> > >the freeing of the minds of the humans living in the matrix. Or perhaps
> > >"pieces" of his "energy" will live on within the people of Zion.
> > >    other things to notice... Smith seems to allure a satan-esk
> character,
> > >(he can control and become any common person) while the french guy is
> more of
> > >a "fallen angel" type and if you look closely at the painting that is
on
> the
> > >tile floor durring the fight with the french guy's henchmen you will
see
> a
> > >famous piece that is entitled "Gnosis" which is a greek word for the
> secret
> > >truth.
> > >    All in all it's easy to critisize the movies attempt to be
hollywood

> > >be on the cutting edge of new age philisophy at the same time. and you
> will
> > >have your people who will say this or that is lame or I don't agree
with
> this
> > >or that... But damn you just gotta give it up to the Wachowski brothers
> for
> > >actually going through with the idea and sticking to it. This movie is
by
> far
> > >the most bold blend of science, myth, religion and hollywood elements
> such as
> > >action, humor and drama that i have yet to see all at once within a two
> hour
> > >time frame.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: the matrix

Just because this film doesn't "answer" certain questions that it brings up 
doesn't give anyone reason to crytizize it. These are deep philisophical 
questions being brought up that have never been asnwered in all of our 
history, and they are not going to just answer them difinitively within the 
movie. The Writers and directors themselves don't "know" the answers, they 
are just asking all the most intriguiging questions and using them to install 
suspense into peoples minds. It's not a "mind-fuck" and it's not disapointing 
and it's not a downfall of the movie, it's just simply the creators of the 
movie being clever and thought provoking. Just the fact that it makes you 
start thinking about such topics is the whole point of the movie rather than 
answering all your questions for you. 
    I dunno i just think it's odd that this movie has so many good aspects 
and yet the majority of people i talk to only comment about their frustration 
about not understanding it. Just think of it like poetry for christ's sake! 
lol it's a goddamn movie! lets give it credit for what it's worth and wait to 
see how the third one comes out.

Subject: [sfraves] Looking for an MP3 BPM counter...

So, with the release of iTunes 4, you can convert the ID3 tags of your
MP3s/AACs to the latest, which includes a field for the BPM of the track! 
Great, thinks I, for creating playlists to suit my mood, by autogenerating
playlists at the right tempo.

One problem... how to populate that field throughout my 19GB of MP3s/AACs in
the first place?!?!?!?  Does anyone know of an application that will do this?

Searching the usual sites, I already found two; but neither is acceptable.

iTunes-BPM Inspector expects you to tap a key or mouse button to the beat
yourself.  This is lame as hell, and obviously unacceptable for a 19GB
collection.

Ask the DJ TRIES to do it properly, but it is defective as hell.  How do I
know?  Well, there's not a happy hardcore song in existance that's only 80 BPM!

I KNOW that such things are possible.  I've SEEN the mixers that display the
BPM dynamically.  So does ANYONE know of an iTunes plugin, or even a
stand-alone program, that can help me out?

Thanks bunches!


cya,
john

Coughing up blood is pretty common among chronic clove and menthol

> > were

had not been relleased and the realse date was supposed to be much closer to 
the release of the CTS.  After shooting and before the cars ended up in the 
compacter, GM officials were rumored to have been going through the trash to 
colllect random parts that had broken off, in order to keep the vehicles 
under wraps.  If you want to talk about product placement, go see X2.  
Cyclops apperently drives a Cobalt Blue RX-8.

MIME-Version: 1.0

CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <20030517231839.98965.qmail@web12306.mail.yahoo.com>
In-Reply-To: <20030517231839.98965.qmail@web12306.mail.yahoo.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Looking for an MP3 BPM counter...

Supposedly, Traktor DJ Studio 2.0 (traktor-dj.com) includes support for 
swapping or exporting
tractor playlists to itunes. When I get a large collection of new music on
MP3, I typically import the collection into winamp (using the "add->directory" 
menu/button) then export a playlist in either m3u or pls format from winamp.
Then I take that same playlist and import it into traktor (this is a quick
way of getting all your artist/album/song.mp3 files in all sorts of deep
directory structures into traktor -- which otherwise things you should
do things a directory at a time, manually).

In traktor, set the "autoload next track" preference, and make sure the
"stop at end of track" preference is unset. Then load the first song from
your playlist into Deck A, and hit play.... it'll then play through your
list of thousands of MP3's (I let it run all night and all day) and
try to determine the BPM's of songs. Traktor then writes the bpm of each
songs into the playlist, which you can then cut/paste or subdivide into
smaller playlists. I think traktor 2.03 has a
new feature for writing ID3v2 tags in MP3 files.

The only additional step you'd need to take, probably, would be whatever 
feature traktor uses to export to itunes. I'm sure there's a gaggle
of freeware programs one could compile and test and cobble together into
a script. My description is just regarding off-the-shelf windows usage.

Regarding the export to itunes ... since I don't use the mac or itunes, I 
haven't tried it out.

PS: you may have to set the max bpm in traktor's bpm counter preferences
to a higher value if you want it to recognize happy hardcore choons. Most
dumb bpm counters expect songs in the 60-140 range... so lets say you got
a 160BPM HHC choon playing... the BPM counters going to go... "hmmm 160
BPM, that's impossible... i must be triggering twice per measure ... I'll
just display 80 bpm instead"...

Having an electronic BPM counter keep count meens you need to inform
it of stuff like the BPM range, and the number of beats per measure.
Most computer BPM counters handle the range part... but don't adequately
handle, nor recognize, non-western-dance time signatures, e.g. the
rhythmic cycles of 16 (or 7, 11, 9, etc) beats in indian music, or
12 beat rhythm cycles in african musics....

-- Niels.

John B. wrote:
> So, with the release of iTunes 4, you can convert the ID3 tags of your
> MP3s/AACs to the latest, which includes a field for the BPM of the track! 
> Great, thinks I, for creating playlists to suit my mood, by autogenerating
> playlists at the right tempo.
>

> the first place?!?!?!?  Does anyone know of an application that will do this?

> 
> iTunes-BPM Inspector expects you to tap a key or mouse button to the beat
> yourself.  This is lame as hell, and obviously unacceptable for a 19GB
> collection.
> 
> Ask the DJ TRIES to do it properly, but it is defective as hell.  How do I
> know?  Well, there's not a happy hardcore song in existance that's only 80 BPM!
> 
> I KNOW that such things are possible.  I've SEEN the mixers that display the
> BPM dynamically.  So does ANYONE know of an iTunes plugin, or even a
> stand-alone program, that can help me out?

Jeff

Wassup Y'all,

As per the usual, we've got some ill ass dnb for ya tonight, straight =
from Dirtbox studio in Berwyn Heights, MD, USA.  Check out the lineup:

07-09pm EST - DJ Abe Froman - This cat sent us a CD a while back, and we =
were impressed! He rolls with a solid track selection, complimented by =
quality production. He'll have some new bits for us this weekend, so =
watch out!
09-11pm EST - Inflictz - Inflictz is another local junglist who's been =
gettin' play as of late. He's solid as hell as far as turntable =
manipulation goes, and uses said skills to build dark, techy mixes =
spiced with a lil bit of that wikka-wikka.
11-whenever EST - Mystery Slot - Higgs will be back up in the studio =
tonight, so we might get some Dirtbox Kru taggin' goin on.  Whatever =
happens tho, it'll be tight:)

To tune in tonight, select one of the links below:
64k (broadband) - http://jungletrain.net/64kbps.pls
24k (modem) - http://jungletrain.net/24kbps.pls
webcam (10 sec refresh) - =
http://glue.umd.edu/~odjallen/dirtboxradio/webcam.html
chat (IRC) - http://www.jungletrain.net/chat.htm

All of the links, as well as up-do-date information and archives, are =
located on the site at http://www.dirtboxradio.com.

If you're interested in playing on the show at some point, or if you've =
got a track or mix you'd like us to play - just hit us up at =
bookme@dirtboxradio.com and we'll sort ya out.  We feature dnb, breaks, =
and hip-hop on the show, but are always happy to listen to anything you =
submit and give some constructive criticism if it's requested.

For those of y'all who are in the Dc Metro area, keep your eyes out for =
a new party starting up at the end of this month, called District Zoo.  =
It's gonna be held every wednesday @ Roha (aka Kaffa House - 1212 u =
street, DC), free before 10pm, $5 after, and 21+.  Opening night is May =
28th, featuring John Tab and yours truly.  It's gonna be a fun party, so =
don't sleep:)

Also, I'm gonna be taking over Renegade Bass (Monday Nights on =
Jungletrain) for the next couple of weeks, while my homies Stamina are =
over in the UK, and basically attempt to run it into the ground ;)  Tune =
in, it'll be fun... heh heh heh.  Gotta work on my Joey Migraine =
impersonation.

Aight y'all, that's enough keyboarding from me for today.  See y'all in =
the chat tonight!

Ez,
Jackson {ODJ}
Partners in Crime, Dirtbox Radio, Trividual Productions, Third Leg =
Productions

Subject: [sfraves] future fest: behind the music

futurefest: behind the music
i recently noticed an advertisement for futurefest2003, below is some emails 
exchanged between james mondrogan & myself, brian frost, in regards to a 
bounced check for $500 he issued to me for my services at future fest 1 
(2000). not only did my check bounce, but every other artist from black 
locust, including others.  Im posting this because I think its necessary 
to let the public know what kind of people are running that outfit. I know 
some people are scheduled to play for them in the near future, and want you 
to be fully aware of who you are getting involved with. I know Im not the 
only one to be screwed over by these people, just be fully aware, and even 
boycott their events if you feel its justified. Sorry to stir up the drama, 
but shit like this hurts the scene more than it helps. It NEEDS TO BE KNOWN.


From: brianfrost@attbi.com
To: feedback@futurefest2003.com
Subject: debt collection
Date: Sat, 17 May 2003 03:02:45 +0000

dear futurefest promotional extravaganza,

you probably dont remember me, since owing $$ to people and never paying 
them are quite common for your organization. but would it be too much to ask 
to be compensated for the $500 bounced check i received for my performance @ 
the first futurefest? remeber jimmy... i kept your dnb room in check when 
everyone showed up late, no mixer was in the room, and the sound went out? 
your 'stage manager', not to mention playing. and the fact that i had to 
drive some 2+ hours to get to that mudhole... on top of helping you 
promote???! thanks to you, i had to close my account because i had spent 
your check before it had cleared assuming (lord knows that was a mistake) 
that you kept your promises. so yeah, not only did i not get paid... but i 
ended up having to pay to play for you.

nice business ethics.
please respond if you have any .oz of dignity.

brian frost
916.###.####
brianfrost@attbi.com

Subject: [sfraves] bsp/apot - correction factor - NEW hard trance/nrg mix download

hey, i just threw a new mix together a few days ago, correction factor, it's 
posted for download on my website:
http://vehicle.me.berkeley.edu/~apot/mixes.html
i also spent some time learning soundforge and split the set into tracks so 
you can download the entire mix or the individual tracks. my first hard 
trance/nrg mix, been getting into it over the past several months and building 
up my vinyl collection. the sound quality's much better than in my last mix 
too, the insomnia sessions (trance, goa), which is also posted for dl on the 
same page.
track listing on the page next to the cover, a blend of my fav trance/nrg 
classics and new releases i'm just learning about.
i put alot of work, energy and love into this set and wanna share it with 
everybody. def dl, give a listen, lemme know what you think... =) promoters, 
friends, strangers, say wazzup. hit me up for a hard copy too if you need 
one...
anyway, enjoy... =)

apot.

matter what the truth brings, it is always accompanied by a quiet pain.

From sfraves-return-102238-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon May 19 18:38:45 2003

From: <mattsb@ozemail.com.au>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Tue, 20 May 2003 4:38:40 +1000
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Message-Id: <20030519183841.GSAG10465.mta11.mail.mel.aone.net.au@[127.0.0.1]>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Post mortem on a year in the bay. [with mindcontrol props]


Hey,

I'm about to leave the Bay having been here for a year, and thought I'd give a little wrap up on my year here, and how good it was in general.

Coming from Australia, with a pretty minimal rave scene, or at least nowadays, I wasn't really sure what to expect. After about a month, I finally thought it would be a good idea to subscribe to the sfraves mailing, list and this was certainly a well played move. From there I could subscribe to a lot of crew lists and music lists, and get a real feel for the bay area rave scene.

I can't remember the first event I went to, but I think the first sfrave related thing was incognita. Was a lot of fun, and cheap drinks too. Didn't really notice any sfraves players at the time.

Might as well just cut to the big memories.

First big event with the sfraves crew, and introduction to three people was the Snow Party on the 21st Feb up past Sacto. Truly phenomenal - jungle, in the jungle, as I was saying, although it wasn't much of a jungle, more of a woods. The three who travelled up in my car, Delia, Sean and Osby, were all greatly amused at the pride I had in my Oldsmobile Cutlass Cierra, now known as Oldsmatron for it's ability to take a beating and still keep going. Had a little incident sliding off the icey road into a tree that kept the punters alert [read: scared], and certainly was the most eventful trip to the site ever. Arrived a bit late, was totally banging. Being the clever Australian that I am, I hadn't brought any shoes with me, only sandals, and this being a snow party, there was indeed very chilly snow on the ground. After deciding that wearing sandals all night would result in losing my toes, I got my thermal underwear out of my bag and wrapped it around my feet. This was working fine until I stepped in a pool of mud out the back, and now had wet icey feet. So then I ran to the fire, heated up my feet, then rewrapped them in clothes and tied plastic bags around my feet. I think I must of looked a little crazy wearing huge plastic bags on my feet and running around in my australian tracksuit. The tunes were amazing, and the outdoors scenery was fantastic. I will always remember dancing to jungle, and being able to look up through the trees at DJ EMP with snow hanging off the branches of the trees just behind him. Fantastic.

Great props to: Delia, Sean, and the pro-driver Osby who put in a lot of hard yards behind the wheel
Unprops to: The guy from Sac who thought he was a mad drug user and who thought he was solely responsible for us getting there because of the sfraves post - "I'm still seeing tracers";
the guy who was telling me that I was a dick and I was going to have to go to hospital for my feet 'when the drugs wear off'. I'm not an idiot mate, and I'm capable of checking if my feet are going blue or not.

After this there are a buncha good times, mostly going to jungle events such as jolly green jungle - I liked the DJs in suits and the plants, and Faultline 3. Really loved faultline 3 - the inperspective crew tore it up, and they were really friendly to me and my friends as we had common foreigner vibe. Loved the crazy mashup style. Also went to Donut - liked the free donuts - and a bunch of stuff at the tenderloft.

But the next big props have to go to Mindcontrol. That was a truly cracking event. I had no idea what a wall of sound was meant to be, but now I know. I liked the space odyssey 2001 feel of the speakers blocking the DJ, and really appreciated all the extra effort of the ppl running around in lab coats and quarantines etc. At first thought it was a bit silly, but later realised was really quite a lot of fun. Met a good bunch of the trust crew and had some good chats, but I think for me the real beauty was the jungle room. Total darkness was no exaggeration, couldn't see a thing, but could feel the bass ripping through me. No idea who was playing due to the wall, but loved the crazy mashed up hardcore beats, never really heard any jungle played like that in my whole time here, and absolutely loved it. My super favourite was the track, not sure who played it [would be glad for someone to enlighten me], with the vocals going 'madness.... madness', truly beautiful as was losing my mind a bit at that point. Also huge props to the techno room - not much of a techno fan, but was a good insight into the original days of raving - a warehouse, lots of crazy good dancing with glowsticks and poi, everyone totally pumped, and a few really drugged out punters along the walls. Was really full too considering the size of the space. Not enough techno gets played in australia I think, especially in Sydney/Canberra, so was good for me to hear some pretty funky stuff. Big props to the last techno DJ, kept it going till 7am, and dropped some stuff at the end that I really like, to me it seemed more kind of disco style, and all I could think about was Beverly Hills Cop - good times.

Reading the list before going, was wondering why everyone was saying 'I know it's a bit pricey, but these guys put on a great show every time, and the speakers alone are worth it'. Too true, I would lend full force of my words behind any trust event - if they put something on, go to it.

--

I've had a really great year here in general. There is no way I could go to any events of the magnitude or quality of the parties I have been to here. There has always been a good vibe and crew at every event. Throughout the year on this list, I have seen people posting about how 'rave is dead', a sentiment shared by old schoolers in australia too. I think this is nonsense. To all those people I say this: remember that at any event you go to, now matter how massive or commercial or lame, that if one person discovers the magic of raves as a result, then it is worth it. I discovered the magic of raves in my year here, and I'm sure that many more people are discovering this every year. Not every youngster is a candy kid, and not every candy kid is a youngster. You are very lucky in the bay, you have people throwing events with very talented musicians every weekend, and you are at the heart of the rave movement. You are in driving distance to sacramento and reno, which regularly have cool outdoors events. People in the bay appreciate good music, and they are presented with it everywhere they look.

Thanks a lot for all the good times, and keep in touch. I'm sure I'll be back as soon as I can manage it.

Matt.

PS - almost forgot, Osby, Im intrigued to hear that I am a 'uber neo candy skater punk'. Not sure if this is applied to me, but found it funny anyway.


This message was sent through MyMail http://www.mymail.com.au

Subject: [sfraves] POL: Fw: Government trying to use your money to defeat state politicians and ballots they dont like?

Anyone catch wind of this?

Note, this will allow the government to attack harm reduction organizations.



>LEGISLATION GIVES BUREAUCRATS POWER TO USE YOUR MONEY TO DEFEAT
>BALLOT MEASURES AND CANDIDATES
>
>Congress wants to use your money to tell you how to think and vote.
>Your help is needed TODAY to stop them. The House Government Reform
>Committee will consider legislation this Thursday, May 22nd that would

>allow Drug Czar John Walters to spend taxpayer money to influence
>voters to reject drug policy reforms.  The section is so broad it
>could allow the White House to use almost $1 billion in taxpayer money

>to run government-sponsored television ads against state and local
>ballot measures that enact drug policy reforms. It could even allow
>taxpayer money for partisan political purposes, such as government-
>sponsored attack ads against candidates the White House doesn't like.

>
>The provision is part of legislation reauthorizing the drug czar's
>office. It would renew the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign, a
>controversial ad campaign that cost taxpayers over a billion dollars in

>the last six years, despite numerous government studies showing it has

>failed to meet its intended goals of reducing drug use.  If approved by

>the full Congress, the drug czar's office would have almost a billion
>dollars over the next five years to spend on the failed media campaign,

>including ads telling voters to oppose drug policy reform. (For more
>information, see the "background" section below.)
>
>ACTIONS TO TAKE
>
>1) If you're from a state with Representatives on the House Government

>   Reform Committee, CALL THEM ALL TODAY (see list of Committee Members

>   and contact information below).
>   * Tell them to remove the section of HR 2086, the "Office of National
>
>     Drug Control Policy Reauthorization Act of 2003", that allows the

>     Drug Czar to use the media campaign for partisan political purposes.
>
>   * Tell them you strongly oppose using taxpayer money to run government
>
>     ads telling us how to vote and what to think.
>   * Urge them to also reduce the reauthorization of the National Youth

>     Anti-Drug Media Campaign to one year instead of five, consistent
>     with recommendations by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB).
>
>2) If you're from a state without a Representative on the House Government
>
>   Reform Committee, call your Representative and urge him or her to
>   pressure Members on the Government Reform Committee to take out the

>   propaganda provision.  To Find out who your Representative is visit:

>
>   http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=3685&l=1666
>   * Tell your Representative to do everything in his or her power to
>     convince the Government Reform Committee to remove the section from
>
>     HR2086 that allows federal bureaucrats to use taxpayer money to
>     influence elections. Tell your Representative to vote against any

>     bill that contains such a provision.
>
>3) Please forward this action alert to your friends and family. Unless

>   Congress hears from thousands of voters this bill and its dangerous

>   provision could easily become law.
>
>GOVERNMENT REFORM COMMITTEE
>

>BACKGROUND
>
>In 1998, the Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP) created
>the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign (Media Campaign). The
>Media Campaign was intended to reduce drug use among young people
>through the use of multi-media advertising and public communications
>strategies that included television, radio, and prints ads. Over the
>past six years, Congress has appropriated more than $1 billion to the
>Media Campaign, making ONDCP - and its primary private partner, the
>Partnership for a Drug Free America - one of the nation's largest
>advertisers.
>
>>From the start the media campaign has been embroiled in controversy.
>In addition to the numerous government studies finding the ads
>ineffective in reducing drug use, the Drug Czar's office has used this

>media campaign to bribe television networks to change their scripts
>and magazines to editorialize on certain subjects.  They were accused
>of violating federal law by manipulating measurement criteria to make
>the media campaign look effective, and faced Congressional heat over
>its decision to maintain contracts with Ogilvy & Mather - an
>advertising agency that has over-billed taxpayers for its work on the
>media campaign.  In addition, the recently canceled "drugs and terror"

>ads were roundly criticized from all quarters, including the
>Partnership for a Drug Free America, which called them off-strategy,
>and the Weekly Standard, which called the ads "propaganda worthy of
>the...Soviet Union."  The most recent anti-drug ads featuring teenage
>pregnancy and an accidental handgun shooting have been accused of
>promoting pro-life views and gun control.
>
>Congress took the first step last week in renewing the National Youth
>Anti-Drug Media Campaign, when the House Subcommittee on Criminal
>Justice, Drug Policy, and Human Resources, approved HR 2086, the
>"Office of National Drug Control Policy Reauthorization Act of 2003",
>a bill that renews the drug czar's office and the National Youth Anti-
>Drug Media Campaign. Chairman Rep. Mark Souder (R-IN) and Ranking Member
>
>Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-MD) both supported renewing the controversial
>ad campaign, despite the fact that the government's own studies have
>found them to be failures.
>
>Buried within Section 10 of HR 2086 are provisions amending the
>statutory ban on using the media campaign for "partisan political
>purposes" to allow the drug czar to use taxpayer money for partisan
>political purposes as long as the purpose is opposing drug
>legalization, including making marijuana legally available to AIDS and

>cancer patients. If enacted, the Office of National Drug Control
>Policy (which is ran out of the White House) could spend up to $195
>million of taxpayer money every year on radio, print, and television
>ads opposing medical marijuana laws and trying to defeat candidates
>that support more compassionate drug laws. It would also give whoever
>is President the power to use taxpayer money for political attacks on
>his or her opponents.
>
>The Drug Policy Alliance is urging Members of Congress to cancel the
>expensive ad campaign and spend the money on drug treatment, after-school
>
>programs and other prevention programs that cost less and are proven to

>work.  At a minimum, say experts at the Alliance, the propaganda
>provision should be taken out and the media campaign should be approved

>for only one year instead of five, consistent with recommendations of the
>
>Office of Management and Budget (OMB) that 2005 funding be contingent upon
>
>improved results.
>
>Government auditors and the President's budget submission for 2004 note

>that "The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign has not demonstrated
the
>
>results sought, and does not yet have adequate performance measures and

>related goals."  In addition, every study by the National Institute on
Drug
>
>Abuse (NIDA) has found the ads to be ineffective in reducing youth drug
use
>
>and could actually make youth more likely to use marijuana in the future.
>
>Even Drug Czar John Walters has admitted the media campaign is a flop,

>telling the Wall Street Journal "this campaign isn't reducing drug use."
>
>NIDA's most recent studies have found that the ad campaign not only fails
>
>to reduce drug use, but may actually make youth more likely to use
>marijuana in the future. According to NIDA, the ads may give youth the

>perception that drug use is common among their peers; and may also trigger
>
>what psychologists call "reactance" - the more someone is told what not
to
>
>do, the more they want to do it.  Other experts believe the ads are so

>ridiculous and over-the-top that young people dismiss them outright,
>assuming they're being lied to. NIDA's final evaluation of the program's
>
>effectiveness will be released later this year, presumably after Congress
>
>decides whether to renew the Campaign.
>
>++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Being broke and parties..

> p.s. MacAudioooo... $4k and a few months of stress
> is NOTHING compared to
> what a lot of people I know have dumped into making
> and promoting thier
> music & labels.  Just a thought.

yah.

isn't it weird that a few teenagers in Detroit can
create a whole world making records, while legions of
grown-ups are still struggling after years and years?

in Urb they had an interview with the three original
techno dons, and they described the early days -- most
of it went like this:

Derrick May: and then I stole my mom's car.
Juan Atkins: and then you stole my mom's car.
Derrick May: right, we drove my mom's car into Detroit
and it broke down. so we told her it was stolen and
then I stole Juan's mom's car.
Kevin Saunderson: and then you stole my brother's car.
Derrick May: right.
Kevin Saunderson: you told me you had a license.
Derrick May: yeah. I was 14, but I had this fake ID
that kinda looked like a license.

somewhere in this tale of serial car theft is the
secret wisdom which will enable you too to succeed in
the music business. what did Derrick May do? he stole
cars from friends and family.

so, obviously, I need a ticket to the next Friends and
Family. (and if anybody knows where I can get a good
lockpick, that would help too.)


Giles

At 12:20 PM 5/19/2003 -0700, innocentchild wrote:
>Apparently Come-Unity is back again, this time at Mezzanine. I thought 
>that Come-Unity was history after the last party at Kelly's. Apollo - you

Yes, I was going to post a BSP later in the week.  Come-Unity will 
celebrate its twelfth anniversary party this Friday at the Mezzanine.  I 
don't know what the plans are beyond this, but the party should be a 
welcome reunion for those of us who have been dancing with Malachy and his 
crew all these years -- and a great opportunity for folks who have never 
been to experience the family vibe.  Come-Unity was, and is, SFs oldest 
house party.

Much love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

hey matt,

you are definitely one of the more colorful characters
ive met in the sf scene. im really sorry to see you
go. you fucking kick ass man. one of the nicest
people. i enjoyed kicking it with you while i could.

--- mattsb@ozemail.com.au wrote:
> 
> Hey,
> 
> I'm about to leave the Bay having been here for a
> year, and thought I'd give a little wrap up on my
> year here, and how good it was in general.
> 
> Coming from Australia, with a pretty minimal rave
> scene, or at least nowadays, I wasn't really sure
> what to expect. After about a month, I finally
> thought it would be a good idea to subscribe to the
> sfraves mailing, list and this was certainly a well
> played move. From there I could subscribe to a lot
> of crew lists and music lists, and get a real feel
> for the bay area rave scene.
> 
> I can't remember the first event I went to, but I
> think the first sfrave related thing was incognita.
> Was a lot of fun, and cheap drinks too. Didn't
> really notice any sfraves players at the time.
> 
> Might as well just cut to the big memories.
> 
> First big event with the sfraves crew, and
> introduction to three people was the Snow Party on
> the 21st Feb up past Sacto. Truly phenomenal -
> jungle, in the jungle, as I was saying, although it
> wasn't much of a jungle, more of a woods. The three
> who travelled up in my car, Delia, Sean and Osby,
> were all greatly amused at the pride I had in my
> Oldsmobile Cutlass Cierra, now known as Oldsmatron
> for it's ability to take a beating and still keep
> going. Had a little incident sliding off the icey
> road into a tree that kept the punters alert [read:
> scared], and certainly was the most eventful trip to
> the site ever. Arrived a bit late, was totally
> banging. Being the clever Australian that I am, I
> hadn't brought any shoes with me, only sandals, and
> this being a snow party, there was indeed very
> chilly snow on the ground. After deciding that
> wearing sandals all night would result in losing my
> toes, I got my thermal underwear out of my bag and
> wrapped it around my feet. This was working fine
> until I stepped in a pool of mud out the back, and
> now had wet icey feet. So then I ran to the fire,
> heated up my feet, then rewrapped them in clothes
> and tied plastic bags around my feet. I think I must
> of looked a little crazy wearing huge plastic bags
> on my feet and running around in my australian
> tracksuit. The tunes were amazing, and the outdoors
> scenery was fantastic. I will always remember
> dancing to jungle, and being able to look up through
> the trees at DJ EMP with snow hanging off the
> branches of the trees just behind him. Fantastic.
> 
> Great props to: Delia, Sean, and the pro-driver Osby
> who put in a lot of hard yards behind the wheel
> Unprops to: The guy from Sac who thought he was a
> mad drug user and who thought he was solely
> responsible for us getting there because of the
> sfraves post - "I'm still seeing tracers";
> the guy who was telling me that I was a dick and I
> was going to have to go to hospital for my feet
> 'when the drugs wear off'. I'm not an idiot mate,
> and I'm capable of checking if my feet are going
> blue or not.
> 
> After this there are a buncha good times, mostly
> going to jungle events such as jolly green jungle -
> I liked the DJs in suits and the plants, and
> Faultline 3. Really loved faultline 3 - the
> inperspective crew tore it up, and they were really
> friendly to me and my friends as we had common
> foreigner vibe. Loved the crazy mashup style. Also
> went to Donut - liked the free donuts - and a bunch
> of stuff at the tenderloft.
> 
> But the next big props have to go to Mindcontrol.
> That was a truly cracking event. I had no idea what
> a wall of sound was meant to be, but now I know. I
> liked the space odyssey 2001 feel of the speakers
> blocking the DJ, and really appreciated all the
> extra effort of the ppl running around in lab coats
> and quarantines etc. At first thought it was a bit
> silly, but later realised was really quite a lot of
> fun. Met a good bunch of the trust crew and had some
> good chats, but I think for me the real beauty was
> the jungle room. Total darkness was no exaggeration,
> couldn't see a thing, but could feel the bass
> ripping through me. No idea who was playing due to
> the wall, but loved the crazy mashed up hardcore
> beats, never really heard any jungle played like
> that in my whole time here, and absolutely loved it.
> My super favourite was the track, not sure who
> played it [would be glad for someone to enlighten
> me], with the vocals going 'madness.... madness',
> truly beautiful as was losing my mind a bit at that
> point. Also huge props to the techno room - not much
> of a techno fan, but was a good insight into the
> original days of raving - a warehouse, lots of crazy
> good dancing with glowsticks and poi, everyone
> totally pumped, and a few really drugged out punters
> along the walls. Was really full too considering the
> size of the space. Not enough techno gets played in
> australia I think, especially in Sydney/Canberra, so
> was good for me to hear some pretty funky stuff. Big
> props to the last techno DJ, kept it going till 7am,
> and dropped some stuff at the end that I really
> like, to me it seemed more kind of disco style, and
> all I could think about was Beverly Hills Cop - good
> times.
> 
> Reading the list before going, was wondering why
> everyone was saying 'I know it's a bit pricey, but
> these guys put on a great show every time, and the
> speakers alone are worth it'. Too true, I would lend
> full force of my words behind any trust event - if
> they put something on, go to it.
> 
> --
> 
> I've had a really great year here in general. There
> is no way I could go to any events of the magnitude
> or quality of the parties I have been to here. There
> has always been a good vibe and crew at every event.
> Throughout the year on this list, I have seen people
> posting about how 'rave is dead', a sentiment shared
> by old schoolers in australia too. I think this is
> nonsense. To all those people I say this: remember
> that at any event you go to, now matter how massive
> or commercial or lame, that if one person discovers
> the magic of raves as a result, then it is worth it.
> I discovered the magic of raves in my year here, and
> I'm sure that many more people are discovering this
> every year. Not every youngster is a candy kid, and
> not every candy kid is a youngster. You are very
> lucky in the bay, you have people throwing events
> with very talented musicians every weekend, and you
> are at the heart of the rave movement. You are in
> driving distance to sacramento and reno, which
> regularly have cool outdoors events. People in the
> bay appreciate good music, and they are presented
> with it everywhere they look.
> 
> Thanks a lot for all the good times, and keep in
> touch. I'm sure I'll be back as soon as I can manage
> it.
> 
> Matt.
> 
> PS - almost forgot, Osby, Im intrigued to hear that
> I am a 'uber neo candy skater punk'. Not sure if
> this is applied to me, but found it funny anyway.
> 
> 
> This message was sent through MyMail
> http://www.mymail.com.au
> 
> 
> 
>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  With Patriot Act, companies forced to play informant on
  customers

--=====================_13949321==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

With Patriot Act, companies forced to play informant on customers

Section upon section of the law imposes new obligations on businesses to 
produce the personal records of their customers, or to spy and snitch on 
their customers as a condition of operating. Million-dollar fines and 
criminal liability are punishment for noncompliance.

By ROBYN E. BLUMNER

05/18/03: (St. Petersburg Times) We all know homeland security is an 
expensive proposition. Assault-weaponed forces standing guard in front of 
all the bridge and tunnel entrances in New York City don't come cheap. And 
the cost for airport inspectors from the Transportation Security 
Administration to fill barrels full of confiscated cuticle scissors at the 
nation's airports runs upwards of $5.8-billion annually.

But what you may not have realized is just how much of the expense of our 
antiterrorism efforts is being borne by private industry. The USA Patriot 
Act, well known as a law that sacrificed civil liberties in the name of 
national security, may also be one of the largest unfunded mandates on 
private business since Social Security.

Section upon section of the law imposes new obligations on businesses to 
produce the personal records of their customers, or to spy and snitch on 
their customers as a condition of operating. Million-dollar fines and 
criminal liability are punishment for noncompliance.

For example, under Section 215, one of the more notorious parts of the 
Patriot Act - the one librarians have been raising a ruckus over - the FBI 
has the power to obtain library records, e-mail logs and entire business 
databases of all sorts just by claiming that the information is relevant to 
a counterterrorism or counterespionage investigation. Before the law, to 
obtain business records law enforcement would have to demonstrate to the 
secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court that the records related 
to an individual who had connections to terrorism or a foreign government. 
But the Patriot Act strikes down these particularity constraints, promoting 
instead a fishing expedition. And since it makes no provision for 
reimbursing businesses ordered to produce the records, there is little cost 
to the FBI for demanding far more information than is necessary.

According to the December 2002 issue of CSO - chief security officer - 
magazine, 45 percent of the 797 businesses surveyed have given law 
enforcement or the government data on their customers, employees or 
business partners. Internet service providers, financial institutions and 
telephone companies especially are repeated targets. BellSouth, for 
example, received 32,370 subpoenas and 636 court orders for information on 
customers last year and has an entire team of people who do nothing but 
respond to law enforcement.

Tim Lynch, director of the Cato Institute's Project on Criminal Justice, 
who is concerned about this burden on business, recently wrote in Forbes 
magazine about a wireless carrier that received a subpoena in 2001 that 
listed 50 pages of telephone numbers. The carrier had five days to come up 
with customer records for every number listed.

And this is not the worst of it. There is another part of the Patriot Act 
that markedly expands the kinds of companies expected to spy on their 
customers. Banks have had to do this for decades, but the new law extends 
this responsibility to a vast array of businesses - anywhere there is a 
potential for money laundering - such as insurance companies, brokerage 
firms and even casinos, pawn brokers and jewelers. These businesses are now 
expected to know their customers' identity and financial habits, and report 
suspicious activities to the government.

The rules are so difficult to implement that a cottage industry of 
compliance products has come on the market. Mike Ernst, product line 
director for Sybase Inc., a California-based software company that offers 
Patriot Act compliance software, explains that his product will help 
companies thoroughly scrutinize every transaction with every customer in 
every part of the companies' business. "A bank may have an insurance or 
credit card division and is required to review a customer's activities 
across all these institutions," Ernst says. "You have to do a 360-degree 
customer review to make sure you're in compliance with the act."

He estimates Sybase's potential market for this software and technical 
guidance is 10,000 financial institutions - about 10 percent of all 
depository institutions. Multiply that by the $200,000 it costs on average 
to implement the Sybase system and you have a $2-billion market. And this 
is just a sliver of the number of businesses now obliged to act as spooks.

All this might be good news for Ernst and Sybase but it is not so happy 
news for private industry stuck with the bill, nor, of course, for the 
privacy of customers. Suddenly, nearly every business we interact with is 
acting as an extension of the FBI. And businesses that don't comply are hit 
hard.

Western Union and its parent company recently paid a combined $11-million 
to settle charges stemming out of its failure to have a system in place to 
report whether customers were wiring more than $10,000 in one day from 
different locations.

One would have thought the business-friendly Bush administration would have 
been a little more sensitive to the expensive burdens it was creating under 
the Patriot Act. But no. When it comes to eradicating Americans' privacy no 
price is too high.



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

I don't do drugs very often..and I am pretty much stone cold sober at parties, but I like my Binkies... My parents didnt belive in binkies...they were like "why should you give a kid a pacifier when they have a thumb?" My punk friend in high school, way back before we were ravers (her and me, I mean) used a binky to quit smoking, So I have been using one to quit biting my nails. I also like to pretend I am rolling so people will give me backrubs and lightshows, I save 20 bucks and a hangover that way.

Subject: [sfraves] Open Call: Promoters, Artist, Graphic Designers

--0-1681576062-1053386850=:62039
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

  Greetings, hopefully everyone is having a good year thus far and enjoying the springtime weather outside. This summer is action packed with multiple musical adventures and festivities.
 
  There's tons of Concerts, Music Festivals, Fairs, and Events all destined to hit the Bay Area. Make sure you take some time to get out and have some fun! 
 
  This year marks COOLWORLDs 12th year for producing music festivals and this summer will certainly be a season to remember! The COOLWORLD 2003 Events Calendar is action packed and will feature several eclectic & diverse events that are certain to surpass all expectations.
 
 In preparing for the events ahead, COOLWORLD is extending an Open Call to ALL Street Promoters, Marketing Gurus, Artist from ALL backgrounds, & Graphic Designers to assist in the Look & Feel of the COOLWORLD organization and the events ahead.
 
 Street Promoters: should be friendly, knowledgeable, humble, respectful, and eager to pass along event information (flyers).
 
 Artist: Graffiti, Abstract, Freestyle, Tapestries, Day Glo, Begginers, Intermediates, Professionals.
 
Graphic Designers: for Multi Media, Flyers, Web, Banners, Event Installations.
 
*If you fit these catagories or have something unique or special to bring to the table, please respond to this email with your name and your contact information and someone will respond to you shortly.
 
Thanks again and we look forward to having everyone out at one of our many events this summer!
 
COOLWORLD
 
visit us online @ www.coolworld.com

Subject: [sfraves] Funkybaby's Art work for sale

After 10 years of promoting parties I feel that it is time to pass on the torch to the younger generations. I have already sold the Funkybaby sound system to Triable souls. And now I want to give the community a chance to purchase a part of the Funkybaby legacy. 
I am selling two of our very large black light banners.
They have been taking very good care of with no holes in them and the black light paint is not chipping. Both are on heavy canvas and are very large. 6ft by 12ft. with a 1/2" steel pipe at the top to support it.
Time, paint and canvas is well worth the $300pr I am asking for each of them, or best offer. But what you are really buying is the magic and vibe that is in each one of these pieces of art work.
Please e-mail me if you would like to purchase one or both of these  black light banners.
I can send you JPG's of the banners for your viewing.
Thank you one and all for being such a big part of my life.
Rodney griffin
Funkybaby productions
