> > >
> > > >===== Original Message From Apollo
> > > <apollo@speakeasy.org> =====
> > > >Ravers hit in 'E' bust
> > > >BY J.K. DINEEN
> > > >Of The Examiner Staff
> > > >
> > > >     In the biggest local rave extravaganza since
> > > two died and four were
> > > >hospitalized from ecstasy overdoses at the Cow
> > > Palace in January, 10,000
> > > >glow-stick waving ravers sweated it out Saturday
> > > night at the San Francisco
> > > >Concourse Exhibition Center.
> > > >
> > > >     But last weekend the ravers had a few
> > > unexpected guests as well: 40
> > > >undercover state and local narcotics cops who were
> > > kept busy throughout the
> > > >night, arresting 41 ecstasy dealers and netting
> > > more than 1,000 pills.
> > > >
> > > >     Even though police made constant busts in the
> > > middle of the vast
> > > >pulsating party, billed as "Popsicle 5," ecstasy
> > > dealers continued to
> > > >accommodate undercover narcs with brown "Mickey
> > > Mouse" pills and blue
> > > >"dolphin" pills.
> > > >
> > > >     "You would think that making so many buys, the
> > > word would get out and
> > > >dealers would have slowed down, but I guess nothing
> > > was going to deter
> > > >them," said Paul Mulligan, special agent in charge
> > > of the San Francisco
> > > >office of the Bureau of Narcotic Enforcement.
> > > >
> > > >     Although the party was "over 18," five of
> > > those either arrested or
> > > >cited were juveniles, according to Capt. Tim
> > > Hettrich, who heads up vice
> > > >and narcotics. Two young women at the party were
> > > taken away in ambulances,
> > > >Hettrich said.
> > > >
> > > >     "There may have been 500 or 600 juveniles in
> > > this place," said Hettrich.
> > > >
> > > >     The Popsicle 5 drug sting was funded in part
> > > by a federal grant
> > > >focusing on "high intensity drug trafficking areas"
> > > and was the first in a
> > > >string of operations that will target raves. The
> > > program was prompted by an
> > > >increase of ecstasy overdoses throughout the
> > > country, Hettrich said.
> > > >
> > > >     Few of those arrested were San Francisco
> > > residents and only one had a
> > > >previous arrest here. Most were from the South Bay,
> > > the East Bay and the
> > > >Sacramento area. Ravers ranged from 18 to 25 years
> > > old; a large percentage
> > > >were Vietnamese and Cambodian.
> > > >
> > > >     Cops who participated in the raid say at least
> > > 80 percent were on
> > > >ecstasy. Partiers sat in circles on the floor,
> > > taking turns making circular
> > > >motions with their glow sticks. Bottled water -- at
> > > $4 a pop -- was
> > > >ubiquitous as were the pacifiers that prevent
> > > trippers from the
> > > >teeth-grinding that is a side-effect of the drug.
> > > >
> > > >     Ecstasy produces some of the speedy effects of
> > > methamphetamines as
> > > >well as hallucinations similar to mescaline, but
> > > milder. While many young
> > > >people see ecstasy as a euphoric party drug, it
> > > disrupts both body
> > > >temperature and cardiovascular system and can lead
> > > to hypertension,
> > > >hyperthermia, heart and kidney failure. Research
> > > has also linked long-term
> > > >use to problems with memory and cognition.
> > > >
> > > >     "Anyone who says we are targeting a specific
> > > community is wrong -- we
> > > >are targeting drug dealers," said Hettrich. "We are
> > > protecting these kids
> > > >from themselves. They don't think so, but when you
> > > have kids overdosing all
> > > >over the country from this stuff, their parents
> > > will be glad we are there."
> > > >
> > > >     The raid prompted complaints form the San
> > > Francisco Late Night
> > > >Coalition, according to Assemblyman Mark Leno and
> > > Supervisor Bevan Dufty.
> > > >Both politicians say they received a call about
> > > police tactics and are
> > > >still looking into the matter. The Late Night
> > > Coalition did not return
> > > >several calls requesting comment.
> > > >
> > > >     Popsicle 5 promoters "Mars, Mystre, and
> > > Dyloot" could not be reached
> > > >for comment. A message on the promoters phone says,
> > > "Hey everyone, thanks
> > > >for coming out to Popsicle 5 -- it was a wonderful
> > > event and hopefully you
> > > >had a wonderful time."
> > > >
> > > >     A veteran city DJ promoter called the event "a
> > > cheesy rave with
> > > >horrible, horrible music catering to tweaked out
> > > kids" who can't get into
> > > >over-21 clubs. He said Saturday's extravaganza drew
> > > a similar crowd as the
> > > >January Cow Palace rave.
> > > >
> > > >     "There is real danger, and real drug abuse in
> > > these," he said.
> > > >
> > > >     E-mail: jdineen@examiner.com
> > > >

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Poetry day?  Ok 'If I were Robert Frost'

I used to be a rushing river
Crashing to and fro.
With twists and turns and gnarled rocks
Always on the go.

Rarely a moment of serenity
My life moved swiftly by..
Whirlpools and rapid falls
My shores were never dry.

Then some pesky farmers came
And set up a little dam.
They told me it was necessary
For the good of common man.

As time went by my waters slowed
The foam was all but gone
A comfortable pace I took in time
And flowed just right along.

But over time the farmers left
And the dam had been kept up
As debris and junk flowed along
And gradually got stuck.

What once was fast slowed to a crawl
Hope was all but gone.
My turbulence and beauty now
Were but a stagnant pond.

And now I lay here waiting
Dreaming of the day
When by luck or chance
The dam my stagnancy decay.

(on corporate america and growing up)
-Rayn 01.16.2003

because of bart stopping at midnight. Last week I got
stranded in Berkeley, and learned that AC Transit runs
to SF all night, once an hour. 
* AC TRANSIT RUNS ALL NIGHT * (no more excuses osby:P)

downtown Oakland, ask the driver for an SF fare, its
about 3$, and I think the SF bus picks you up at 14th
and Broadway.

Any promoter, and i do mean any promoter is subject to fines and possible arrest if they produce a party or event where drugs are rampant.
 
More so the venue of any establishment runs the risk of the same treatment and could possibly find themselves on a goverment black list.
 
And to answer the question of who pays for all this???? The promoter. Plain as day. For those that think the promoter doesnt know that there are under cover cops in the party, etc....welcome to reality.
 
The promoter is the person who is footed the bill at the end of the day for ALL POLICE services. 
 
I think it's childish to blame massive promoters, etc for all these drug & cop related problems. Massives is a word that was created in relation to big events. 
 
But in retrospect, these large music gatherings have been happening since before our scene even started. Before the Oakenfolds and Tiesto's, there was Jimi Hendrix & Janis Joplin and the promoters were Bill Graham & Kenny Fender.
 
They too were dealing with same politics and bullshit. There audiences were much like the people we see at parties today. Just a different time and erra, but there was still a major drug problem.
 
Large Festivals are not the problem. To blame skills or anybody else for the demise of our civil liberties is short sighted. But i guess easier then believing the problem is your girlfriend and her two best friends....

State trying to stem tide of plastic water bottles
Officials want to increase recycling rate
Jane Kay, Chronicle Environment Writer
Friday, May 30, 2003
2003 San Francisco Chronicle | Feedback


URL: http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2003/05/30/BA210518.DTL


Health-conscious Californians are consuming so much bottled water -- and 
just throwing away the plastic containers -- that state officials are 
warning that the trend threatens to clog landfills and harm the environment.

"It's common in California to see someone walking down the street with a 
water bottle in one hand and a cell phone in another," said Mark Oldfield, 
spokesman for the state Department of Conservation.

"The sales of single-serve water bottles and, in fact, all plastic 
containers, have been skyrocketing for the last five years. If they're not 
recycled, they're going to be around for a long, long time," Oldfield said.

The conservation department is launching a campaign to raise public 
awareness of the problem and convince consumers to do a better job of 
recycling. Separately, a bill recently introduced in the state Senate would 
improve the incentive for recycling by doubling the deposit.

California has one of the highest per capita rates of bottled water 
consumption in the United States, according to industry figures, although it 
trails behind European countries such as Italy and France.

But according to the state's report, only 16 percent of water bottles are 
being recycled, well below the overall container recycling rate of 60 
percent. The rest of the bottles -- more than 1 billion plastic containers a 
year -- are thrown away and end up in landfills.

In 10 years, the discarded bottles would be enough to create a two-lane, 6- 
inch-deep highway stretching the length of the 1,100-mile coast.

The water-guzzling public can change all that, says the report. If recycled,

the bottles can find life after death in carpets, soft foam, fiber-fill and 
clothing. Most water bottles are made of PET, or polyethylene terephthalate, 
the type of plastic that has the greatest recycled market value.

Coca-Cola and Pepsi, which distribute filtered municipal bottled water under 
the labels of Aquafina and Dasani, have asked for a greater amount of 
recycled raw materials to use in the production of new bottles. Coke is 
working toward its goal of using 10 percent recycled plastic in 25 percent 
of the bottles.

"There is a market for recycled PET in building materials and some clothing.

Recycled PET is a good, pure stream of raw material," said Bob Achermann, 
executive director of the California Nevada Soft Drink Association, which 
represents the major bottlers.

Achermann attributes the popularity of bottled water to its convenience. 
"I'm old enough to realize that people used to walk around without bottled 
water. We used to be camels before. Now we have to be hydrated."

Californians Against Waste, the lead environmental group lobbying for 
greater recycling, supports raising the deposit as a way to increase the 
state's overall container recycling rate. That rate fell from 78 percent in 
the mid-1990s to 60 percent in 2002.

Democratic Sens. Byron Sher of Palo Alto and John Burton of San Francisco, 
have introduced a bill that would double the deposit to 5 cents on 
containers less than 24 ounces. The deposit is returnable at reverse-vending 
machines and recycling centers.

The bottlers' association likes the part of the bill that changes the way 
its members pay a processing fee. But it opposes raising the redemption 
value. "If people want to raise (the deposit) to encourage recycling, we 
don't know if that will accomplish the task," said Achermann.

California's deposit is too low to create the proper incentive for 
recycling, according to the Container Recycling Institute in Arlington, Va., 
a group that analyzes success rates. To prove that a higher deposit works, 
the group points to Michigan, which puts a 10-cent deposit on carbonated 
beverages and has a 95 percent recycling rate.

"The saddest part about all of this," said Mark Murray, executive director 
of Californians Against Waste, "is that we should be cleaning up our water 
so people can just turn on the tap and they don't have to buy it."

of the neighbors and keep your noise levels down when outside. Thank you.

food is not to be missed...

60 Things Not to Say to a Naked Guy 
1. I've smoked fatter joints than that. 
2. Ahh, it's cute. 
3. Who circumcised you? 
4. Why don't we just cuddle? 
5. You know they have surgery to fix that. 
6. It's more fun to look at. 
7. Make it dance. 
8. You know, there's a tower in Italy like that. 
9. Can I paint a smiley face on that? 
10. It looks like a night crawler. 
11. Wow, and your feet are so big. 
12. My last boyfriend was 4'' bigger. 
13. It's ok, we'll work around it. 
14. Is this a mild or a spicy Slim Jim? 
15. Eww, there's an inch worm on your thigh. 
16. Will it squeak if I squeeze it? 
17. Oh no, a flash headache. 
18. (giggle and point) 
19. Can I be honest with you? 
20. My 8-year-old brother has one like that. 
21. Let me go get my tweezers. 
22. How sweet, you brought incense. 
23. This explains your car. 
24. You must be a growing boy. 
25. Maybe if we water it, it'll grow. 
26. Thanks, I needed a toothpick. 
27. Are you one of those pygmies? 
28. Have you ever thought of working in a sideshow? 
29. Every heard of clearasil? 
30. All right, a treasure hunt! 
31. I didn't know they came that small. 
32. Why is God punishing you? 
33. At least this won't take long. 
34. I never saw one like that before. 
35. What do you call this? 
36. But it still works, right? 
37. Damn, I hate baby-sitting. 
38. It looks so unused. 
39. Do you take steroids? 
40. I hear excessive masturbation shrinks it. 
41. Maybe it looks better in natural light. 
42. Why don't we skip right to the cigarettes? 
43. Oh, I didn't know you were in an accident. 
44. Did you date Lorena Bobbitt? 
45. Aww, it's hiding. 
46. Are you cold? 
47. If you get me real drunk first. 
48. Is that an optical illusion? 
49. What is that? 
50. I'll go get the ketchup for your french fry. 
51. Were you neutered? 
52. It's a good thing you have so many other talents. 
53. Does it come with an air pump? 
54. So this is why you're supposed to judge people on personality. 
55. Where are the puppet strings? 
56. Your big gun is more like a BB gun. 
57. Look, it fits my Barbie clothes. 
58. Never mind, why bother. 
59. Is that a second belly button? 
60. Where's the rest of it?

Subject: Re: [sfraves]How come skills hasn't been arrested?

--- Troy Sheets <tsheets@atari.saturn5.com> wrote:
> Just becuase the law is on the books, it does not
> mean they will use it
> all the time.

yes indeedy. keep in mind that the rave act is
seriously questionable from a legal standpoint. the
last thing that the bullshit artists who put it
together need is to see some district judge throw out
a rave act prosecution citing any or all of the
numerous problems, both practical and constitutional,
with that particular law. it would only encourage the
ACLU to mount a serious opposition, and if there's any
law the ACLU could take down, among the blizzard of
bullshit laws we've had since Bush became "President,"
that's it. (the patriot act is even bigger bullshit,
but politically almost untouchable.)

so, because of this, imagine you're a Fed. you've got
this handy-dandy new law that sounds great but in
practice could easily explode in your face. so, where
do you use this law? in the single most liberal city
in the United States? or in some other place, like
Atlanta or Nashville, where the judges are less likely
to throw out your case?

Skills is safe, for now.


Giles

Subject: [sfraves] neobeatnik dot com goes THUD

to whom it may concern!

if you've been wondering what happened to all the new
music from me, well, I'm still making it, but my web
host is having issues from hell. I tried to upload a
bunch of tracks, a simple task that should have taken
four minutes, and I'm giving up after three &$@*%#!
days. the most I was able to do was get part of this
one online:

http://www.neobeatnik.com/richmond.mp3

actually it's almost the whole thing, the whole thing
was a big song tho. anyway, if you're wondering why
it's called "Richmond," it was part of a Bay Area
geography trio with two more songs called "Fremont"
and "Menlo Park." unfortunately neither of those two
survived the unusually harrowing upload process.


Giles
